At the -same time, \nyou will be starting an academic adventure of \nchallenging courses taught by a variety of profes\xad\nsors, all of whom demand your best work. \nThe \namount of studying required of you will be far \ngreater than anything you have previously experi\xad\nenced. \nThe helpless feeling of how much you \nDON’T know will engulf you, as it does every stu\xad\ndent.\nPinpointing each classroom experience, how\xad\never, is the excitement of learning. \nUnlimited \nhorizons of knowledge, which are yours for the \npursuit, can and should be an enthralling part of \nyour college career.\n', 56, 0), (1499.355712890625, 394.62591552734375, 1741.98046875, 547.0133666992188, 'You will find that many upperclassmen are \nguilty of a crime which dulls the sharpest profes\xad\nsor too quickly. Students who sit in stupors, ask\xad\ning no questions and never engendering discus\xad\nsions, destroy the fire which should be lit and re\xad\nkindled each time that students and professors \nmeet. As incoming freshmen, you are challenged \nto retain your enthusiasm in the classroom and to \nseek the joy inherent in true learning.\nEncountering new people who will absorb your \ntime and thoughts is an essential in university life. \nNothing can be more rewarding than penetrating \nthe ideas of another individual, coming face to face \nwith the bare core of that person. \nTake time to \nenjoy the exchange of perspectives to which the\n', 57, 0), (1750.35546875, 321.91864013671875, 1992.2791748046875, 547.0022583007812, 'isolated college community is so conducive. Give \nof yourself only to those groups which you find \nworthy of your participation.\nBut be alert for a danger whiph stalks all stu\xad\ndents. The loss of that which is genuine may not \nworry you in the whirl of parties, pins and puns, \nbut that value slips away far too easily. Borrow\xad\ning a few moments to live in review the events of \neach day helps to preserve one’s sanity and ac\xad\nquaint him with himself.\nYou will change as a product of rapid exposure \nto new ideas and experiences. Don’t be afraid of \nwhat is happening to you, but continue to judge \nyourself critically. \nEveryone has a controlling \nhand in his own development; that grasp should \nbe firm and sincere.\nShakespeare. has perhaps expressed it best in \nHamlet, as Polonius advises his son Laertes:\n“This above all,\nTo thine own self be true\nAnd it must follow as the night the day;\nThou canst not then be false to any man.”\n', 58, 0), (1254.063232421875, 562.8635864257812, 1839.543212890625, 614.8635864257812, 'Welcome\n3LUirimrUtan\n', 59, 0), (1522.86328125, 620.0569458007812, 1716.212158203125, 633.0569458007812, 'BU C K N ELL U N IV E R SIT Y\n', 60, 0), (1930.36328125, 587.9069213867188, 1992.3673095703125, 600.9069213867188, 'Freshmen \\\n', 61, 0), (1249.9622802734375, 647.8521118164062, 1991.4239501953125, 659.5521850585938, 'VOLUME LXIII\nLEWISBURG, PA„ FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 23. 1960.\nNUMBER I.\n', 62, 0), (1249.2623291015625, 679.761962890625, 1512.02734375, 747.7991943359375, 'Dorms, Class Buildings \nImproved Since Spring\n', 63, 0), (1248.77099609375, 753.6000366210938, 1400.80419921875, 1201.7958984375, 'This summer m arked the be\xad\nginning of an extensive building \nand renovation program on the \ncampus. \nIn order to meet in\xad\ncreased enrollment, the fourth \nfloor of Harris has been converted \ninto residence quarters for 39 \nwomen. Hardly a day passes \nnow without a steady progression of wagons from the mountains \ncarrying large supplies of surplus grains, lumber, hides, and other \nproducts to the port.\nDue to the increase in trade, local industry is fast oq the rise. \nSeveral new foundries, tanneries, mills, and boat yards have recently \nbeen established. \nThe population has risen to 1220 persons.\nPerhaps the best way of realizing the extent of the development \nin this area is to compare the Lewisburg of today with the town as \nit was in 1813. The population in those days was a mere 250 persons. \nIndustry was confined to one primitive nail factory and, two very \nsmall tanneries. There were no churches then, but seven taverns, a \ndistillery, and a brewery were very much in existence. \nThe taxes \ncollected that year came to only $98.88. Trading as we have come to \nknow it today did not even exist.\nIt seems incredible that so much progress could be achieved in \nso short a period. \nBut the facts indicate that Lewisburg is well on \nits way to becoming one of the top ports in the area.\n', 16, 0), (568.0689697265625, 730.0693359375, 721.0205688476562, 962.467529296875, 'cers Association, \nthe Pennsyl\xad\nvania Bankers Trust For today I \nbegin my seventh year of writing columns for the makers of \nMarlboro Cigarettes.\nSeven years! Can it be possible? It seems only yesterday I \nwalked into the Marlboro offices, my knickers freshly pressed, \nmy cowlick wetted down, my oilcloth pencil box clutched in \nmy tiny hand. “Sirs,” I said to the makers of Marlboro—as \nhandsome an aggregation of men as you will find in a month \nof Sundays, as agreeable as the cigarettes they make—mild yet \nhearty, robust yet gentle, flip-top yet soft pack \nSirs, \nI \nsaid to this assemblage of honest tobacconists, “ I have come to \nwrjte a column for Marlboro Cigarettes in college newspapers \nacross the length and breadth of this great free land of America.\nWe shook hands then-silently, not trusting ourselves to \nspeak—and one of the makers whipped out a harmonica and we \nsang sea chanties and bobbed for apples and played \nRun, \nSheep, Run,” and smoked good Marlboro Cigarettes until the \ncampfire had turned to embers.\n“What will you write about in your column?” asked one of \nthe makers whose name is Trueblood Strongheart.\n', 72, 0), (1461.3477783203125, 1094.2547607421875, 1564.6358642578125, 1110.2547607421875, "'§ o é t \n$\n", 73, 0), (1442.8988037109375, 1120.9930419921875, 1693.698974609375, 1487.822998046875, '“About the burning issues that occupy the lively minds of \ncollege America,” I replied. “About such vital questions as: \nShould the Studfent Council have the power to levy taxes? \nShould proctors be armed? Should coeds go out for football?” \n“ And will you say a kind word from time to time about \nMarlboro Cigarettes,” asked one of the makers whose name is \nHonor Bright.\n“ Why, bless you, sirs,” I replied, chuckling silverly, ‘ there \nis no other kind of word except a kind word to say about \nMarlboro Cigarettes—the filter cigarette with the unfiltered \ntaste—that happy combination of delicious tobacco and ex\xad\nclusive selectrate filter—that loyal companion in fair weather or \nfoul—that joy of the purest ray serene.”\nThere was another round of handshakes then and the makers \nsqueezed my shoulders and I squeezed theirs and then we each \nsqueezed our own. ^ id  then I hied me to my typewriter and \nbegan the first of seven years of columning for the makers of \nMarlboro Cigarettes.\nAnd today as I find myself once more at my typewriter, once \nmore ready to begin a new series of columns, perhaps it would \nbe well to explain my writing methods. I use the term “writing \nmethods” advisedly because I am, above all things a methodical \nwriter. I do not wait for the muse; I work every single day of \nthe year, Sundays and holidays included. I set myself a daily \nquota and I don’t let anything prevent me from achieving it. \nMy quota, to be sure, is not terribly difficult to attain (it is, \nin fact, one word per day) but the important thing is that I do \nit every single day. This may seem to yotl a grueling schedule \nbut you must remember that some days are relatively easy— \nfor example, the days on which I write “the” or “a” . On these \ndays I can usually finish my work by noon and can devote the \nrest of the day to happy pursuits like bird-walking, monopoly, \nand smoking Marlboro Cigarettes.\n°  \n©  1960 Max Shulman\n* \n* \n*\n', 74, 0), (1450.80810546875, 1493.7230224609375, 1695.5711669921875, 1521.8729248046875, 'The makers of Marlboro are happy to bring you another \nyear of Max Shulman’s free-wheeling, uncensored column \n—and are also happy to bring Marlboro Cigarettes, and for\n', 75, 0)]

August.\n(Continued on page 8)\n", 17, 0), (428.89776611328125, 442.0852355957031, 579.6978759765625, 798.460205078125, 'by Jane Tilton\nPaul Johanne Tillich, noted \nProtestant Theologian, in his ad\xad\ndress, “Creative Listening” pre\xad\nsented a refreshingly different \nview of the value of an education \nat Wednesday’s Convocation.\nThe real meaning of the word \ncreativity, Dr. Tillich explained, \nlies in this mythical interpreta\xad\ntion of the term. Creation is an \nact by which that which hafe no \nbeing is brought into living. Man \nin and of himself cannot actually \ncreate, yet creativity is quite pos\xad\nsible. Indeed it is creativity that \nproduces freedom. \nHis charac\xad\nterization of any nation which \ntakes for granted that it is unam\xad\nbiguously right and all others \nwho have opposing views are un\xad\nambiguously wrong, as sick, serv\xad\ned as a bitingly accurate descrip\xad\ntion of the problems facing us \ntoday. That conformity which so \nmany modem writers condemn \nproduces a lack of freedom des\xad\ntroying creativity. We are chain\xad\ned not by law, but rather by me\xad\nchanically spontaneous responses \nto life.\nMan, claims Tillich, can be \n| creative only when he is able to \n! listen. His mind must be open, \n! for knoWledge cannot enter a \nlocked \ncompartment. \nLife \nis \n“mysterious and open, profound \nand on the surface, sublime and\n', 18, 0), (580.0977783203125, 440.2102355957031, 730.1978149414062, 797.957275390625, 'profane”. \nIt is a series of un\xad\nsolved paradoxes. As is life, so \nis Man. \nSince equal attracts \nequal, any object can be a med\xad\nium through which the Eros can \nbe achieved.\nThree Types\nTillich discussed three types of \n“Creative Listening”: the Aca\xad\ndemic, Conversational, and Lis\xad\ntening to Ourselves. So often the \ncollege student never really lis\xad\ntens. \nHe goes through college \nwaiting for the stimulating pro\xad\nfessor, the outstanding course; \nhe fails to realize that the Eros is \nfound instead in Reality itself. \nWe can be creative only when we \ncan be open to the Reality, only \nwhen we can experience it. Crea\xad\ntive education can never be a \npassive experience; instead it \nmu?t be a matter of personal con\xad\ncern. Only when we experience \nthis concern or the will to change \nwhat we learn, can creativity \nexist.\nCreative listening can and does \ntake place in interaction between \npersons. Typical college conver\xad\nsations usually do more to hinder \nthan help the process. Kennedy and Vice-President Richard F. \nNixon played marbles with political trivia for an hour \nWednesday night.\nIn his opening statement about America’s standstill, \nKennedy spoke glibly of rights due a Negro baby born in \nthis country. Nixon countered Kennedy’s statement with \nthe declaration that America was on the move and had \nbeen so for the past seven and a half years. \nHe did not \ntouch on the question of civil rights at any time during \nthe evening.\nMore than half of the program time consisted of replies \nto questions formulated by four representatives from \nsponsoring networks. \nOne reporter confronted Nixon \nwith President Eisenhower’s remark that he could think \nof nothing contributed by Nixon during his term of office. \nRising to the occasion with equanimity, Nixon countered \nhis ipquisitor with the assurance that Ike’s remark was \nmerely facetious, for he could not possibly reveal the \nidentity of his advisors.\nDulling a barbed question, this repartee was as dazzling \nas the glittering generalities of “freedom” and “progress” \nwhich dripped like sticky honey from Kennedy’s tongue.\nWhat was the good of these debates? \nNeither man \nconcerned himself with major issues of party or country. \nVying with each other to- present the most scintillating \nimage of potential presidency, both candidates fingered \ncliches with surprising ease.\nOn a stark stage, Peck’s Bad Boy extolled the virtues \nof a democratic platform surprisingly similar to that of \nthe Republicans, described in words from the cadaverous \nface of the vice president. Having no audience reaction \nto play their words against, Kennedy and Nixon struggled \nto appear keen opponents of each other.\nThe result was an ineffectual discussion, leaving the \nviewer with little or nothing on which to base his allegi\xad\nance. \nThe candidates took no distinct stands on major \nissues, sallying instead from side to side in an attempt to \npick up votes. \nEven traditional party ideologies were \nabsent from their speeches. Compromising for the sake \nof votes has reduced the level of competition to the per\xad\nsonal appeal of Kennedy versus that of Nixon.\nWe would hope that the next three debates, scheduled \nfor October 7, 13 and 21, will show that the two candi\xad\ndates have committed themselves to stands on major is\xad\nsues. Surely Nixon can speak of living standards in terms \nless emotional than, “poverty I have known.” Similarly, \nKennedy’s “rendezvous with destiny” seems hardly the \ncampaign note of a Nobel Prize \nnecessary evil. \nThe procedure was simple: (1) Receive \nstudent ID cards; (2) fill out address cards for switchboard \nand handbook use; (3) pick up treasurer’s release slip; (4) \nobtain registration envelope. \nWhy did it take each stu\xad\ndent at least half an hour to go through these four steps? \n(We will not comment on the further time required for \nthose who had schedule could be mailed in advance \nand returned prior to registration day. Perhaps including \nthese cards in the registration envelope, with directions \nto fill them out before leaving the gym, would also elim\xad\ninate some confusion and minimize the time spent in reg\xad\nistration.\nRetarding the process most, however, was a lack of per\xad\nsonnel prepared to handle the registration influx. Sure\xad\nly, more student help could be utilized at such points as \nthe ID card pick-up station, and in the distribution of \nname and address cards, treasurer’s release cards and \nclass schedules. It is an institution that promises to grow into \none of the top schools in the nation.\nLast year the trustees feeling that their efforts far obtaining sub\xad\nscriptions would be successful built the first building on the college \ngrounds. (Classes were previously held in the Baptist Church). With \nthe completion of Taylor Hall, the university was able to instigate \nstill another first in its history, coed classes. \nThe measure while still \na radical one in college circles is a sensible one. \nThe girls occupy \nthe west side of one of the large rooms on the second floor of Taylor \nHall and must face the West at all times, the young men are confined \nto the east side of the room and similiarly are required to face the \nEast.\nIn commenting on the monumental advances that have been \nmade here in the past three years, Dr. Taylor has released the follow\xad\ning statement:\n“Three years ago last November we commenced with abso\xad\nlutely nothing. \nAt the date of this record, October 1, 1849 we \nare permitted under the blessing of Heaven to witness the fol\xad\nlowing results:\nA University Charter obtained, a farrn of seventy acres in the \nBorough of Lewisburg, now valued at $12,000, belonging to the \ntrustees and affording as good a site for the University as can be \nfound between the Atlantic and the Pacific, a substantial brick \nedifice erected at an expense of $8,000; Following is a \nlist of simple instructions which, if faithfully observed, will \npositively guarantee that you will be a mad success as a \nsorority girl.\nFirst, let us take up the matter of housemothers. The \nhousemother is your friend, your guide, your mentor. You \nmust treat her with respect. When you wish to speak to her, \naddress her as “ Mother Sigafoos” or “ Ma’am.” In no circum\xad\nstances must you say, “Hey, fat lady.”\nSecond, let us discuss laundry. Never hang your wash on \nthe front porch of the sorority house. This is unsightly and \nshows a want of breeding. Use the Chapter Room.\nThird, meals. Always remember that planning and preparing \nmeals for a houseful of healthy girls is no simple task. Your \ncook goes to a great deal of trouble to make your menu varied \nand nourishing. The least you can do is show your apprecia\xad\ntion. Don’t just devour your food; praise it. Exclaim with \ndelight, “ What delicious pork jowls!” or “ What a yummy soup \nbone!” or “ What scrumptious fish heads!” or “ What clear \nwater!”\nFourth, clothing. Never forget that your appearance re- \n■ fleets not just on yourself but on the whole house. It was \nwell enough before you joined a sorority to lounge around \ncampus in your old middy blouse and gym bloomers, but now \nyou must take great pains to dress in a manner which excites \nadmiring comments from all who observe you. A few years ago, \nfor example, there was a Chi Omega named Camille Ataturk \nat the University of Iowa who brought gobs of glory to all her \nsorors. Camille hit on the ingenious notion of suiting her garb \nto the class she was attending. For instance, to English Lit she \nwore a buskin and jerkin. To German she wore lederhosen and \ncarried a stein of pilsener. To Econ she wore 120 yards of \nticker tape. Her shiningest hour came one day when she \ndressed as a white mouse for Psych Lab. Not only her Chi \nOmega sisters, but the entire student body went into deep \nmourning when she was killed by the janitor’s cat.\n', 67, 0), (1433.027587890625, 1288.76513671875, 1678.762939453125, 1470.782470703125, 'Finally, let us take up the most important topic of all. C. course. \nIn doing so, however, the student stands to \nlose much more than he gains.\nDifficult courses, challenging professors and honors sec\xad\ntions offer rewards far more valuable than a high grade- \npoint average. \nFor one thing, material in such courses is \npresented in a searching and extensive manner, with a \nresulting gain in concrete knowledge. \nMare important, \nhowever, is the intangible factor of the student’s personal \ndevelopment.\nIt is only through challenge, through asking more .of \nhimself than he hs done before, that the individual’s high\xad\nest abilities may be realized. \nThe student who is willing \nto measure himself against standards more fundamental \nthan letter-grades will choose his courses on the basis of \nthe challenge they offer him, and un\xad\nless they have been accustomed to it at home. \nSome person in \nLewisburg should be entrusted with the funds, expend it as re\xad\nquired, and render exact accounts. \nMany a student has been Kennedy \nand Vice President Richard \nNixon is scheduled for Friday, \nOctober 7 at 7:30 p. m. \nOrig\xad\ninating in Cleveland, the pro\xad\ngram will forego debates, fea\xad\nturing an hour of questions \nposed by a panel of news re\xad\nporters.\nIn 1956, our government offer\xad\ned to give economic and to help \nbuild the Aswan Dam. The snorkel, con\xad\nsisting of a basket mounted on a \nfolding ladder, is designed to put \n.one or two men with fire hoses \non top of the fire. \nThe entire \noperation is controlled by the \nman in the basket, through use \nof airplane-type controls. \nIt is \npossible for him to swing the i \nsnorkel, ladder and basket, all \naround the roof of a tall building, \nthus facilitating rescue as well as \nfire-fighting.\nThe Pitman Company last week \ndemonstrated the snorkel on Hunt! \nHall and East College. Miss Mary \nJane Stevenson, dean of women, \nMiss Sylvia Ohanesian, assistant \ndean of women, and Mr. John \nZeller, vice president of the Uni\xad\nversity, rode to tfce roofs of the \ndormitories on the snorkel during \nthe demonstration.\n', 63, 0), (1404.64892578125, 1358.0489501953125, 1550.993408203125, 1561.0367431640625, 'Swim Club Chooses\n*\nFifteen After Tryouts\nAfter performing a series of \ndolphins, surface dives and ballet \nlegs, the new Synchronette mem\xad\nbers were chosen on October 5. \nNew additions to the synchroniz\xad\ned swimming group are Martha \nO’Dell, \nAndrea Becker, \nCarol \nPatterson, Donna Sirerek, Char \nEdwards, Carolyn Thornes, Sue \nKoch, and Susan Bechtold.\nOther new members are Mar\xad\ntha D’Alessandro, Donna Fred\xad\nerick, \nStxzanne \nSeville, \nLynn \nStruggles, Nancy Smith, Lin Car- \ndozo and Pam Squires, bringing \nthe total club membership to 32 \ngirls.\n', 64, 0), (1551.2889404296875, 430.0367736816406, 1698.37451171875, 820.8333740234375, '^ Dr. Mark C. Homecoming is a weekend when \nold grads return to their alma maters to watch a football game, \nvisit old classrooms and dormitories and inspect each other’s \nbald spots.\nThe weekend is marked by the singing of old songs, the slap\xad\nping of old backs and the frequent exchange of such greetings \nas “ Harry, you old polecat!” or “ Harry, you old porcupine!” \nor “Harry, you old rooster!” or “ Harry, you old wombat!” \nAs you can see, all old grads are named Harry.\nIt is not just old grads who behave with such liveliness during \nHomecoming; the faculty also comports itself with unaccus\xad\ntomed animation. Work that \nis being done by students just \nlike us and through aid given by \nmany Bucknellians last year.\nLast year and again this year j \nthe emphasis o f the World Uni\xad\nversity Service is on Community \nDevelopment in Africa. \nThese \nCommunity Development projects \nare designed not only to meet the \nneeds of the particular villages, \nbut also to meet the needs of | \nAfrica’s \nincreasing number of \nuniversity students. \nWUS has \nreported and I found out this \nsummer that the African univer\xad\nsity student states as his chief \nconcern his relative isolation from \nhis colleagues in other countries \nand from his own village. There\xad\nfore, recognizing this need, WUS \nwith a generous offer from Ford \nFoundation conducted a seminar \nin 1959 to study techniques and \nsponsor Community Development \nwork camps in Sierra Leone and \nGhana.\n', 10, 0), (128.91017150878906, 734.9955444335938, 275.6787109375, 976.4650268554688, 'Tw ofold Purpose\nThe purpose of Community De\xad\nvelopment projects is twofold. \nFirst, materially it is designed to \nencourage the villagers to im\xad\nprove their own community by \nimproving their facilities, like \nwater supply, building schools \nand houses by their Own labor \nand \ninitiative. \nSecondly, \nbut \nmore important is to bring Afri\xad\ncan students from all parts of \nAfrica together; The rules for other \nstates are as follows:\n•New York: Applications can be \nmade to the Board of Elections of \nthe county or borough of resi\xad\ndence before November 1.\nNew Jersey: Students request \nballots from the county clerk of \nthe county in which they live be\xad\nfore Oct. 31.\nConnecticut: Applications can \nbe made to the town clerk up to \nelection day.\nDelaware: Students have until \nOct. 29 to apply to the Depart\xad\nment of Elections of their county. I\nMaryland: The deadline is Oct. \n19. \nStudents should write to the ! \nSupervisor of Elections in the \ncounty or city of his residence.\nMassachusetts: Write to your \ncity or town clerk any time up to \nelection.\nOhio: Each county Board of I \nElections will accept applications | \nup to the elections.\nVirginia: November 1 is the \ndeadline for applications address\xad\ned to the County Voters’ Registrar \nof the students home county.\n', 72, 0), (1103.51025390625, 884.8588256835938, 1257.699951171875, 1556.0037841796875, 'by Bob Scot!\nThe Judical Board of the Men’s \nStudent Government has operat\xad\ned in its present form for five \nyears. \nThe original court was re\xad\ndefined and reorganized by Dean \nHayward.\nUntil recently the board only \nmade recommendations concern\xad\ning cases to the administration. \nNow, any decision made, with the \n.exception of those which involve \nséparation from the University, is \nfinal. \nSeparation decisions, that \nis: suspension or expulsion, are \nstill in the form of a recommend\xad\nation. \nTo this date, every decis\xad\nion has been executed.\nResponsibilities\nAs a part of MSG, the Judicial i \nBoard is responsible for the gen\xad\neral conduct and actions of all : \nthe male students. \nIt not only | \npunishes, but helps or refers in -. \ndividuals to helpful agencies. Re\xad\nhabilitation is an important part \nof discipline.\nAnother aspect of the Board’s ! \nresponsibility \nconcerns \ntown- 1  \ngown relations: to repair and \ncreate good sentiment with the ! \ntownspeople \nand \npolice force. \nFor example, the Judicial Board \nrecently held a banquet for the \nPolice Chiefs in the area with the \nrepresentatives of student govern\xad\nment organizations. \nNot only \nwas a working relationship with ■ \nthese people facilitated, but ques\xad\ntions of policy and ordinances : \nwere discussed.\nProcedure\nThe Board operates on a three \npoint foundation which may vary \nwith the needs of each case. \nThe \nBoard discusses and deliberates \ncases after receiving a statement \nfrom the police, if involved; the \nadministration, if involved; and \nthe student. \nMembers of the t \nBoard often interview persons \ndirectly or indirectly involved in \norder to have as complete a story \nas possible. \nThen, the individual \nis called before the board so that \nhis .side may be heard. \nAfter a \nperiod of interrogation, the de\xad\nfendant is excused and the Board \nmembers deliberate, reaching a \ndecision. \nA majority vote of the \nnine members is necessary to es\xad\ntablish a decision, while a recom\xad\nmendation for dismissal requires \na two-thirds vote.\nThree Penalties\nBriefly, a number one warning \nentails a strong verbal reprimand; \na number two decision might re\xad\nquire a “campus” probation, or a | \nletter home. \nThe number three\n', 73, 0), (1254.7083740234375, 885.5537719726562, 1400.843994140625, 914.9536743164062, 'penalty is a recommendation for \nseparation from Bucknell. \nSuch \n(Continued on Page 12)\n', 74, 0), (1254.9583740234375, 934.5394897460938, 1362.086181640625, 975.5394897460938, 'MOCK ELECTION \nSET FOR NOV. 1\n', 75, 0), (1254.0059814453125, 983.253662109375, 1400.6748046875, 1356.101806640625, "Is it true that as Bucknell goes, \nso goes the Nation? It is an exhilarating sensa\xad\ntion. \nI knew that the first jump \nwas going to be the biggest thrill \nor the worst experience of my \nlife. \nI must- admit that I was \nterrified as I tumbled backwards \nhead over heels for those first few \nseconds. \nHowever, after the re\xad\nassuring jolt of the opening can\xad\nopy, I took a grateful glance up\xad\nward at that beautiful silk, and \nmy confidence soared. \nAt that \nheight (2000 feet) it appeared as \nthough I were suspended and not \ndescending at all. \nIn a few fleet\xad\ning moments the sighteseeing was \nover and I was After the customary rigors \nof examination and cross exam\xad\nination, Jane Carson was admit\xad\nted to the group of one thousand \nundergraduates \nprivileged \nto \nspend the summer in Europe un\xad\nder the auspices of The Experi-! \nment.\n', 4, 0), (133.9073486328125, 416.6830139160156, 430.2180480957031, 1077.0765380859375, "ing of what those miles mean to \nthe people who inhabit them. To\xad\nward this end the European pil\xad\ngrimage is arranged on a ‘Family \nPlan’.\nEach student is assigned a host \nfamily by The Experiment. Those \nwho are not fluent in any foreign \nlanguage are dispatched to family \ngroups where at least one person \nspeaks English. Some countries, \nFrance in particular, will not ad\xad\nmit candidates who are not fluent \nin the native tongue.\nJane's Family\nJane Carson spent her four \nweeks as an ambassador-guest \nwith a middle-aged couple in \nBaden, Switzerland. \nHer Swiss \nparents spoke fluent French but \nno English. Baden is in the Ger\xad\nman section of Switzerland where \nthe local tongue is a dialect of \nGerman derivation totally incom\xad\nprehensible to most Germans. \nThe Bucknell junior found no \n. great barrier, for the Swiss are \ngenerally a very linguistic people. \nMany are fluent in German, \nFrench and Italian, and the new \ngeneration invariably understands \nEnglish.\nIn' the course of several side \ntrips with her host fafnily Jane \nvisited Lausanne, Geneva and \nShauffhausen (The City of the \nRhein Falls). \nHer favorite city \nwas Bern, a metropolis abounding \nwith quaint remembrances of \nI small Swiss towns. Bern harbors \nI lovely capitol buildings, Countless \nclock towers, flowery window \nboxes, and of course the Bear Pits \nwhich gave the capitol its name.\nWar Orphans\nThe Experiment sponsors its \npilgrim participants by providing \ncontacts, special information and \nchartered \ntransportation. \nStu\xad\ndents ordinarily pay their own \nfare, although The Experiment \noffers several scholarships to out\xad\nstanding candidates who could \nnot otherwise participate in the \noverseas program. Trans-Atlantic \ntraffic usually involves charter\xad\ned planes and ships. \nAfter ar\xad\nriving in Europe, students separ\xad\nate into groups of 10 according to \ngeneral destination. Though they \nlive separately, group members \nfrequently meet for hosteling and \ncasual side trips.\nItineraries\nThe \nExperiment’s \nitineraries \nare established with a definite \naccent, placing emphasis, not on \nthe amount of mileage covered, \nbut on the student’s understand-\n", 5, 0), (280.10723876953125, 849.426513671875, 430.207275390625, 1077.07421875, 'Her most memorable event was \n| her visit to the International \n| Home for War Orphans at Pesta- \n| lozzi, Switzerland. This orphan- \nj age is a modest monument to the \nI success of Pestalozzi’s experiment \ni in international living. Students in sororities and fraterni\xad\nties stayed up all night stuffing paper napkins in chicken \nwire in order to entertain the citizens of Lewisburg for an \nhour the next day. Women in small dorms spent hours \nof time stringing tin cans and painting spotted leopards \nin competition for a prize.\nThis year, more than in others, a conflict was presented. \nSix weeks grades reared an ugly head and leered at stu\xad\ndents over the coffee cup and the cocktail glass. Expect\xad\ned, on the one hand, to produce the usual colorful decor\xad\nations for Homecoming, and on the other, to contribute to \ntheir studies an extra amount of work, students gave the \nworst half of their time to both.\nFar from condemning the new academic approach \nwhich has stiffened old courses and created challenging \nnew Honors sections, we raise the question of “The Old \nBucknell” versus the “New.” \nFloats were created this \nyear by a small nucleus of people, and the antagonism \nagainst those “who didn’t have time to help” was bitter. \nHouse decorations were hung with a maximum of grumb\xad\nling and a discouraging lack of spirit.\nIf this university is to concentrate on learning, and we \nassume that that is its primary goal, perhaps the tradi\xad\ntional Homecoming activities should be re-evaluated. It \nwould seem that the house decorations in the Sem could \nbe discarded without losing much sentiment or sleep. For \nthose traditionalists who wish to keep the parade, student \nenergy might better be divided between floats and studies \nthan between studies and a host of insignificant decora- \nions.\nAt the risk of being considered eggheads, we commend \nthe invasion of challenging young minds on the teaching \nstaff and the pulled-up bootstraps of what have been tra\xad\nditionally “Q. C. courses.” \nIsn’t it a shame that student \nresponse to these innovations should be negligible during \nthe two weeks that “scholars” are preparing for and re\xad\ncovering from Homecoming?\nAlthough better scheduling of Homecoming with the \nbarrage of tests preceding six-week grades is a partial so\xad\nlution, the conflict between the “Old” and the “New” \nBucknell is yet to be resolved. \nAs students, we cannot \nconsider ourselves members of a university and still damn \nthose who study in preference to stuffing paper napkins.\n', 5, 0), (163.8898468017578, 894.3380737304688, 404.2899475097656, 919.3380737304688, 'Everyone Can Vote\n', 6, 0), (146.38995361328125, 927.3597412109375, 424.46978759765625, 1242.1405029296875, 'On Tuesday, November 1, Bucknellians will, we hope, \nflock to the polls one week before the rest of the nation. \nAn election will be held on this campus in which all stu\xad\ndents and faculty members may vote, regardless of age \nor out-of-state residence. The purpose of the election is \nto generate some genuine political enthusiasm on the part \nof those unfortunately “set apart” from the excitement of \nthe American political scene.\nConceivably, the entire student body can support such \nan endeavor by posting campaign signs and wearing cam\xad\npaign buttons for Kennedy and Nixon. Those who cannot \nvote in the national election may show their favor for the \nparty of their choice by taking the time to fill out a ballot \non Tuesday.\nColeman Hall will feature polling places manned by po\xad\nlitical science students. The results of the balloting will \nbe published in the Bucknellian and will offer valuable \ninformation as to party affiliations of those attending this \nparticular university.\nMock conventions and mock elections have been a \nsource of enthusiasm and political concern on campuses \nacross the nation for years. The value of such an event \nat Bucknell may only be measured by the support of those \nwho step out of their well-worn ruts to manifest an inter\xad\nest in national affairs.\nIt is possible that the mock election will be a dismal \nfailure. \nIf this happens, we may consider the student \nbody worse than dismal arid certainly a failure. \nIf we \ncall ourselves well-informed and consider ourselves citi\xad\nzens of an enlightened country, we must accept the re\xad\nsponsibility of voting.\n', 7, 0), (217.18894958496094, 1252.9967041015625, 356.5929870605469, 1269.9967041015625, '(2H?? Yet \nthere is lacking that old spark, \nthat old ingenuity which used to \nmake fortunes overnight.\nHowever, one should not lose \nconfidence, because there are ex\xad\nciting opportunities still left for \nthe \nunscrupulous, \nambitious \nyoung man of today in this great \nland of ours. Various businesses \noffer almost unlimited chances for \npublic exploitation and profit\xad\nmaking. \nTake, for example, the \noperation of a college book store. \nAt first look, the prospects aren’t \nespecially attractive, but under \nthe right supervision, an extreme\xad\nly lucrative practice could be es\xad\ntablished.\nLocation of Book Store\nHere is how one should go \nabout it. Locate your book store \nat a rural university that is re\xad\nmoved from any commercial cen\xad\nter. \nThe reason for this is that \nnear a metropolis, other sources \nj are available for the student to \nbuy his books and he might not \npay your pripes. \nIt is imperative \nthat yours be the only outlet so \n| that your prices can be as high as \ni you want.\nStudent Co-Operative\nYou might also object that com\xad\npetition with a student co-opera\xad\ntive that buys and sells books \nfrom year to year at cost would \nruin your business. The student \nj cp-operative, \nwhich \nexists \non \nmany of our larger campuses, is \na very dangerous threat and must \nj be exterminated at any price. A \nvery neat and subtle way to do \nj this is to renew negotiations with\n', 19, 0), (732.501953125, 872.162109375, 884.8460693359375, 1358.0078125, "the faculty and arrange it so that \ndifferent textbooks be required \nj each successive year. The lower \n¡case student co-operative, in this \n| case, will be impossible to main- \n! tain since its stocks will become \ni obsolete from year to year.\nStockpile Old Books\nAnother advantage to be gain- \ni ed by this system is to stockpile \n| all old books bought back from \n! students at the end of their terms \nj (at a minimum price, of course), \nj and in three or four years redis- \nI tribute these old books at almost \n] original price. For example, con\xad\nsider a book wholesaling at $5. \n'You charge the student, say, $8.50, \ni profiting $3.50 in the initial trans- \nj action. You buy back said book \nfor, say, $2.50 (maintaining it is \nobsolete), and redistribute it years \nlater for, say, $5, profiting $2.50 \n¡in \nthe \nsecondary \ntransaction.\nI Multiplying this gain on one book \nby a thousand would make any \nnormal \nbusinessman’s \nmouth \nwater.\nImportance of Name\nDon’t call concern, say, “Smith’s \n! Book Store,” but rather name it \nsomething like “The University \nBook Store,” thus creating the \nimpression that it is run by the \nadministration and therefore is \nI above all reproach. \nA kickback \nmight be necessary here tpo but \nas they say, “ You gotta pay your \nway.”\nHere, then, is your hypothetical \nbusiness. \nThe beauty of it is \nthat no salesmanship is necessary \n—your clientele come to you. \nAnd what a clientele—wealthy \nchildren who have no regard for \ncost or worth but merely send \ntheir bills home. Both candidates have \nmade many speeches, have been \nseen by enormous crowds, and \nhave traveled extensivley. \nBoth \nSenator Kennedy and Vice Presi\xad\ndent Nixon have campaigned vig\xad\norously in their pursuit of votes. \nIn the process, the American pub\xad\nlic has become quite familiar with \nQuemoy and Matsu, Cuba, and \nthe concern about the prestige of \nthe United States. The resulting \ngain in public knowledge is ques\xad\ntionable.\nThere is no denying that Que\xad\nmoy and Matsu and similar prob\xad\nlems are important to the well \nbeing of the United States. \nIt \nmust also be realized that these \nare problems that would affect \nthe entire world and not just the \nelectorate of the United States.\nOne wonders whether or not \nthe public should not be more in\xad\nterested in more practical issues, \nespecially the domestic affairs of \nour country. It is this broad as\xad\npect of affairs which will decide \nif the United States is going to \nbe able to maintain its prestige \nand world power. It is the do\xad\nmestic sector which should decide \nwhich candidate is to determine \nand to initiate the programs \nwhich would increase our eco\xad\nnomic growth.\nMajor Issues Arguable\nA marked lack of emphasis has \nbeen placed on this area by both \ncandidates. They have both been \nguilty of making major issues out \nof lesser points which were inter\xad\njected into the campaign. \nThey \nwould rather be seen on television \nwhere they can be asked probing \nand embarassing questions by re\xad\nporters. The end result has been \na quibbling and an emotional ef\xad\nfect. This seems to be the effect \nthat the American public enjoys \nas they meet the personalities \nwho are running for President of \nthe United States.\nShould not we, the public, de\xad\nmand a greater exploration of the \nbasic campaign issues? Modern technology, the increasing \nimpersonality of social contact, and the shrinkage of the \nglobe by means of advancements in transportation and \ncommunication have necessitated this far-sighted plan\xad\nning in order to insure the efficient functioning of society.\nBut then there is our own dear University, who, in her \nefforts to combat conformity, has reverted to the idea of \nformulating short-term plans. \nIt seems like only last \nspring that coeds began using the newly completed stair\xad\nway leading to Tustin Gym. And now this same stairway \nis being removed. \nThere is a new wing (undreamed of \nlast spring, of course!) being added to the gym, and these \nsteps are now in the way.\nThe grass in the academic quad in front of the library \nwas so nice and green (after it finally grew high enough \nto cover the scars left by the construction of Coleman \nHall), and then someone decided that trees might enhance \nthe area. \nSo the grass was uprooted. \nThe turf barely \nhad time to recover before someone realized that a water \nmain had to be laid between Coleman Hall and the new \nAdministration Center. Since the workmen couldn’t quite \nburrow from one building to the other, the grass “got the \nax” again.\nOh, yes! You must have noticed by now the face-lift\xad\ning job recently done on Bucknell’s highway system. The \nmost noticeable of these additions and corrections is prob\xad\nably the disappearance of the roadway from Vaughan \nLiterature Building to Davis Gym. It seems that the plan\xad\nning program calls for a circuitous route between these \ntwo points. The highway system has now been rounded \nout, at least temporarily, by that splendid boulevard, lov\xad\ningly known as Geiger’s Super Highway, which cuts \nstraight across campus in a most essential direction.\nAll is not lost, however, because the considerate plan\xad\nners have provided sidewalks to complement the highway \nsystem. Of course the cross-walk at the Vaughan Liter\xad\nature Building isn’t situated just right, and everyone cuts \nacross the grass (intended grass, that is). \nBut this is a \nsmall matter, and wholly in tune with the present plan\xad\nning program.\nThese energetic planners certainly do deserve a vote of \nconfidence. How'else could the University be consistent \nin its physical improvement program and still avoid con\xad\nforming to the long-range trend now being adopted else\xad\nwhere in the United States?\n", (427.88037109375, 879.5219116210938, 724.6051635742188, 1096.119873046875, 'by Jane Tilton\nLewisburg 1891\nThe football record at Bucknell this year is one that we of Lew\xad\nisburg feel obligated to comment. \nIn spite of the fact that Bucknell \nis still considered one of the smaller eastern colleges, they have man\xad\naged to produce a team that was able to beat Lafayette 16 to 10, State \nCollege 12 to 10, and Cornell University 4 to 0.\nThese triumphs are to the credit of the team. \nThey have been \nforced to play their games under every possible disadvantage. \nBeing \nwithout a coach, as well as sufficient time in which to practice, the \nmen seem to win by pure determination. \nFor instance it has been \nreported by one member of the Cornell football team that Bucknell \nhas but one signal: “One, two, three—give me the ball.”\nYet Bucknell football has certainly come a long way from its \nmeager beginning in a game with Lafayette only eight years ago. \nNever having played football before, the team was literally forced to \nlearn the gameas it played it. \nThe original team consisted of but \n11 men and one substitute. The game was played with little previ\xad\nous practice; as a matter of fact, no member of that first team had \never even seen a football game, no less played in one. \nThe final \nscore: Lafayette 59, Bucknell 0.\nCongratulations to the Bucknell football team. \nWe comment on \nyour past and look hopefully to your future.\n', 19, 0), (429.33038330078125, 1105.619873046875, 724.4981079101562, 1123.2197265625, '“Flattery is like perfume. \nThe idea is to smell it, not swallaw \nit,” recommends The Keystonian, of Keystone Junior College.\n', 20, 0), (743.4703979492188, 371.50982666015625, 852.2103271484375, 394.50982666015625, 'LETTERS TO \n', 21, 0), (739.6704711914062, 407.95880126953125, 849.4274291992188, 430.95880126953125, 'THE EDITOR\n', 22, 0), (723.0714721679688, 436.7287902832031, 874.7471313476562, 1117.7178955078125, 'Dear Bucknellians,\nIn a very short time this year’s \nReligion-in-Life Program will be \nat hand. \n(Nov. 13-16 and Nov. \n20). I am writing this letter in \norder to acquaint you with the \ntheme for this year’s program and \nto give you some necessary in\xad\nformation.\nAfter studying for four years at \nBucknell, what will our college \neducation mean to us? \nWill it \nsimply be a degree for degree’s \nsake, or will our degree symbolize \na much greater and more mean\xad\ningful \neducational \nexperience? \nHow can our campus activities \nin classrooms, in fraternities and \nsororities, and in campus organiz\xad\nations contribute to our educa\xad\ntional experience? These are just \nsome of the questions that have \ncome up while we were discuss\xad\ning our theme for this year’s pro\xad\ngram, The Idea of the University.\nLast week we read an editorial \nin this newspaper pointing out \nthe basic differences and confus\xad\nions apparent between the idea of \nthe “old Bucknell” and the “new \nBucknell”. We feel that our Re\xad\nligion-in-Life Program this year \noffers \na great opportunity \nto \neveryone—faculty, students, and \nadministration—to see if Bucknell \nis really where we want it to be \nor to investigate roads of further \nimprovement and clarification.\nOur program this year will of\xad\nfer the opportunity for student - \nfaculty discussions about our edu\xad\ncation. \nWe have three excellent \nleaders coming in to present their \nviews on this very topic—The \nIdea of the University. \nThese \nthree leaders are: Dr. \nHarold \nTaylor, Dr. Victor Yanitelli, and \nDr. Shubert Ogden.\nWe have planned to have an \n“ all Bucknell” panel one evening \nmade up of professors and stu\xad\ndents who will attempt to see how \nthe Idea of the University relates \nto our 744.0468139648438, 'THE PARTY WEEKEND: ITS CAUSE \nAND CURE\n', 75, 0), (1428.5087890625, 751.8892822265625, 1676.5870361328125, 1043.33642578125, 'With the season of party weekends almost upon us, my mail of \nlate has been flooded with queries from young inmates of women’s \ncolleges wishing to know how one conducts one’s self when one \nhas invited a young gentleman for a weekend, so let us today \ntake up this burning issue.\nWell, my dear girls, the first thing to remember is that your \nyoung gentleman is far from home and frighteried. Put him at \nhis ease. You might, for instance, surprise him by having his \nmother sitting in a rocker on the station platform when he gets \noff the train.\nNext, what kind of corsage should you send your young gentle\xad\nman? Well, my beloved maidens, orchids are always acceptable. \nSo, indeed, are phlox and delphinium. In fact, most any flora \nwill serve. Do try, however, to avoid carnivorous plants.\nIf you find, my esteemed fillies, that your local florist has run \nout of stock, do not be dismayed. Make a corsage out of paper. \nBut pick good, stiff, durable paper—twenty dollar bills, for \nexample.\nRemember at all times, my fond wenches, to show your young \ngentleman courtesy and consideration. Open doors for him, \nwalk on the traffic side of the path, assist him to the punch bowl, \nzip his parka, light his Marlboros. (What, you ask, if he doesn’t \nsmoke Marlboros? Ridiculous, my precious nymphs! Of course, \nhe smokes Marlboros! Don’t you? Don’t I? Doesn’t everybody \nwho knows a hawk from a handsaw? What other cigarette \ngives you such a lot to like? Such easy-drawing filtration? Such \nunfiltered taste? Such soft pack or flip-top box? No other, my \nsweet minxes, no other. Marlboro stands alone, and any man \nworthy of you, my estimable damsels, is bound to be a Marlboro \nman.)\n', 76, 0), (1434.957763671875, 1052.33642578125, 1447.240234375, 1060.83642578125, 'NS\n', 77, 0), (1433.5078125, 1066.80078125, 1506.1439208984375, 1104.2535400390625, 'm.\nIll\n', 78, 0), (1450.558837890625, 1146.1865234375, 1456.8487548828125, 1154.6865234375, 'If\n', 79, 0), (1650.248779296875, 1206.4365234375, 1665.44677734375, 1214.9365234375, '\\\\\\\n', 80, 0), (1434.6988525390625, 1227.0865478515625, 1683.037109375, 1489.9847412109375, 'If you will follow the simple instructions stated above, my \ngood lasses, you will find that you have turned your young \ngentleman into a fast and fervent admirer. There is nothing \nquite like a party weekend to promote romance. I am in mind \nof a party weekend some years ago at Miss Pomfritt’s Seminary \nfor well-born females in West Linotype, Ohio. Serafina Sigafoos, \na sophomore at this institution, majoring in napkin folding, sent \nan invitation to a young man named Fafnir Valve, a junior at \nthe Joyce Kilmer School of Forestry, majoring in sap and boles. \nSerafina had been ape for Fafnir since high school, but Fafnir \npreferred a girl named Gelia Fleshwound, the high school drum \nmajorette who once threw a baton so high she impaled a south\xad\nbound mallard.\nAnyhow, Serafina sent an invitation to Fafnir, and he came, \nand she showered him with kindness and cuff links, and then \nhe went away, and Serafina sat anxiously by the mailbox, \nwondering whether she would ever hear from him again. Sure \nenough, two weeks later she got a letter: “ Dear Serafina, Can \nyou let me have fifty bucks? Yours, Fafnir.”\nWhimpering with ecstasy, she ran to the bank and withdrew \nthe money and mailed it to him. When I re\xad\nturned this September I was quite concerned with the problem of \nfinding someone to read to me. \nThanks to your interest, the problem \nof finding readers has virtually been solved. \nI now have an ever in\xad\ncreasing list of people who are willing to read to me, and as some of \nthem know already, reading to me is not quite so hard as some may \nimagine. \nThey are finding such work not only to be helpful to me, \nbut a help to them.\nI hope that this shall continue to be the case, for I like the pro\xad\ncess of reading to be a two sided affair, where both parties benefit.\nTo those of you that are now reading to me, I do not think that a \nmere “thank you” as expressed by these printed words is sufficient, \nbut in many cases, words are often lacking in their ability to express \nfully the feelings behind them.\nSay Hello\nFor those of you who have stopped to make my acquaintance I \nam' grateful. \nAs I said in that first article, I would like to meet as \nmany people as possible and to get to know them.\nFear not, I w ill not, upon you introducing yourself to me, grab \nyou and say “Read to me.”  \nIf you are interested in doing reading, it \nw ill be left up Jo you to say so.\nMy World\n“My World” is the title under which I hope to write, during the \ncourse of this coming year, various articles telling of my world. \nIt \nis true that each of us sees the world in a different way. \nBut, know\xad\ning that to many of you my world would seem quite different from \nthat which you know, I hope that the world in which I live and the \nworld in which you live may prove to be connected. \nFor is not “ my \nworld” also your world?\nOne of the questions which I am frequently asked is: “How doi \nyou get around.” \nPerhaps one of the reasons why this question is \nso difficult to answer is that I myself do not really think about how \nI  get around. \nJust as you, day after day, go from here to there and \nback again Without really thinking about each step, so it is with me. ]\nW e all know how to walk, but if asked how to do it, most of us \nwould probably take a considerable amount of time in forming a \nclear informative answer to this question. \nSo it is when you ask me \nhow I get around; I must stop and think how to answer you as simply \nand understandably as possible. \nJust as each of you had to learn to \nwalk, I too had to learn some “tricks of the trade” of traveling. Many \nthings have become almost second nature now.\nI might as w ell begin with the most obvious of my “ tricks,” that \nis, my cane. \nI took a course at Overbrook in the use of a cane for \ntraveling. \nNaturally as with everything else, most of what I know \nabout using a cane has been learned through experience.\nCane Touch \n.\nAs you know, the sense of touch is very important to me. \nThe \ncane I carry is actually a means by which I am able to feel the \nground before me and know, to a greater or lesser degree, what is in \nmy path. \nThe cane is, in reality, an extension of my finger. \nCon\xad\ntrary to the general belief of most people, the cane is not used, ex\xad\ncept in rare incidents, to make a tapping noise.\nIt is used to tell the difference between the paved walk and the \nground or grass along side the walk. \nThus I use the edge of the] \nwalks as a guide to assist me in my travels. \nNaturally, if I happen \nto misjudge the edge of the walk, I may find myself on another path. \nHere at Bucknell where there is so many angled paths, it is very easy \nto get off a couple of degrees. \n.\nKeeping my general direction is very important also. \nIf you \nwere to transport me to some place completely unknown to me and \njust set me down there, I would have to take some pains to find out \njust which way to go. When coming to a new place for the first time, \nI usually have someone walk me to the various places where I am to \ngo. Thus I build up in my mind a sort of mental direction picture \nof where various buildings, etc, are located.\n", 49, 0), (1272.953857421875, 604.0172119140625, 1345.825927734375, 612.0172119140625, 'BESHIR KASSIS\n', 50, 0), (1239.103759765625, 628.4671630859375, 1381.9676513671875, 657.1170654296875, 'by Beshir Kassis \nOn June 14, 1830, a French ex\xad\npeditionary force of 37,000 men\n', 51, 0), (1380.953857421875, 362.0670471191406, 1537.7938232421875, 654.71484375, 'conquered Algeria after a war \nlasting 17 years. \nFollowing the \nassertion of-French military au\xad\nthority in the occupied territory, \nsteps were taken both in Algeria \narid France to assimilate and in\xad\ntegrate the Algerians. \nBut the ] \nAlgerian masses had clung des- \nperately to their Arabic tradition \nof language and it became ex-1 \ntremely difficult to overcome this j \nstrong attachment.\nThe Algerian National Move-1 \nI ment goes back to the few years j \nbefore the first World War. Today’s front page carries the name of the Presi\xad\ndent-Elect of "the United States. \nIf it is the name of \nSenator John F. Kennedy the experts will say that he \nbenefitted from the debates. If the name is that of Vice- \nPresident Nixon, the talk will be that he overcame the \nsetbacks he suffered as a result of the debates.\nThe purpose here is not to decide who came off best \nfrom the debates, but to express our hearty approval of \nthem-. There is no way as effective in gauging the respec\xad\ntive merits of two men as seeing them together in face to \nface exchange. \nIt is hard to judge the actual impact of \nany of the instruments of mass media, however the de\xad\nbates were a test of mind and not fiery oration, which is \nso effective in politics, and were therefore beneficial.\nThe Bucknellian has not taken a stand for either party, \nrather we have tried to evaluate the important develop\xad\nments in the campaign. ap\xad\npearing, as it were, to be merely \na segment of human existence \nlifted, quite arbitrarily, out of \ncontext. \nThere seems to be no \nbeginning, middle, and end in \nsuph drama, nor is anything solv\xad\ned, resolved, or completed.\nAt the beginning of The Lower \nDepths, we see a group of dis\xad\ncouraged individuals and at the \nend we see this same group in the \nsame state of mind, minus a few \ncharacters who have died. \nIt \nwould seem as if nothing has hap\xad\npened, nothing has been settled. \nBut, of course, a great deal has \nhappened in the transition and \nmuch accomplished.\nCharacters\nWe have come to understand \nthe 16 characters in the play as \ndistinct and separate individuals \nby their responses to their en\xad\nvironment and to the old man, \nLuka. \nIf nothing is drastically \nchanged at the end, it is not be\xad\ncause of the playwright’s inepti\xad\ntude, but because of the charac\xad\nters themselves.\nThe Baron, played by Bruce \nMatthews, an example of the idle, \nirresponsible aristocrat suddenly \nthrown upon his own resources, \nnever develops because of his es\xad\nsentially insubstantial nature and \nlimited mentality. \nBubnoff, the \nrealist of the play, stubbornly re\xad\nsists the idealistic nonsense of \nLuka and remains a detached \nobserver throughout.\nStage Position\nNotice that he stays on the left \nside of the stage for almost the \nentire action, indicating his ad\xad\namant \nposition. \nAndrushka \nKleshtch, portrayed by Mr. Ward \nHooker, places himself on the ex\xad\ntreme right and is «manually \nbathed in an erie green light. He \nis in the opposite condition from \nBubnoff—utterly smashed by his \nenvironment.\nHowever, Nastya, Satine, the \nActor, Vaska, and Natasha occupy \nthe \nmiddle \nground—not quite \nsubdued by their surroundings \nand still able to visualize a bet\xad\nter existence. \nAnd into this at\xad\nmosphere comes the old 1 man, \nLuka, the catalytic agent, bring- \nng promise and chance for escape. \nThe reaction is immediate—the \nhopeful fasten onto him for in\xad\nspiration \nwhile \nthe \nwretched \nscorn and abuse.\nChrist Image\nA Christ without a heaven, the \nold man spins fantasies and par\xad\nables to elleviate his people’s \nmisery. \nMany act on his advice \nand find themselves in worse con\xad\ndition than before—Vaska mur\xad\nders, the Actor commits suicide, \n(Continued on page 4)\n', 88, 0), (1567.69091796875, 1367.9908447265625, 1707.7288818359375, 1403.69091796875, 'Honorary Hosts \nFuture Lawyers\n', 89, 0), (1565.291015625, 1409.513916015625, 1714.0623779296875, 1558.6634521484375, 'This weekend Sigma Delta Pi, \nthe Sapnish Honorary, is playing \nhost to nine pre-law students from \nEl Salvador visiting Bucknell un\xad\nder the auspices of the U. There is simply not room enough for both men \nand women in our overburdened colleges; therefore, in all fair\xad\nness, women who have far less need of a degree than men, must \nyield their places.\nWell sir, when I heard this drastic proposal, I was so shocked \nthat I sat right down and lit a Marlboro. I always sit right down \nand light a Marlboro when I am shocked. I also always sit right \ndown and light a Marlboro when I am not shocked. There is \nno time, no condition, no mood, no estate when it isn’t a source \nof soul-deep gratification to settle back and have a full-flavored \nsmoke—Marlboro, the filtered cigarette with the unfiltered taste \n—Marlboro, the jewel of cigarettes—Marlboro, the pinnacle of \nthe tobacconist’s art—Marlboro, my comfort, haven, and snug \nharbor.\nWell sir, I sat smoking my Marlboro and thinking over the \nshocking proposal to keep women out of coed schools, and hoping \nfervently that another solution can be found. If the calamitous \nday ever comes when women are banned from coed collèges, I \nwill gnash my teeth and rend my garments and take to my bed \nwithout supper. Like any other Marlboro man, I love women. \nI love the sight and sound of them, the cut of their jibs, their \nbeauty and grace, their cunning little spitcurls, their sleek \ndimples, their middy blouses, their aura and effluvium. More\xad\nover, I freely admit that when it comes to brainpower, they can \ngive the average man cards and spades and big casino too. It \nwould be a shame, a disgrace and a catastrophe to keep these \nbeautiful, intelligent creatures out of college.\nHowever, it is always wise in time of fair weather to prepare \nfor foul. What if the advocates of keeping women out of college \nbegin to gather strength? We who abhor this fiendish plan must \nbe ready with a substitute . . .  and it just so happens I have \none—and a mighty ingenious little plan it is,, if I say so myself.\nGranted that classroom seats are in short supply, and granted \nthat men need degrees more than women, it is still not necessary \nto bar women from college. Kennedy is the 34th \npresident of the United States of America.\nHowever, a good number of Bucknell students don’t \nbelieve that Kennedy is to be the next president or they \nhave no respect for the office of President of the United \nStates. \nDuring the half-time ceremonies of last week’s \nfootball game, the Temple Uniyersity Band was present\xad\ning a musical tribute to some of America’s past chief ex\xad\necutives. The old phrase “Service with \na smile,” and the accompanying connotation of a willing\xad\nness to accommodate customers, seems to be completely \nbeyond the comprehension of the Merit Laundry Com\xad\npany.\nFor instance, the times set up for linen exchange are \nrather restrictive. If you are unable to take your linen to \nthe exchange point at the prescribed time, you incur the \nwrath of Merit’s representative the following week be\xad\ncause you have failed to “exchange your linens every \nweek—soiled or not.”\nThe exchange of linens requires other exactness,, too. \nFor example, be sure the pieces of your “unit” are neatly \nfolded and piled in the right order, or they may not be \naccepted by the linen exchange worker. \nHe may even \nshove the whole pile on the floor and grunt something-to \nyou about refolding them.\nIt used to be so convenient to have linens delivered to \nyour room each week. But now, students not only have \nto carry their soiled linens to an exchange point, but they \nalso run the risk of having their “unit” stolen. The Uni\xad\nversity laundry performed another small, yet important, \nservice; they welcomed students back each fall by making \ntheir beds for them before they arrived. Now if students \narrive after Merit Laundry closing hours they are forced \nto sleep without sheets their first night on campus. Head \nresidents do have an extra unit on hand, but this is little \nhelp to the second or third latecomer.\nIf Merit Laundry is interested in deserving the title \nService for its commodity, the least it can do is: (1) ex\xad\ntend exchange hours; (2) devise a less time-consuming \nsystem of exchange (such as a “de-assembly” line where \nthe student files past the laundry bins and deposits each \npiece of his own soiled unit, and is then handed a new \nunit); (3) encourage its adult employees to assume a more \ncourteous attitude.\n', 5, 0), (221.51805114746094, 1220.8992919921875, On \nthe opening kickoff, Dick Orlow- \nski knocked the Temple ball car\xad\nrier unconscious and Dean Stump \nrecovered \nthe fumble on the \nOwls’ 37-yard line. On the second \nplay \nfrom \nscrimmage, \nTerhes \ntoured right end to the 19 and a \nfirst down. Ren Twiford and Ash \nDitka each bulled for two yards, \nand then Paul lofted a 15-yard \naerial to Mickey Melberger for the \nscore. \nRon Maslanik’s perfect \nplacement gave BU a 7-0 lead.\nTerhes and company marched \nalmost the length of the field for \ntheir second touchdown. Starting \nfrom their own six yard stripe \nthe Orange and Blue rolled 94 \nyards in nine plays. Ken Twiford \ninitiated the trek by splitting the \ncenter of the line for 16 yards to \nthe 27. \nThen Terhes began an \naerial barrage. \nFirst he hit Ron \nMaslanik on the 36, then Ditka to \nthe 48 and again to the Temple \n47. His fourth consecutive com\xad\npleted pass was snared by Dick \nTyrrell on the 30. \nAsh Ditka \nbroke through the line on a re\xad\nverse to the 14, and Mickey Mel\xad\nberger carried to the 10. \nTerhes \nthen tossed a 10-yarder to Ditka \nfor the TD. \nPaul also ran for a \ntwo-point conversion and Buck\xad\nnell led at halftime by 15-0.\n, \n.The Bisons tallied their last \nscore early in the third period. \nRay Cosgrove took a punt at the \nmidfield stripe and twisted and \nturned to the Temple 34-yard line. \nA moment later, Terhes and Dit\xad\nka collaborated on the most spec\xad\ntacular play of the day. Back to \n.pass, Terhes was almost thrown \nfor a 15-yard loss, but he shook \noff one tackier and eluded two \nmore before heaving a long des\xad\nperation aerial. \nDitka raced for \nthe ball and was interfered with \nby a Temple defender. \nHe still \nmanaged to clutch the pigskin \nand scamper into the end zone for \nthe \ntouchdown. \nTerhes " then \nthrew to Ditka again for the two- \npoint conversion and a 23-0 lead.\n', 2, 0), (299.4910888671875, 383.9624328613281, 467.1611022949219, 435.76837158203125, 'F r o m\n . .  .\nThe Sidelines\n', 3, 0), (349.44110107421875, 442.5614318847656, 422.5156555175781, 451.0614318847656, 'by Steve Skinner\n', 4, 0), (296.14111328125, 454.36328125, 574.3209838867188, 464.89678955078125, '— -------- --------------------- .------ --------- -------- - --------------------- -------------- »\n', 5, 0), (388.80999755859375, 470.3727111816406, 473.3680114746094, 478.8727111816406, 'The Roughest Sport\n', 6, 0), (280.31005859375, 485.5227355957031, 579.8116455078125, 568.4219970703125, "Eight weekends ago, Bucknell fielded a strong, healthy, well bal\xad\nanced football team, with an outstanding quarterback and a better \nthan average line. \nThat better than average line developed into one \nof the outstanding defensive units in the Middle Atlantic Conference, \n| but at a cost which can only be described as incredible. \nAs of tomor- \nI row’s s6asoh-ending contest' with Delaware, only one man from the\nline that opened against Gettysburg remains intact. \nKirk Foulke, a \n210-lb. tackle, who has been on an All-East team this season, is the \nsole survivor.\n", 7, 0), (391.90997314453125, 581.02099609375, 471.01092529296875, 589.52099609375, 'Chaump Started It\n', 8, 0), (285.3609619140625, 596.1710205078125, 580.480712890625, 688.1700439453125, 'It all started back in the second quarter of the G-Burg game \nwhen Don Chaump had to be taken out of the game with a broken \nleg. Herkie’s father, Walter O. Nylet, is as every\xad\none knows, president of the First National Artificial Cherry \nCompany, world’s largest maker of artificial cherries for ladies’ \nhats. Uncle Walter had great plans for Herkie. Last year he \nsent Herkie to the Maryland College of Humanities, Sciences, \nand Artificial Cherries, and he intended, upon Herkie’s gradu\xad\nation, to find him a nice fat wife and take him into the firm as \na full partner.\nCould a young man have more pleasing prospects? Of course \nnot. But a couple of months ago, to everyone’s consternation, \nHerkie announced that he was not going into the artificial cherry \nbusiness. Nor was he going to stay in college. “ I am,” said \nI • \nHerkie, “a member of the Beat Generation. I am going to San \nFrancisco and grow a beard.”\nWell sir, you can imagine the commotion in the family when \nHerkie went traipsing off to San Francisco! Uncle Walter would \nhave gone after him and dragged him home, but unfortunately \nhe was right in the middle of the artificial cherry season. Aunt \nThelma couldn’t go either because of her old leg trouble. One still has, so to speak, a hold \non the finer things of life-like good tobacco, like easy-drawing \nfiltration, like settling back and getting comfortable and enjoy\xad\ning a full-flavored smoke. For instance, aren’t \nthe Pre-med, Engineering, Busi\xad\nness Administration, and Geology \ncurricular basically non-intellect\xad\nual? \nThey are not searches for \nthe truth; they are professional \ntraining.\nHowever, we need medical doc\xad\ntors, we need engineers, we need \nbusinessmen, and we need geolo\xad\ngists in this world, for they have \na distinct contribution to make.\nTrue, a university should be an \nopen field for creative listening \nand thinking, but should it not \nalso provide the opportunities for \nus to put our creativity into prac\xad\ntice? ' Why shouldn’t there be \nstudent government organizations \nto help develop our society’s lead\xad\ners, for certainly leadership is \nneeded? \nAs Frank Wood said, \nwe need a place to test our wings. \nInstead of reiterating the popular \ncry of “over-organization,” why \ndon’t you offer constructive criti\xad\ncism?\nAs was pointed out, anti-intel- \nlectualism is not unique to Buck\xad\nnell University, but is common to \nour society. So is over-organiza\xad\ntion. \nBoys don’t play sand-lot \nbaseball anymore, they join the \nLittle League, etc.\nMy point is that there is good \nin these organizations. \nWhy not \napply our creative thinking to re\xad\norganizing and offering advice, \ninstead of abolishment?\nSincerely,\nRobert A. $3214.21 \nof its goal of $3500. \nOf this, \n$2393.05 has been received in cash \nand $821.16 in pledges, which are \ndue before Christmas vacation. \nIt is hoped that late returns will \nmake up the differences between \nthe total and the goal.\nThe freshmen, giving $1109.80, \nwere not far from matching the \n$1371.36 given by ti\\e upperclass\xad\nmen. Of the freshman total about \n50% was given by men and 50% \nby women, whereas 60% of the \nupperclass total was given by \nwomen and 40% by men. \nAp\xad\nproximately 23% of that 40% was \ndonated by fraternity men. The \ndifficulty with which students liv\xad\ning in town are solicited was \nstated as one reason why their \ntotal is relatively low.\nA division similar to that be\xad\ntween freshmen and upperclass\xad\nmen occurred between the men \n$1102.67) and women ($1378.49). \nRemembering that all dorms vary \nin number of residents, npte that \nLarison, Harris, Hunt, Kress, and \nSwartz each gave between $230 \nand $295. Roberts and East Col\xad\nlege reported lower totals, and \nwomen’s houses, especially fresh\xad\nmen houses, reported relatively \nhigh totals.\nRanking high among the fresh\xad\nmen \nhouses \nwere \nStephens \n($80.50), Carey ($67.55), and Leiser \n($54.00). \nWalker ($56.00), French \n($48.50), and Hulley ($34.00) were \nthe upperclass houses having the \nhighest totals. Of the fraternities, \nDU reported the highest total \n($92.00), and SPE ($46.80) and \nSAE ($39.00) ranked second and \nthird.\nDonations from the faculty and \nadministration account for 20% of \nthe $3214.21 now collected. The purpose of \nthe camp was twofold: to ac\xad\nquaint high school and college \nstudents with the social problem \nof slums and to provide a way \nto improve the corfditions of .this \nsegment of our society. Our head\xad\nquarters aqd “hotel” was a house \nlocated in the center of the slum \narea, where we slept rolled up in \nblankets on Army surplus mat\xad\ntresses.\nRooms Painted\nOur project was to paint two \nrooms in a young negro woman’s \nshabby “band box” (a three story \napartment of three rooms averag\xad\ning about $65 rent per month). \nWhen we arrived at Mrs. Pleas\xad\nant’s door complete with step lad\xad\nders, paint buckets, plastering \nequipment, and Bucknell sweat\xad\nshirts, we were impressed by her \nfriendliness.\nMrs. Pleasant and her seven \nchildren were supported by relief \nfunds, and so we were surprised \nto find a large and new television \nset in the midst of her dingy liv\xad\ning room. \nHowever, upon com\xad\nparing notes with the other work \ncrews, we found that television is \nan escape device for these people \nand, as such, is a necessity.\nProblems Discussed\nAfter our day of hard' work \nand first-hand views of slum life, \nthe discussions with the leaders \nand-other work crews were per\xad\nhaps the most memorable and en\xad\nlightening \nexperiences \nof \nthe \nweekend. Topics of conversation \nran from the desperate need of \nthe slum dwellers for more edu\xad\ncation to the ultimate meaning of \neducation.\nFurther conversation covered \nsuch topics as time effectiveness \nof passive resistance as a fighting \nweapon and American student \nreaction to government corrup\xad\ntion.\nCourt Session Attended\nSunday morning the group at\xad\ntended Magistrate’s Court. \nThe \nmost pathetic sight was a group \nof 14 drunks. Many of the men \nhad been driven to drinking by \nthe unresolved conflicts their slum \nlife imposed on them. \nSome of \nthe men, in advanced stages of al\xad\ncoholism, begged to be sent to the \nstate correctional institute, where \nthey unfortunately would get \nlittle or no permanent help, but \nat least would be taken off liquor \nfor a period of about two months \nbefore they would return to so\xad\nciety.\nThe other cases ranged from \nknifings, mostly committed under \nthe influence of alcohol, to rob\xad\nbery. \nIt was strange to see a \nperson of our same age stand be\xad\nfore the judge knowing that he \nwould probably spend the next \n20 years in prison.\nThe weekend, although it gave \nno ultimate answers to the prob\xad\nlems revealed, nevertheless show\xad\ned us a different way of life. \nThus, we were encouraged to ex\xad\namine our social system, which \ngives people caught in the slums, \nlittle or no way to get out of their \npredicament.\n", 25, 0), (279.84716796875, 385.3768005371094, 766.0123291015625, 450.6533508300781, 'Third in a Series:\nThe World of Richard Fidler\n', 26, 0), (277.6971435546875, 454.7860412597656, 574.5220947265625, 957.4815063476562, ', \nby Dick Fidler\nOn recent Saturdays, many of you have probably seen me in the \ncrowd attending the football games and have wondered why I should \nwant to attend such activities. In this short article I shall try to ex\xad\nplain why I like to go to football games and plays. I shall also men\xad\ntion some of those sports and other events of a social nature which \nthose in “my world” like to attend and in which we sometimes even \nparticipate.\nEver since I can remember, I have always enjoyed attending \nbaseball games, football games, or the like, for I can sometimes enjoy \nthese events even more than some of my friends. \nIf the game is \nbroadcast, I usually carry a- radio to save the person with me much \ntalking, since he will not have to do as much describing to me. \nHowever, I often attend wrestling matches or ball games without \neither a radio or a talkative companion.\nI find it quite exciting to sense the emotions which spread \nthrough the stands as the game unfolds before those who are watch\xad\ning. \nI am sure that you feel some sort of an emotional effect on \nhearing the band strike up a march number, or on hearing a cheer \nswelling in intensity throughout the stands. Not seeing what is ac\xad\ntually going on down there on the field, leaves a lot of room for \nimagination.\nSometimes, however, my imagination will get a little ambitious \nand suddenly be halted by the commentary on the radio, or by some\xad\none sitting near me. For example, while describing a play the radio \nannouncer will often exaggerate what is actually occurring. He may \nsay that there just has been a magnificent run. \nI’ll imagine a gain \nof many yards. \nThen all of a sudden the announced will say that \nthe gain was for only a couple of yards.\nThe best example to illustrate the point that there need not be \nanyone to describe What is occuring, is to tell you about a typical \nwrestling match at the school I attended. Naturally most all of the \naudience can not see what is going on out on the mat. Even if some\xad\none is there to describe what is happening, the cheering is so loud \nthat often they can not be heard. Yet everyone enjoys that emotional \nfeeling which is built up during a match. Through just the slightest \nhint of what is occuring, the audience senses what is happening.\nImagination\nThe fact that much is left to the imagination can often be of help \nin enjoying what is happening, whereas you are at times restricted by \nthe fact that you know what is happening.\nFor example, how often have you heard an announcer on a radio \ndescribe something which is overly exaggerated? \nIn so doing he \nbuilds up in the minds of those listening an image which is probably \nquite different from that which is actually happening. \nYou, how\xad\never, seeing what is happening, can not be so easily aroused.\nI guess the best answer to the question “why do you go to a \nfootball game?” is that I find it just as emotionally exciting as you \ndo. and that I can exercise my power of imagination.\nThe same answer would apply to the question “what do you get \nout of going to a movie?” \nAgain I can enjoy myself by trying to \nfollow the plot and imagining what is happening. \nNaturally in a \nshow such as the usual Western type where the main theme is riding \nback and forth across the screen on horseback shooting, I find this\n', 27, 0), (577.4351806640625, 454.9910583496094, 876.201171875, 810.82861328125, 'typé of show rather dull and very hard to follow. I think I am right \nin saying that most of you would also find these shows less interest\xad\ning. Why? \nBecause they are all the same and you know what is \ngoing to happen.\nMajor Sports\nSome of you may wonder what kind of sports and activities the \npeople in “my world” participate in and enjoy.\nThe major sport in which we can participate in on an equal basis \nis wrestling. I do not mean that “fake” wrestling which one can see \nat the eleventh hour of the evening on TV. I know that there are a \nnumber of people on campus who attend high schools which might \nhave wrestled my school. \nWrestling is the big sport because you \nreally do not have to see to participate in it fully.\nWe also swim, do some track events—such as races, jumps, and \nshotput, bowl, play baseball and football, and some sports of our own \ninvention.\nFor the running events in track, the lanes are marked off by \nwires which are used as guides. \nThe runners half hold on to the \nwire as they run. However, most of the good trackmen can run in a \nstraight line without using the wire. The jumps are done the same \nway as you would do them. Naturally there are no running jumps. \nShot-pùtting is performed exactly the same as you do.\nFor bowling sometimes there is a guide rail by which one lines \nhimself up with the alley, but this is not essential. \nI and most of \nmy friends can bowl on a regular alley with no difficulties other than \nhitting the pins.\nBaseball Methods\nWe play baseball slightly different than you. Instead of throw\xad\ning the ball in the air, we roll it along the ground. \nThe batter hits \nthe ball and then starts running for the base. Sometimes the batter \nmay have enough sight to be able to run to the base without assist\xad\nance. However, if this is not the case, than he has a “runner,” that \nis, someone who runs with him to the base. \nThe fielders field the \nball by sound.\nThere was one fellow in my class who had no sight whatsoever, \nbut could run to the bases, field the ball, and peg the ball directly \nwhere it should go. I myself was never that proficient. Actually I \namjiot as athletically inclined as some of my friends.\n', 28, 0), (335.4761657714844, 986.2019653320312, 546.0861206054688, 1018.244873046875, 'P ri/AT£ © /©\n', 29, 0), (277.6261291503906, 1058.8775634765625, 424.0411376953125, 1192.6768798828125, 'by Pal Gall\nPinned:\nDU—John Goodyear to Linda \nPeterson, Cornell.\nPhi Psi—Tom Millen to Marti \nMolinaro.\nPhi Lam—Dick Cranford to \nRuth Ellie Dobson.\nSAE—Bill Quarton to Patty \nMarble; Hal Wilson to Kitty Cobb.\nSPE—Joel Howard to Sandy \nAllanson.\nCo-eds Pinned Off-campus:\n.
