And in his senior year, each recipient \nstill clings to every weed sprouting from the cliff of an in\xad\ncreasingly complex life.\nIt’s not that freshmen should not have counselors. On \nthe contrary, for counselors are essential in easing the ad\xad\njustment from high school to college. \nThis adjustment \nis becoming increasingly difficult with the “academic \nsqueeze” as yet uneased by proper high school prepara\xad\ntion. Moreover, the men counselors are invaluable in re\xad\ntaining the roofs of Swartz and Kress Halls on weekends. \nThe women counselors lend advice about social situations \nand encourage an academic approach.\nThese ends are appropriate. \nWould that they were \nmerely fulfilled. Instead, counselors serve as built-in tu-. \ntoring services, theme punctuators and quiz kids. They \nrun handy dating bureaus and maintain verbal “dear \nAbby” columns. The counselor’s door is always open; the \nbarest semblance of problems are played upon the coun\xad\nselor’s ear and are most frequently solved by that oracle \nextraordinaire!\nWe do not condemn the dormitory counseling system; \nwe merely lament the overplaying of its role. Although \nit varies with individuals, we feel that freshman depend\xad\nence upon counselors is merely a reflection of an attitude \npermeating all aspects of Bucknell life.\n-Several years ago, the students rejected an academic \nhonor system because they felt themselves incapable of \nhandling the responsibility of individual honesty on ex\xad\naminations. \nSince then, the cheating problem has in\xad\ncreased in scope and seriousness. Thus, we have foisted \nonto professors a responsibility which is ours.\nLast year, the women students dissolved their social \nhonor system, having proved that they were unable to \nlive without falling back on some method of group en\xad\nforcement. Today, they have that enforcement which, in \nmany cases, fails to function properly because council as\xad\nsistants are afraid to accept the duty of reporting another \nwoman’s violation.\nCompulsory attendance at classes, rather than unlimit\xad\ned cuts is another instance of student dependence upon \nenforced regulations. Professors, on the basis of past ex\xad\nperience, do not feel that students are disciplined enough \nto regulate their own class attendance. The fact that the \nadministration requires an attendance record for each \nclass further emphasizes the lack of trust in students.\nThose courses allowing independent study are intoler\xad\nably few. \nFor most students, the nearest approach to \nscholarly research is a surface-scraping term paper con\xad\nsisting of a collection of footnoted quotations. Seldom are \nwe required to exercise our critical abilities; when we \nmust, we find ourselves floundering in a sea with which \nwe are not prepared to cope.\nDependency is an attitude fostered in the home. How \nsad we do not have the opportunity to find our own hand\xad\nholds, even in our universities.\n', 9, 0), (460.7691955566406, 475.8807678222656, 722.32080078125, 781.0279541015625, 'Whee! \nWhoopie!\nT. This can be debated \nin terms of the career soldier, but that is not our point here.\nThe U. S. Government has given tacit approval to the purchase \nof the English Ford Motor Company by the American Ford Motor \nCompany. \nA transaction' which will involve the transfer of some \n300 million dollars to Englad. \nThus, it seems that the government \nis either very fond of the Ford Motor Companies or is little concerned \nabout the welfare of military personnel.\nEither alternative is unpleasant in its ramifications. David Martin, professor of \nphilosophy. Two courses will be \noffered: Descriptions of Philoso\xad\nphy 212 for undergraduates and \nPhilosophy 312 for graduate stu\xad\ndents, ■ Students may pursue these \n; courses for three credit hours or \nfor' non-credit.\nBoth courses will be based on \nthe fundamental experience of \nmeeting our artistic heritage in its \noriginal setting, so as to bring to \nlife the times and spirit that creat\xad\ned the greatest artistic values of \nwestern civilization. \nQualified \nlocal specialists in the visual arts \nwill meet or travel with the \ngroup. \nEach object of art will be \nrelated to the artist or artisan, his \nlife and character, and the en\xad\nvironment \nwhich \ninspired \nor \nmade possible its creation. \nThe \ntour will avoid or minimize the \ntourist-type of sightseeing which \ncovers broad areas in a rapid and \ncursory manner.\nThe countries to be visited are: \nItaly, Greece, Austria, West Ger\xad\nmany, Switzerland, France, and \nEngland.\nDr. Martin, who will conduct \nthis study-tour, has lived and tra\xad\nvelled extensively in Europe. However, our \ndifficulty lies in seeing how the present SFC carries out \nthis aim.\nIt is not our purpose to judge here the past functions of \nthe organization; rather we are concerned only with tlie \npresent. \nW7e have seen thus far the actions of SFC in \nsuch significant events as the organization of the Who’s \nWho Election and the recommendation that the name of \nthe Parachute Club remain the Parachute Club at Buck- \ni \nnell University. If this examination yields, \nas it has in this case, negative results, then there is obvi\xad\nously something amiss. \nEither the fault lies in the fact \nthat SFC falls embarrassing short of the function it is \nsupposed to fill or its channels for bringing reports of its \nprogress to the student body are extremely inadequate. \nWe sincerely hope that the latter is the case, rather than \nthe former.\nBut in any case: Please SFC would you mind telling us \nwhat evidence justifies your existence?\n', 3, 0), (155.74923706054688, 1139.629150390625, 426.62420654296875, 1164.629150390625, 'Quality Not Quantity!\n', 4, 0), (153.09933471679688, 1173.349853515625, 434.0293884277344, 1484.9967041015625, 'We have recognized the “academic squeeze” which has \nhit this university, along with most of its contemporaries \nthroughout the nation. (Have you ever wondered, incidentally, about the \norigin of this interesting phrase "Quicker than you can say \nJack Robinson” ? WelF sir, the original phrase was French— \n“Plus vile que de dire Jacques Robespierre.’\' Jack Robinson is, \n¡is everyone knows, an anglicization of Jacques Robespierre who \nwas, as everyone knows, the famous figure -from the French \nRevolution Who, as everyone knows, got murdered in his bath \nby Danton, Murat, Caligula, and Aaron Burr.\n(The reason people started saying “ Quicker than you can say \nJacques Robespierre (or Jack Robinson as he is called in English- \nspeaking countries)” is quite an interesting little story. It seems \nthat Robespierre’s wife, Georges Sand, got word of the plot to \nmurder her husband in his bath. All she had to do to save his \nlife was call his name and warn him. But, alas, quicker than \nshe could say Jacques Robespierre, she received a telegram\' from \nher old friend Frederic Chopin who was down in Majorca seating \nlyrics to his immortal “Warsaw Concerto.” Chopin said he \nneeded Georges Sand’s help desperately because he could not \nfind a rhyme for “ Warsaw.” Naturally, Georges Sand could not \nrefuse such an urgent request.\n(Well sir, Georges Sand went traipsing off to Majorca, but \nbefore she left she told her little daughter Walter that some bad \nmen were coming to murder daddy in his bath, and she in\xad\nstructed Walter to shout Robespierre’s name when the bad men \narrived. But Walter, alas, had been sea-bathing that morning \non the Riviera, and she had come home loaded with sea shells \nand salt water taffy, and when the bad men came to murder \nRobespierre, Walter, alas, was chewing a big wad of salt water \ntaffy and could not get her mouth open in time to shout a \nwarning. Robespierre, alas, was murdered quicker than you \ncould shout Jacques Robespierre (or Jack Robinson as he is \ncalled in the English-speaking countries).\n(There is, I am pleased to report, one small note of cheer in \nthis grisly tale. When Georges Sand got to Majorca where \nChopin was setting lyrics to his immortal “ Warsaw Concerto,” \nshe was happily able to help him find a rhyme for “Warsaw,” \nas everyone knows who has heard those haunting lyrics:\nIn the fair town of TFarsaie,\nWhich Napoleon’s horse saw,\nSinging cockles and mussels, aim alive of)\n', 70, 0), (1481.9605712890625, 1309.8070068359375, 1574.81005859375, 1334.8070068359375, "'fe^ìmeà,\n", 71, 0), (1420.76171875, 1346.6158447265625, 1666.9464111328125, 1505.43896484375, 'But I digress.\nWe were speaking of Christmas gifts. 1052.14453125, 404.7629699707031, 'Mistletoe and Santa:\n', 65, 0), (939.974609375, 419.4351806640625, 1076.6705322265625, 435.4351806640625, 'WhaTs Their Origin!\n', 66, 0), (1086.5745849609375, 391.1047058105469, 1335.860595703125, 409.1047058105469, 'F o u r t h  i n a s e r i e s\n', 67, 0), (937.0745849609375, 443.7734680175781, 1104.330810546875, 1508.960693359375, 'There is no mystery about the \nmodem Christmas tree topped \nwith its bright star . . . ablaze \nwith lights . . . and heaped un\xad\nderneath with colored packages— \nbnt in olden times it was shroud\xad\ned In myth.\nTor this holiday decoration we \nare indebted to the old Northern \nEuropean belief that the trees of \nthe forest were inhabited by god\xad\nlike spirits. The Germans brought \naw» trees into their homes to ap\xad\npease these “spirits” and show \nthem they were welcome at the \nWinter Solstice ceremonies.\nThere is also no doubt about the \nmeaning of the modem mistletoe, | \nand what happen to you if you’re \nstanding under it. But the- cus\xad\ntom of kissing under the mistletoe \nooan.es down to us from the mystic \nrites of the primitive British \npriests. \nIn their faraway age, the \nmistletoe, which means “all heal,” \nwas believed to have magic quali\xad\nties—the power to heal disease, \nneutralize poisons, protect its pos\xad\nsessor from witchcraft, and be\xad\nstow fertility on humans and ani\xad\nmals. \nIf a young couple sealed \nih w  betrothal with a kiss under \nthe mistletoe, they would receive \nwonderful blessings and much \ngood luck for the rest of their \nlives.\n•Wassail’ was how they greeted\nanother in Merry Old Eng- \nlaad when toasting with a cup of \nwine. \nIt means to “be whole” or \n“have health,” the answer being \n“drink hail.” The word came to \nmean any liquor in which health \nis toasted, especially the spiced \ndrinks served as a feature- of \nmedieval Christmas celebrations \nThat Yule Log blazing on the \nhearth looks simple and provides \na wealth of warmth, but the an\xad\ncients were more concerned with \nits mystical associations than its \npracticality. The custom was first \npracticed by pagans in Scandina\xad\nvia, where a huge log was set on \nAre in honor of Thor, to mark his \nfestival at the time of the winter \nsolstice. In many parts of Europe \nthe dragging home of the Yule \nLeg is still one of the big events \nof the year and a source of great \nexcitement, especially to the chil\xad\ndren.\nWe modems envision Santa \nCSaose as a paunchy gent, but in \nolden times he was a complex \nsymbol and many things to many \npeople. Santa descends from the \noriginal Saint Nicholas, a kindly \nman who lived in Patara, Turkey, \nand died a martyr in 342 A. D., \nbeonring the patron saint of chil\xad\ndren.\nThe cult of St. Nicholas spread \nasra» Europe. \nHe became the \npatron saint of Greece, Holland, \nand Belgium. \nMerchant sailors \nsaed his three golden «purses as a \ndevice on their guild flags. The \nRussians passed the good saint to \ntie  Scandinavians, at which time \nlie was still mounted on a white \nhorse according to an old tradition \nof Turkey. \n^ut the Scandinav\xad\nians knew nothing of horses, so \nthey gave him a reindeer-drawn \npV«gVv \nThey also grafted to him \nthe legend of the Norse God, \nThor, who used to ride through \nthe sky in a chariot, and would \nappear in a red coat for the pagah \nfeast of Yule.\nIn the New World, the Dutch \ncalled \nSaint \nNicholas \n“Santa \nClaus” for short. \nOur modem \nconception of him comes from the \nfamous poem, The Night Before \nChristmas. Dr. Clement C. Moore, \na Presbyterian divinity professor \nIn New York State, wrote it to \nplease his children, and modelled \n« . p hero after a little old wizened \nDutch gentleman he bumped into \none night in 1822—a man with red \ncheeks and white hair, smoking \nan old clay pipe. Dr. Moore read \nthe po°m to his delighted chil\xad\ndren, then threw it in the waste\xad\nbasket. \nA lady visitor fished it \nout and printed it a year later in \nthe Troy, New York Sentinel. Wheatcroft’s orig\xad\ninal children’s play, Ofoti the \nTroll. was presented by the Ac\xad\ntors’ Lab of Cap and Dagger on \nDec. 14. \nOfoti is the story of a \nyoung boy who wanders about in \nsearch of a troll—a being which, \nhe has been told, does not exist. \nBecause of his imagination, how\xad\never, he is able to find the troll.\nAlthough there Were several \nsatirical elements in the * play \nwhich held the interest of the au\xad\ndience, for the, most part Ofoti \nseemed to drag. \nThe actors did \nnot pick up their cues, and seem\xad\ned to move aimlessly about the \nstage. \nIt was hard for the audi\xad\nence to imagine the play holding \nthe attention of a group of chil\xad\ndren for any length of time.\nTechnical Flaws \nTechnical errors also marred \nthe production. \nThe stage looked \nlike a cluttered attic, with moving \nrocks placed in front of a bed \n(which the audiehce was not able \nto disregard) and a rock door \nwhich led to a bedroom. \nAlso, \nthe lighting seemed to lack any \nkind of coherence; the lights pop\xad\nped on and off areas at random. \nHowever, the costumes were very \nwell executed, especially those of \nthe turtle and the mermaid.\nThe play gained momentum \nand interest when the ridh man \nand his entourage appeared on \nstage. \nRichard Wilsker, as the \nrich man’s secretary, was excep\xad\ntionally funny,- although a bit \nnervous. As editors \nof a college newspaper, we cannot help but wonder why \nthose involved in a university do not take it upon them- \nselves to utilize this privilege. We run a weekly column \nentitled Letters to the Editor, which would be a vital ex- \nchange of opinions, were students of a mind to take pen \nin hand to express their views.\n', 14, 0), (113.29695129394531, 531.826171875, 391.6068420410156, 623.9229736328125, 'During the semester, we have printed a number of con\xad\ntroversial editorials: Homecoming Traditions, the Function \nof SFC, the Idea of a University, Counseling and Depend\xad\nency, to name just a few of these subjects. We haye re\xad\nceived no written response to any of these challenges. \nDuring Religion in Life week, a number of intriguing dis- \ncussions arise and opinions were expressed; the sole frui \nof all was one letter defending the fraternity system, \nwhich no one bothered to answer.\n', 15, 0), (115.44603729248047, 630.7230224609375, 400.0648193359375, 992.7567138671875, 'In past years,-a great deal of steam has been generated \nover columns which might be called “controversial, pro\xad\nviding the term was used loosely. \nOne such topic was \nthat of the calibre of Bucknell women; it seems that the \nfemale ego could not take such a beating and that the \nbruised belles were finally called upon to defend them\xad\nselves.\nUnfortunately, students do not react accordingly when \ntheir favorite educational theories are attacked. Or could \nit be that Bucknell students do not have any intellectual \nviewpoints? \nWe prefer to think that perhaps the news\xad\npaper has failed to challenge those views, that are held. \nBut if such is the case, why don’t students take it upon \nthemselves to advance these ideas in letters, to hold them \nup for discussion and publication upon an ideal verbal \nbattle-ground? \n>\nIn snooping around the campus, even Sam has beard \ndiscussions resulting from editorials. But somehow tne \nsound ideas expressed in these arguments never appear m \nwritten form. Are students afraid to screw their courage \nto the sticking place in order to argue an issue? \nOr are \nwe lazyrtferhaps it is too much trouble to jot down one s \nthoughts and drop them into the Bucknellian box. \nNeither of these excuses is particularly valid for one who \ncalls himself a student.\nAnd what of the administration and the faculty? In the \nlast three years, three letters, all written by members of \nthe administration, have appeared in this newspaper. We \nlike to consider ourselves a community of scholars, but \nthose who complain that students do not “think” do not \nencourage them to do so outside of the classroom or an \noccasional conference. \nWhat more exciting discussion \nmight ensue than one between students, administration, \nand faculty members on the printed page?\n', 16, 0), (124.79488372802734, 997.90673828125, 401.1749267578125, 1038.854736328125, 'In examining the student newspaper of a European uni\xad\nversity, one cannot help but be ashamed that we have no \nsuch spirited and outspoken comments on subjects such as \nacademic freedom or the goals of a university.\n', 17, 0), (125.49488067626953, 1044.2037353515625, 402.3747863769531, 1096.4517822265625, 'Lethargy is an infectious state. At Stratford-upon-Avon \nthe subject will be Elizabethan \ndrama; at the University of Lon\xad\ndon the course will be the study \nof English literature, art and mu\xad\nsic of the 17th and 18th centuries, \nusing materials preserved in Lon\xad\ndon’s buildings, galleries and rec\xad\nords; at Oxford the subject will \nbe English history, literature and \nthe arts from 1870 to the present. \n[The theme of the \nEdinburgh \nSchool will be the political and \neconomic history, philosphy and \nliterature of Britain from 1559 to \n1789. Although the courses are \ndesigned for graduate students, \nj undergraduates in their last two \n| years at a university will be con- \nI sidered.\n-j \nThe inclusive charge for board, j \nj residence and tuition for six- [ \ni weeks at each of the four British i \nsummer schools is L90 (approxi\xad\nm ately $254). 1003.9282836914062, 901.1549682617188, 1556.2711181640625, 'by Mike Ingraham\nThe subject of University law has always been a touchy one. \nThe prevalent feeling has been and still is one of blind servitude and \nunquestioning obedience. \nWe usually fall into error by betoeymg \n\' that since our attendance at Bucknell is a privilege and not a right, \nwe are under strict obligation to submit to any arbitrary whim which \nthe Administration enforces; that if we did not comply, we could al\xad\nways get out.\nIt is distressing to learn how many students hold this identical \nview when they must realize it is archaic, irresponsible, adolescent, \nand unbelievably stupid. \nFor that day is past when any autonomous \ncommunity, no matter how wealthy or influential, can exist outside \nand independent from the greater scope of laws and judgments which \nregulate society at large. \nIt would be the same as to imagine the \nexistence of a feudal barony in the middle of Manhattan.\nThe point is this: no law-making body, either nation, state, or \nuniversity, can remain healthy fot any length of time without peri\xad\nodically investigating the precepts behind its legal datum, and in \nmodifying or eliminating those laws whose precepts are outdated, un\xad\nfair, or unreasonable. We must remember that the university exists \nfor us and not visa-versa, and it is with us that the responsibility lies\nfor its well-being. \n,\nUnfortunately this has not been the case with Bucknell. Anyone \nwho has disagreed with university law has been termed a “smart- \naleck” or “wise-guy” and refused support; so, many laws which \nwould have been discarded decades ago at Harvard or Princeton are \nstill in effect here.\' The administration should not be blamed since \nit is primarily a monetary organization which by nature doesn’t ob\xad\nject to any method that increases revenue.\nLet us take an isolated example of University law and investi\xad\ngate its logic. A friend of mine brought his automobile to Lewisburg \nbetween Thanksgiving and Christmas vacations, and parked it down\xad\ntown off University property. \nA  week later, a Lewisburg police\xad\nman noticed his out-of-town plates and the absence of a University \nparking sticker, stopped him, took his name and reported it to the \nUniversity police. \nA  few days later, my friend received notice of a \n$50 fine. It was that simple.\nThe University insists that every student who operates a vehicle \nat Bucknell is required to obtain a parking sticker for the fee of $20; \na quite reasonable law since the school maintains a parking tot and \ncampus roads at its own expense. \nTherefore the premise is that \nsince students use University facilities, they should pay for them— \nquite right. But in my friend’s case, he did not use University road \nand parking facilities; he kept his car downtown. Therefore, theo\xad\nretically, he should have to pay neither registration nor fine (And \nwhat a fine! \nA small fortune to the student who can work only three \nmonths out of the year.)\nYet the Administration would argue that without the deterrent \nof registration fee and fine, Lewisburg would be overrun with stu\xad\ndent vehicles. This is a municiple problem which could be resolved \nin much the same way as Bucknell and a hundred other colleges have \nsolved their problem, and is beside the question anyway. \nIf, how\xad\never, they insist upon this point, the law should be changed to read \nas follows: "Any student who operates a vehicle at Bucknell and in\xad\ntends to use the facilities provided must pay the required fee. and \nany student-owned vehicle apprehended on any University-owned \nproperty without said sticker shall be subject to fine." \nThis would \nbe a sensible and honest phrasing.\n.(Continued on Page 8)\n', 49, 0), (123.60089111328125, 1708.22705078125, 164.42288208007812, 1744.195068359375, 'mSS \nIH\n', 50, 0), (168.7008819580078, 1750.071044921875, 179.12789916992188, 1758.571044921875, '. ■\n', 51, 0), (354.70086669921875, 1625.7393798828125, 415.4328918457031, 1659.7393798828125, 'mm\n', 52, 0), (203.50086975097656, 1673.5185546875, 245.1008758544922, 1693.5185546875, 'H H\n', 53, 0), (203.75086975097656, 1631.7314453125, 359.828857421875, 1707.7852783203125, "■f e : - . . First off, it is the only year since \n1951 which begins and ends with the Figure 1. Of course, when \nit comes to Figure l ’s, 1961, though distinguished, can hardly \ncompare with 1911, which, most people agree, had not just two, \nbut three Figure l ’s! This, I’ll wager, is a record that will stand \nfor at least two hundred years!\n1911 was, incidentally, notable for many other things. It \nwas, for example, the year in which the New York Giants played \nthe Philadelphia Athletics in the World Series. As we all know, \nthe New York Giants have since moved to San Francisco and \nthe Philadelphia Athletics to Kansas City. There is a movement \nafoot at present to move Chicago to Phoenix—the.city, not the \nbaseball team. Phoenix, in turn, would of course move to \nChicago. It is felt that the change would be broadening for \nresidents of both cities. Many Chicago folks, for example, have \nnever seen an iguana. Many Phoenix folks, on the other hand, \nhave never seen a frostbite.\nThere are, of course, certain difficulties attending a municipal \nshift of this size. For instance, to move Chicago you also have \nto move Lake Michigan. This, in itself, presents no great prob\xad\nlem, what with modem scientific advances like electronics and \nthe French cuff. But if you will look at your map, you will find' \nthat Lake Michigan is connected to all the other Great Lakes, \nwhich in turn are connected to the St. Lawrence Seaway, which\nC«AMPUS\nLEVIN#! You start dragging \nLake Michigan to Phoenix andy willy-nilly, you’ll be dragging \nall that other stuff too. This would make our British allies \nterribly cross, and I can’t say as I blame them. I mean, put \nyourself in their place. What if, for example, you were a British \nworkingman who had been saving and scrimping all year for a \nsummer holiday at Brighton Beach, and then when you got to \nBrighton Beach there wasn’t any ocean ? There you’dbe with your \ninner tube and snorkel and nothing to do all day but dance the \nLambeth Walk. This, you may be sure, would not make you \nNATO-minded!\nI appeal most earnestly to the residents of Chicago and \nPhoenix to reconsider. I know it’s no bowl of cherries going \nthrough life without ever seeing an iguana or a frostbite, but I \nask you—Chicagoans, Phoenicians—is it too big a price to pay \nfor preserving the unity of the free world? I am sure that if \nyou search your hearts you will make the right decision, for \nall of us—whether we live in frostbitten Chicago, iguanarridden \nPhoenix, or narrow-lapelled New Haven—are first and foremost \nAmericans!\nBut I digress. We were speaking of 1961, our new year. And \nnew it is! There is, for one thing, new pleasure in Marlboro \nCigarettes. How can there be new pleasure in Marlboros when \nthat fine, flavorful blend, that clean easy draw filter, have not \nbeen altered? The answer is simple: each time yoq light a \nMarlboro, it is like the first time. The flavor is such that age \ncannot wither nor custom stale. Marlboro never palls, never \njades, never dwindles into dull routine. Each pack, each \ncigarette, each puff, makes you glad all oyer again that you are \na Marlboro smoker!\nSo, Marlboros in hand, let us march confidently into 1961. \nMay good fortune attend our ventures! May happiness reign! \nMay Chicago and Phoenix soon recover from their disappoint\xad\nment and join our bright cavalcade into a brave tomorrow!\n', 52, 0), (703.4694213867188, 1510.924560546875, 848.8243408203125, 1521.904541015625, '©  1961 Max ShulauMk\n* \n* \n*\n', 53, 0), (604.3194580078125, 1528.553466796875, 851.2824096679688, 1555.25341796875, 'The makers o f Marlboro and of the new un filtered king-size \nPhilip Morris Commander join Old Max in adding their good \nwishes for a happy and peaceful 1961.\n', 54, 0), (950.91943359375, 431.5142517089844, 1692.371337890625, 512.6024780273438, 'Bulk of Mrs. Bertrand’s Will\nM IBurfmeUran Provides Library Endowment\n', 55, 0), (1074.9683837890625, 490.7525939941406, 1692.817138671875, 512.3215942382812, 'Mrs. Ellen Clarke Bertrand of New York City. We \nnow have two Negro students at Bucknell, both of them \nmen. None were admitted in the class of 1964. Twelve \nyears ago, there were ten Negro students, both men and \nwomen, some of whom had white roommates, attending \nthis university. By way of comparison, we have moved \nbackward.\nTo what may we attribute this regression? Certainly, \nadmission policies have a great deal to do with the num\xad\nber of Negro students who enter Bucknell. As students, \nwe haye never been given a clear statement of discrimin\xad\nation policy by this university. \nWe are asking, at this \ntime, that such a statement be made.\nAnd what of the application form? \nAfter repeated \nbadgering and questioning on the part of this newspaper, \nstudents, and certain faculty members, the Admissons \nCommittee deleted this year the question concerning the \napplicant’s race. However, the Committee voted against \ndropping the required applicant’s picture.\nWhy do we require the picture? \nNumerous answers \nhave been given; including primarily its use for the fresh\xad\nman directory and for files in the recorder’s pffice. \nBut \nfor such purposes, pictures could more easily be submit\xad\nted after the student was accepted for admission. \nAs it \nis, requests for photographs merely raise questions of pos\xad\nsible discrimination in the minds of applicants.\nIn a survey of 127 institutions of higher learning recent\xad\nly completed by the Pennsylvania Fellowship Commis\xad\nsion, Bucknell was one of ten colleges of equivalent size \nand status which still request photographs on the applica\xad\ntion form. "We see no reason why this information is nec\xad\nessary for application tojthis university.\nWe question the Admission Committee’s decision to re\xad\ntain the picture and would be interested in hearing their \nreasons for so deciding. \nPerhaps their answer will be \npart of the statement of discrimination policy for which \nwe are calling. The Bucknellian will gladly print such a l \nstatement if the university staff-can produce one.\nWSGj4: What For?\n', 15, 0), (156.27066040039062, 882.9354858398438, 440.797607421875, 1370.1668701171875, 'The Women’s Student Government Association has \nbeen operating under a revised constitution and cooper\xad\native system for more than a semester. \nFrom various \nsections of the campus have come conflicting reports: ■ \nFrom the head resident of a freshman house, “It isn’t \nworking in our house; no one reports anything.” From \nthe head of an upperclass residence council: “We can’t \ndecide when to see people and when not to; consequently, \nwe’ve never called anyone in.” From a woman student in \nHarris: “We get caught up in pretty things like telephone \nhours and quiet hours and miss the significant cases.” \nFrom a council assistant in Larison: “it’s working fine, as \nfar as I can see; the freshmen understand the government \nand are able to make it work”\nWhat are we to believe from such inconsistent reports? \nIs the council assistant program working well in some liv\xad\ning situations and not in others? Are the time-consuming \nsmaller cases being weeded out by the residence councils, \nleaving Judicial Bard time for more important cases and \ndiscussions of policy? Is the line of communication be\xad\ntween Judicial Board and the Residence Councils clear \nand frequently used?\nMore important, perhaps, is the question of whether \nmore women are being involved in student government \nand are showing a concern for both individual and collec\xad\ntive responsibility. As the mouthpiece of the university \ncommunity, we would like to call for an evaluation of the \nproposed system. \nSuch aji evaluation would demand \ncomments from Senate, Judicial Board, House of ^eps, \nand members of the Dean of Women s staff.\nMoreover, we would like to see some tangible results \nfrom the Committee for Constitutional Revisions, which \nhas been meeting behind closed doors for several months. \nBefore we begin the election of a new set of WSGA of\xad\nficers, perhaps women should be questioned as to the \nvalue of student government? Is it worth the time and \nenergy expended on it? \nDo enough people possess the \nintrinsic belief in self-government to warrant continuing \nit?\nThese questions were raised last year. We raise them \nagain, and this time, we should like an answer.______ __\nUnrknrLlian\nOF BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY \nEstablished 1897 \nLEWISBURG. Cargille '56\nYou are probably wondering about my trip homo from South \nEast Asia, and I wish to share a few of the highlights enroute from \nIndonesia to New York. \nIt was a wonderful experience, and though \ntime was short, I saw many places, visiting in mission -hospitals and \nmaking friends along the way. \nAfter leaving Djakarta, I returned \nto the Medical School in Singapore and spent four days with student \nfriends, having the opportunity to»rest and post home several pack\xad\nages of gifts from Indonesia.\nLeaving Singapore by train I traveled to Bangkok in Thailand \nand visited the large Adventist Hospital as guest of the staff. \nDur\xad\ning my brief stay, I made rounds and observed in the outpatient \nclinic. \nBangkok was a most enjoyable city, and the Christian nurses \nshowed me great kindness.\nBurma was the delight of ,my return trip. After spending several \ndays in Rangoon visiting a good friend who formerly had been to my \nhome while studying in America, I went to Muse and Namkham on \nthe Chinese border. \nMy friend pr. A1 Lun met the bus* at Muse, \nwhich is a very small village only 19 miles from Namkham, where \nDr. Seagrave, the “Buripa Surgeon,” works. \nDr. A i Lun showed \nslides from his visit to America, and there was much to discuss. \nHis \nson drove me to Namkham by jeep, and it was a thrill to meet Dr. \nSeagrave for the first tiftie.\nHe was playing baseball with the nurses when I arrived. \nHe \nappeared an old man, head bent low, with white hair, and walking \nwith effort. \nWe played side by side for the rest of the game as he \ndescribed the hospital and school of nursing, the great medical needs \nof his area, and the character of girls whom he teaches. \nThere are \n240 patients and almost 90 girls in training but only one other doctor \nto help him, an unbelievable work load. \nFor the next ten days \nwas to have the privilege of dining and working beside him.\nOur day began at eight with chapel to which all the girls were | \ninvited, Christian and Buddhist. \nEach morning they read about a \nchapter from the Bible, reading together aloud in a musical sing-song \nBurmese. \nThe Hospital is not a mission hospital, but the kindness! \nand concern, the love which is there translated into action makes it j \nstill a dynamic focus of Christianity in Burma. \nThroughout the! \ncountry Dr. Seagrave is known as the ‘‘grand old man,” and it was I \nthe Burmese people themselves who rose to defend and clear him of \nall false charges during his trial for treason in 1950. \nThe effects of I \nhis imprisonment during this time, however, are still visible, for it? \nwas a tremendous drain upon his body and spirit.\nDr. Seagrave taught for four hours each morning. \nI would ad\xad\nmit, examine, and prescribe for the morning outpatients and new \nadmissions, usually eight in number. \nWhen the Indian physician \nthere started surgery, I joined him to assist on the major cases or \nhandle the minor myself. \nIt was a valuable experience in minor \nsurgery to open abscesses, debride carbuncles, remove bullets, and \nassist with superficial lipomas and tonsillectomys. \nI removed one j z \ntonsil myself and assisted with -the removal of a huge ovarian cvst \non a patient whom I had admitted and diagnosed.\nThough Namkham is at an altitude of 3000 feet and has a very \npleasant climate, it is still customary to sleep each afternoon. \nDr. \nSeagrave was forced to live on a strict schedule to conserve his en\xad\nergy. \nWe parted after lunch and I usually studied in the hospital \noffice until coffee time at four-thirty. \nThen began the clinic work \nwith outpatients and the daily review of inpatient progress. \nSince \nDr. Seagrave is unable to walk for ward rounds, the tiny Burmese \nnurses get four to a stretcher and carry the patients down to his office.\nThere we worked side by side, he translating the history while \nI examined the patient and quickly did a brief physical on the heart, \nlungs and abdomen. \nI was fortunate enough to pick up an empyema \nwhich had been missed on admission on a child, and Dr. Seagrave \nsoon said he trusted my ears as well as his own and discontinued \nchecking my findings unless I requested his opinion.\nAt first we discussed the various interesting points of diagnosis \nand therapy so much that it slowed his work. He is a natural teacher \nand can hardly keep himself from sharing knowledge or swapping \nstories, and I saw many new things to question him about. \nBut soon \nwe- learned to discipline our own conversation and worked together \nefficiently as a team. This was a wonderful thing for ,me.\nIn a very few  days I grew in efficiency and speed as well as con-, \nfidence. \nIt was my first chance to do my own therapy with drugs j \nand to perform minor surgery. \nI saw conditions for the first time— \n¡scurvy, typhoid, cerebral malaria, hookworm, and ascariasis. \nDr. j \nSeagrave expressed the wish that I could stay to assist with th e! \nwork, and it was with deep regret that I left at the end of ten days! \nto return via Muse to Rangoon.\nFrom Calcutta I continued on by train day and night, stopping i \nonly in Delhi a few hours fo ra  visa enroute to Amritsar. \nThere for \nthe second time I visited the beautiful Golden Temple of the Sikh \nreligion, and slept outside on the roof of a temple inn, comfortable I \non a string bed with my mattress, and entranced by the warm beauty j \nof the Indian night and misty face of the moon over Hindu temples, j \nI crossed the border into Pakistan by. foot, went on local bus to ] \nLahore, and then by train for two days to Quetta, 6000 feet high on [ \nthe Baluchistani desert.\nIt was a disappointment to learn in Quetta that the weekly train i \nto Zahidan in Persia had just left, for I was racing across the Middle] \nEast (as fast as one cap race by bus and train in the desert) in order | \nto reach Sweden and have time with my friend before sailing for j \nhome on Agust 10.\nBut my frustration turned to appreciation. when I came to know | \nDr.. Ronald Holland, a Royal College surgeon and eye specialist work-1 \ning at the Mission Hospital there. \nI spent three days watching and j \nassisting him at operations, making walking rounds, working in th e! \noutpatient department and talking about the medical problems of the | \ndesert peoples. \nHe is the most distinguished eye man in that part of \nthe. world and each year holds a six-week clinic in the southern part \\ \nof the country to which two American ophthalmologists are invited' \nfor training.\nTogether they do 2000 eye operations, over 50 a day, mostly for j \ncataract. \nDuring my brief stay, I observed more than a dozen o f! \nthes^e. \nWithout complications, it is a simple procedure. \nWith them, j \none must be an expert. \nDr. Holland takes less than two minutes! \nonce the patient is properly prepared. I wondered whether a general' \nphysician working, say, in Burma would be able to do such work I \nwithout specializing in ophthalmology. \nIt seemed as if the blind! \nhad nothing to lose and everything to gain from an attempt at oper\xad\nation, even if the surgeon is not an expert.\nContinuing on by train, bus* and truck, I reached Belgrade, Yugo-\n", 18, 0), (757.683837890625, 354.1521301269531, 887.1318359375, 362.1521301269531, 'FRID AY, FEBRUARY 3, 1961.\n', 19, 0), (739.8848266601562, 384.3550109863281, 866.90283203125, 438.2673034667969, '¡Skiers Frolic \nAt Whiteface\n', 20, 0), (443.98565673828125, 445.6011047363281, 891.4940185546875, 754.7982177734375, 'by Patty Brown\nI \n“What \na \nwonderful \nweek,”\n! agreed 47 Bucknellian skiers after \nspending the mid-semester holi\xad\nday in Lake Placid skiing the \nAdirondacs.\n“Is this a ski clftb or a ,survival \nunit?” wondered the same group \nupon braving 15 below 0“ windy \nweather. I960.\n', 4, 0), (134.64996337890625, 395.1026306152344, 425.5460205078125, 421.1026306152344, 'Challenge: Peace Corps\n', 5, 0), (143.0489501953125, 428.61474609375, 423.76800537109375, 753.8258056640625, 'President Kennedy has recently proposed a program \nknown as The Peace Corps. This program involves the \nsending of volunteers, preferably recent college graduates, \nto underdeveloped countries. These people would com\xad\npose The Peace Corps. The function of this corps would \nbe to teach and aid in political adjustment of newly inde\xad\npendent countries.\nOriginally the plan was to exempt the members of the \ncorps from the draft, but that provision has been dropped. \nIt is a far from glamorous proposition. It would involve \nliving in a backward country and being paid a minimum \ngal ary \nIt now no laiiger holds the attraction of draft\nexemption for young men.\nThe program has been conceivted as a contrast to the \nAmerican habit of aiding foreign countries with money, \nand offering them no practical assistance in the running \nof an unstable country. The Kennedy administration has \nbeen characterized by the word vigorous. This word sums \nup the type of people who will be* needed to make The \nPeace Corps a reality. \nService in it offers no material \nrewards, and certainly no special recognition. However, \nit dofes offer the chance to do something for America.\nSince most young men are subject to the draft, it will \nbe up to the young women of the country to answer Presi\xad\ndent Kennedy’s challenge to get out in the world and \nwork for America and her principles. \nIt has been said \nthat America’s college students are the “softest” ever. \nThis is a chance to show that we have just as much spirit \nand desire, if not more, than our fathers and grandfathers. \nThere are a good many seniors who have yet to plot their \nfutures. We suggest that they give The Peace Corps seri\xad\nous consideration.____________________\n', 6, 0), (175.19000244140625, 769.9526977539062, 394.822021484375, 792.9526977539062, 'LETTERS TO THE EDITOR\n', 7, 0), (431.2900085449219, 384.2226867675781, 580.2447509765625, 621.2186279296875, 'everyone else. \nBefore you criti\xad\ncize the coaches because there art \nno pegro boys on grant-in-aid, \nask them about this problem. Well sir, some say \nthat in order to be called truly small, a college should have an \nenrollment of not more than four students.\nI certainly have no quarrel with this statement; a four- \nstudent college must unquestionably be called small. Indeed, \none could even call it. intime if one knew what intime meant. \nBut I submit there is such a thing as being too small. Take, for \ninstance, a recent unfortunate occurrence at Crimscott A and M.\nCrimscott A and M, situated in a pleasant valley nestled \nbetween Denver and Baltimore, was founded by A. and M. \nCrimscott, two brothers who left Ireland in 1706 to escape the \npotato famine of 1841. As a result of their foresight, the Crim\xad\nscott brothers never went without potatoes for one single day of \ntheir lives—and mighty grateful they were! One night, full of \ngratitude after a hearty meal of French fries, cottage fries, hash \nbrowns, and au gratin, they decided to show their appreciation \nto this bountiful land of potatoes by endowing a college. They \nstipulated that enrollment should pever exceed four students \nbecause they felt that only by keeping the college this small\n', 75, 0), (1530.505615234375, 1092.341552734375, 1549.2496337890625, 1114.341552734375, '&\n', 76, 0), (1581.6046142578125, 1119.2406005859375, 1680.862548828125, 1141.2406005859375, 'let/\nm\n', 77, 0), (1449.8546142578125, 1147.675048828125, 1700.3353271484375, 1506.803955078125, "could each student be assured of the personalized attention, the \ncamaraderie, the feeling of belonging, th3t is all too often lacking \nin higher education.\nWell sir, things went along swimmingly until one Saturday a \nfew years ago. On this day Crimscott had a football game \nscheduled against Minnesota, its traditional rival. Football was, \nof course, something of a problem at Crimscott, what with only \nfour students enrolled in the entire college. It was easy enough \nto muster a backfield, but finding a good line—or even a bad \nline—baffled the most resourceful coaching minds in the country.\nWell sir, on the morning of the big game against Minnesota, \nits traditional rival, a capricious destiny dealt Crimscott a cruel \nblow—in fact, four cruel blows. Sigafoos, the quarterback, \nwoke up that morning with the breakbone fever. Wrichards, the \nslotback, was unable to start his motorcycle. Beerbohm-Tree, \nthe wingback-tailback. got his necktie caught in his espresso \nmachine. Langerhans, the fullback, was stolen by gypsies.\nConsequently, alas, none of the Crimscott team showed up at \nthe game, and Minnesota, its traditional rival, was able to score \nalmost at will. Crimscott was so out of sorts that they immedi\xad\nately broke off football relations with Minnesota, its traditional \nrival. This later became known as the Dred Scott Decision.\nSo you can see how only four students might be too small an \nenrollment. The number I personally favor is twenty. How \ncome? Because when you have twenty students and one of \nthem opens a pack of Marlboro Cigarettes, there are enough to \ngo around for everybody, and no one has to be deprived of \nMarlboro’s fine, mild flavor, of Marlboro’s easy-drawing filter, \nof Marlboro’s joy and zest and steadfast companionship, and \nas a result you have a student body that is filled with sweet \ncontent and amity and harmony and concord and togetherness \nand soft pack and flip-top box.\nThat’s how come. \n© '<><>> M»-* shuima»\n# \n* \n*\n", 78, 0), (1455.604248046875, 1511.2540283203125, 1701.0672607421875, 1550.00390625, 'You will also find tiventy cigarettes—twenty incomparable \nunfiltered king-size cigarettes—in each pack of Marlboro’s \nnew partner in pleasure—the Philip Morris Commander. \nWelcome aboard!\n', 79, 0), (123.3642578125, 1819.9832763671875, 153.0802764892578, 1835.9832763671875, 'ili!\n', 80, 0), (146.4142608642578, 1811.743896484375, 157.0392608642578, 1820.243896484375, 's a\n', 81, 0), (165.36326599121094, 1627.537841796875, 207.91726684570312, 1640.6939697265625, '13191\nS\n', 82, 0), (444.7122802734375, 1721.492919921875, 497.3782043457031, 1729.992919921875, 'liSlÄ iSiiSli\n', 83, 0), (380.41229248046875, 1737.093017578125, 535.17578125, 1774.1429443359375, 'iiii Sa?*“\nK ill§qS\ni . \n-fl\n', 84, 0), (628.5512084960938, 1616.593017578125, 1104.8006591796875, 1637.593017578125, 'K\nI\n', 85, 0), (940.5512084960938, 1659.6585693359375, 1104.6473388671875, 1681.6585693359375, 'WÊËÊËÊsÊÊÈÊÊËm\n', 86, 0), (1694.401123046875, 1656.4439697265625, 1723.324462890625, 1698.9400634765625, 'I H\n§\n■Ë b f!\nL\n', 87, 0), (1718.4010009765625, 1654.29296875, 1764.281005859375, 1736.53466796875, 'N » « l l\nUsai\n■ill\n. i\nitisi\ni i i ¡ l\n', 88, 0)]

But the key word \nhere is “hit”; they could hit that \nupper register, but they could not \nplay there. \nFor whereas with \nothers, such high notes were \nfreakish—squeals to be reached \nand skidded over and then drop\xad\nped—Maynard was able to work \ncomfortably and accurately at \nthat register. \nThe Kenton band \nhad parts written especially for \n, Maynard, because no one else \ncould play them.\n", 13, 0), (270.68280029296875, 444.6488952636719, 433.1357116699219, 1035.0240478515625, "j \nOne of the memorable sights \ni in jazz was to see Maynard, with \n! I \nNo matter where one looks, on \ncampus or off, people will be \nfound to fit into three classes in j \ntheir \nrelation \nwith \nminority j \ngroups. There are those who truly | \naccept all people as equals; those j \nwho go to extremes to demon- j \nstrate their liberalism; and also j \nthose \nwho won’t even speak. This revised ! \nconstitution has been discussed \nand passed already in a joint \nmeeting of the present SFC (Zoun-1 \ncil and Cabinet.\nThé major change in the con-1 \nstitution is that the SFC will be \none body consisting of 21 mem\xad\nbers. \nIt is felt that in a smaller, \nmore compact body, the Student \nFaculty Congress can work more \nefficiently and serve the entire \nbody to a better advantage.\nAnother change is that the vice \npresident will now assume the \nduties of chairman of the Elec\xad\ntions Committee and will run the \naffairs of the freshman class until \nits officers are elected. \nIn these \ncapacities the vice president will \nbe taking over the responsibili\xad\nties now held by faculty mem\xad\nbers.\nUnder the revised constitution \nthe vice president can be either a \njunior or a senior. \nIt is felt that \nthis will offer more of an oppor\xad\ntunity for persons to work up in \nthe organization.\nAnother important item in the \nrevised constitution is the addi\xad\ntion of the Academic Advisory \nCommittee “to consider the aca\xad\ndemic standards and program of \nBucknell and ways in which they \nmay be improved, and, if pos\xad\nsible, specific steps to be taken.” \nIt was strongly felt that this is \nan area in which SFC should be \nconcerned.\n", 90, 0), (1549.679443359375, 757.9179077148438, 1696.0338134765625, 1143.467041015625, 'Vice President\nNominated for the office of vice \npresident are William Dorr, Wil\xad\nliam \nFletemeyer, \nand \nWayne \nGrove. \nBill Dorr, a junior from \nDelmar, N. [(747.8499755859375, 349.4227600097656, 1699.216796875, 359.3727111816406, 'FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1961.\nFRIDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1961.\nTHE BUCKNELLIAN, BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY, LEWISBURG, PENNA.\nPAGE THREE\n', 0, 0), (145.9000244140625, 387.4611511230469, 383.55499267578125, 405.4611511230469, '■ \nFacts and Questions\n', 1, 0), (149.489013671875, 412.3345947265625, 433.5390625, 1053.7532958984375, 'It is not often that the Bucknellian answers a readers’ \nletter through an editorial. \nHowever we feel that Mr. \nZeller’s letter of February 6 is a special case.\nWe are sincerely sorry that our editorial angered Mr. \nZeller to the point that he felt strong language might help \nan otherwise weak case. The Bucknellian did send a re\xad\nporter to the admissions office last year, he was refused \nthe pertinent information on the basis that it was confi\xad\ndential.\nMr. Zeller made the point in his letter that there is no \nUniversity policy toward Negroes concerning admissions. \nWe sincerely hope that this statement doesn’t imply that \nthere are policies toward other racial or religious groups. \nThe letter argued that there simply aren’t enough “fiinan- \ncially able Negroes to go around.” \nHowever, investiga\xad\ntion shows that the Betty Ann Quinn Scholarship, which \ncontrary to Mr. Zeller’s letter is specifically for Negroes, \nis not being used at this time.\nThe letter made a valid point in its statement as to why \nthere are so few, indeed no, Negro athletes at Bucknell \nHowever a boy by the name of Irwin Roberson who won \na silver medal for the United States in the recent Olym\xad\npics, applied for admission to Bucknell four years ago; he \nwas in the top quarter of his class, and a star football \nplayer and trackman. \nHe is a Negro; he wanted to come \nto Bucknell; he was denied admission. This fact has been \nsupplied by a present Bucknell student who is a friend of \nRoberson’s. \nIt is entirely possible that there was some \nperfectly valid reason for rejecting this boy. \nUnfortu\xad\nnately it is not apparent.\nWe must accept Mr. Zeller’s statement that the social \nclimate at Bucknell is not as sympathetic to Negro stu\xad\ndents as it might be. \nWe wonder whether a continued \nlack of Negro students will do anything to change this sit\xad\nuation. Also, the soeiaL opportunities for Jews, Catholics, \nKoreans, Burmese and other non-Anglo-Saxon Protestants \nare really not much better. Yet each of these groups is \nrepresented on the Bucknell campus. \nNow it seems, to \nus, unfair to subject these groups to a narrow social life,, \nwhile saving the Negro student from it. \nThere appears \nto be something wrong with Mr. Zeller’s reasoning on this \npoint.\nWe do agree with Mr. Zeller that the absence of a pho\xad\ntograph from the application will not take prejudice out \nof people’s hearts, but it certainly would be a step toward \nattracting more Negro applicants, which Mr. Zeller agrees \nwould be a more desirable goal than having them scared \naway by the picture requirentent.\nAccording to Mr. Zeller’s letter we have been “beating \nthe director of admissions.” We are extremely sorry if we \ngave this impression. \nThe Bucknellian is quite aware \nthat Mr. Walling and his staff are not in the position of \nbeing directly responsible for admissions policies. How\xad\never, somewhere at some time, there must take place a \ndiscussion as to how the incoming freshman class will be \n“distributed”. \nWe must apologize to Mr. Walling; we \ncentered on the Admissions Office only because it is the \nplace where, if a policy of discrimination were existent, \nit would be most blatantly manifest.\nThe Bucknellian is grateful for the response of its read\xad\ners in last week’s paper, and we hope that this important \nquestion will not be allowed to escape us again.\n', 2, 0), (551.4690551757812, 382.14447021484375, 770.869140625, 406.14447021484375, 'LEITERS TO THE EDITOR\n', 3, 0), (437.72906494140625, 415.6394348144531, 590.1082153320312, 715.2362060546875, 'To the President of the Univer\xad\nsity, to the Student Body, and \nto the Faculty:\nIn any society, in order to de\xad\nvelop the individual’s intellect \nand understanding of his fellow \nman, there must be a variety of \npeople; not only in character \nmake-up, but in the variety of \nraces, religions, and creeds. \nFor \nthis reason, the society of the \nUnited States as a whole has al\xad\nways been a rich and satisfying \ncountry to live in. \nIn order to \n| enrich college life for students at \nBucknell, there inust be a more \nheterogeneous student body. In Buck- \nnell’s case, they have been granted the privilege of limit\xad\ned self-government. \nThis means that they can elect of\xad\nficers who meet as an official body, regulate drives for \nfunds, conduct such programs as Spring Festival and \nfreshman hazing, and sponsor the Artist Series.\nAll these things are presently done by the SFC, but \nthese are relatively minor administrative functions. The \nmost important thing an official representative body of \nthe students should do is to mold opinion, to deliberate \nand evaluate. The rightful subject matter for such de\xad\nliberation is in this case the academic and social welfare \nof Bucknell as an institution of higher learning. This im\xad\nplies concerns within and among the students about not \nonly learning itself, but also their roles as citizens.\nFor this reason, concerned students should have a struc\xad\ntural means of meeting together and considering issues \nthat are important to the learning experience and to pub\xad\nlic citizenship. It is their position as an official body to \ndeliberate on issues that are important to the quality of \nthe university and to the public welfare. It is fitting for \nthem to consider issues carefully and, arriving at respon\xad\nsible opinions, to publicize these opinions in an attempt \nto move public sentiment behind them and ultimately \nbring the measures into effect. It is .to the credit of the \npresent SFC that it has established a committee on na\xad\ntional and international issues. We hope that it will pur\xad\nsue this end and broaden its role in the formation of cam\xad\npus opinion and in the fostering of responsible discussion \nand opinion forming in all situations.\nWho should be the leaders of such an organization? \nThey should first of all be responsible people who will \ncarry out their administrative duties effectively and will \nnot overstep their bounds in deliberation and declaration. \nThey should understand the meaning of the learning ex\xad\nperience and be eager to support those measures which \nimprove it. They should understand the aims, and needs \nof the students they represent. They should be aware of \nsocial issues beyond the campus. \nIn short, they should \nbe competent and responsible, moral and intellectual lead\xad\ners. Is this the type of person we have elected in the \npast? Is it the type we are about to choose in the coming \nelections?\n', 21, 0), (443.7601013183594, 1025.9454345703125, 595.8923950195312, 1185.64453125, 'is the obligation of this univer- \nI sity to offer these minority groups \nj a chance to develop.\nAnd since we believe that Jhis \nj is the democratic way of life, we \nj ask the student body, the faculty \nand the administration for their \n| support for the following pro- \nJ posai:\n1. \nThere isn-t\nyears. \nI any \nundergraduate student \nat\nDuring the past ten years, con- Bucknell that has taken at least\nditions have changed. \nThere is\nno longer the same need of an \nROTC program a t' Bucknell to \ninsure a stable enrollment of men \nstudents. \nThe pressure on the \nAdmissions Office here, and, at \nmany other institutions, is mount\xad\ning and will continue to ipount. \nFurthermore, although the Army \nhas a continuing need of Reserve | \nOfficers at about the present an\xad\nnual level o f‘ 14.000, with college \nenrollments in basic ROTC ex\xad\npected to double in the next \ndecade, the national requirements \nfor compulsory ROTC have di\xad\nminished.\nUnder these circumstances, the \nUniversity Board of Trustees de\xad\ncided last June that for men stu\xad\ndents, beginning with the Class \nof 1965, enrollment in Bucknell \nshould no longer carry with it a \nrequirement of enrollment in the \nbasic ROTC program. \nIt should \nbe pointed out, however, that a \nnumber of considerations point to \na voluntary program rather than \nto no program at all.\nAs long as America lives in the \npresent world of tension, a strong \ndefense is vital for our national \nsecurity and that of our friends \naround the world. \nSome of the \nuniversities of the country must \ncontinue, in the national interest, \nto provide opportunity for the \ntraining of future leaders of the \nArmed Services, whose motivation \nin the direction of a Service \ncareer is strong. \nThe Service \nAcademies do not, and could not \nwithout drastic expansion, meet \nthe present need \nfor officers. \nBucknell’s unit is one of the bet\xad\nter ones, and there is no good \nreason for dropping it. By adopt\xad\ning a voluntary program at both \nlevels, Bucknell places itself, as \nfar as ROTC programs are con\xad\ncerned, on a basis of equality in \nrecruiting men students, with all \neducational institutions, whether \nthey have compulsory or volun\xad\ntary programs, or no ROTC pro\xad\ngram at all.\nKarl D. [(132.5, 347.5209655761719, 1692.071533203125, 364.4208679199219, 'PAGE TWO\nTHE BUCKNELLIAN, BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY, LEWISBURG, PENNA.\n‘ FRIDAY, MARCH 3, 1961.\nFRIDAY, MARCH 3, 1961.\nTHE BUCKNELLIAN, BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY, LEWISBURG, PBNNA.\nPAGE THREE\n', 0, 0), (188.3900146484375, 387.5129699707031, 371.0650329589844, 412.5129699707031, 'A Clarification\n', 1, 0), (139.6800994873047, 420.983642578125, 425.4100341796875, 1005.506103515625, "Much has been said about discrimination on the Buck- \nnell campus, both on the printed page and in heated and \nsome not-so-heated discussions., In view of the recent ex- \n' change of letters-to-the editor, the Bucknellian wishes to \nclarify its stand on discrimination.\nWe originally raised the issue in order to obtain some \nconcrete proof for the charge that the admissions staff \ndiscriminates in their selection of students. We are happy \nto recognize, as a result of figures released last week, that \nthis charge is completely unfounded.\nMoreover, a check of scholarship records shows that the \nBetty Ann Quinn scholarship mentioned in last week’s \neditorial has been awarded to a Negro student every se\xad\nmester for the past five years. At present, it is not being \nused because its recipient withdrew at the end of the first \nsemester.\nIn addition, a check of applications shows that Irwin \nRoberson, the star athlete described in last week’s edi\xad\ntorial, did not apply to Bucknell. \nIt is thought that he \nwas interested in this school and may have been ap\xad\nproached by the athletic department, but no facts are \navailable to corroborate this rumor.\nA clarification of these statements by no means closes \nthe issue; if anything, it should make us more aware of \nthe problems at stake. \nAs we see it, the question of dis\xad\ncrimination is two-fold. \n(1) To encourage more Negroes \nto apply to Bucknell, two steps may be taken: the picture \nnow requested on the application could be eliminated, and \npictures requested only after the applicant has applied \nfor admission. Secondly, the admissions team might make \nmore of an effort to seek out qualified Negroes in their in\xad\nterviewing. \n*\n(2) To make the social climate amenable to Negroes, \nstudents must evidence a desire for real understanding of \nand friendship with those of other races. Paul Pearson’s \nletter indicated that none of the fraternities on this cam\xad\npus have discriminatory clauses. \nThis reassurance re\xad\nlieves us from making a token gesture to remove such \nclauses. \nThe question is not one of clauses, but one of \nattitude. We would hope that the individuals comprising \neach fraternal organization reserve the right to choose \nmembers on the basis of personal qualities, and that each \nchapter, in turn, is free to extend membership accord\xad\ningly.\nBut why, you ask, should we bother to diversify the \nstudent population? \nThere is an answer to this question: \nit is unrealistic and provincial for a university to exist as \nan island in the midst of the racial problems confronting \n. the rest of the United States. To discourage contact with \nother races and nationalities is to shelter today’s student \nand to submerge him in a stagnant environment.\nBy the educative process, íyoven of both social and aca\xad\ndemic threads, we expect individuals to learn to recognize \nother human beings for their abilities and attributes, re\xad\ngardless of their racial or socio-economic heritages.\nis the Bucknell community ready to accept this respon\xad\nsibility?\n", 2, 0), (542.880126953125, 381.20721435546875, 762.1842041015625, 405.20721435546875, 'LETTERS TO THE EDITOR\n', 3, 0), (578.630126953125, 410.6022033691406, 877.268798828125, 445.5021057128906, '] discontinued \nit. \nHowever, we j useful type of evaluation form. \nI should like to inquire if the au- It will be completed for use this\nsemester.\nThe third criticism in the edi-\n', 4, 0), (731.9701538085938, 455.7521057128906, 878.3216552734375, 501.9015197753906, 'munication. \nLike any large size \norganization we do have some \nproblems \nwith \ncommunication. \nHowever, we do manage to pub\xad\nlish an agenda before each of our\n', 5, 0), (432.47015380859375, 413.5024719238281, 725.0650634765625, 440.9514465332031, 'Dear Editor:\nLike any group that is interest-.\ned in achieving its purpose and I thor of the editorial has ever at-\n', 6, 0), (431.0091857910156, 449.5014953613281, 880.0120239257812, 619.4974365234375, 'St^dent-Faculty^C^ngras^wel- j W e^tóve]6 a n /* w *  classify tffis. toria! presented was one of com- \ncomes all helpful criticism. The topic was as timely and fit\xad\nting a one as could have been chosen: America Challenged \nin a Changing World. It was general enough to be inter\xad\nesting and important to any citizen, but specific enough to \nbe highly informative and to provide the factual basis for \nresponsible opinion making. It covered domestic as well \nas international issues.\nThe personnel who came to lead the sessions were es\xad\npecially noteworthy, if a little weak on the conservative \nside. \nIt is to Miss O’Bannon’s credit that, she was able to \nsecure such prominent personages.\nThe success of the conference lies not only in that im\xad\nportant men discussed current issues at Bucknell, but also \nin that the student response was so great. Each session \nwas crowded with people, who asked pertinent and intel\xad\nligent questions which reflected interest in. as well as \nawareness of, the problems involved.\nWith the hope that students will continue to think and \ndiscuss the “challenging” ideas presented by this two-day \nconference, the Bucknellian salutes both Bucknell and thfe \nChallenge.\nUnrknrlltan\n', 16, 0), (210.19911193847656, 1345.5322265625, 373.8647155761719, 1384.1219482421875, 'OF BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY \nEstablished 1897 \nLEWISBURG. The quality of both courses and professors \nhas improved considerably. I think most students will \nacknowledge the successful efforts by the administration \nto make Bucknell wprthy of calling itself an “institution \nof higher learning.” I feel, however, that the administra- \nI \ntion has overlooked one very important fact.\nIncoming freshmen are not aware of this academic re\xad\nform program; and, under the present system, the only \nway they can find out is to go through the rigors of their \nj \nfirst stemester. Unfortunately, some freshmen experience \nmore difficulty than others because they sigh up fpr the \nwrong courses, plan an unbalanced schedule, or take too \nmany courses in one semester that involve extensive read- \n! \ning or writing.\nActually, the difficulty these people experience is unnec\xad\nessary. The situation can be remedied if the administra\xad\ntion, along with its other reforms, will provide counseling \nfor freshmen before they sign up for courses and before \nthey arrive on campus in September. Right now the only- \n“counselor” available to a high school senior, who has \n! \nbeen accepted by Bucknell, is the catalogue. An incom- \nI \ning freshman must select his first semester courses, mak- \n1 \ning his decisions solely on what he learns from the cata\xad\nlogue. . For instance, History 99 and 100: “The evolution \nof Western Civilization from its beginning to the present \ntime, with emphasis on problems and values.” \nThis is \nj \nwhat it says in' the catalogue; sounds pretty innocuous, \n", 22, 0), (439.1940002441406, 1220.868408203125, 729.023193359375, 1283.1644287109375, 'j \ndoesn’t it? \nThere is nothing to keep a freshman from \ntaking courses like History 99, Religion 100, Math. 201, a \nthird year language, and English 101 all in the first se\xad\nmester.\nCounseling is definitely needed, as evidenced by the \nfact that too many freshmen took a first semester as heavy \n', 23, 0), (434.3929748535156, 1283.513427734375, 735.7235107421875, 1527.00048828125, 'j \nas the one just outlined, too heavy to handle efficiently, \nj \nand they are now in serious academic difficulty. \nSome \nwere forced to do only half a job on one or two subjects . \n• j \nin hopes that the extra time could be used to pull up two \nI \nother subjects. \nToo many freshmen have a “2.000” as \ntheir goal rather than striving for a higher average. This \nis a poor situation to be forced into and a poor attitude \nto take toward learning.\nThe administration should require incoming freshmen \nto come up to Bucknell before the end of July to go over \ntheir first semester schedule with their counselor. \nThe \ncounselor should make changes to make sure that the new \nstudent takes the best courses and spreads them out so he \nhas the time to get the most from his courses. \nI realize \nthat in some cases a freshman will find it impossible to \narrange a trip to Bucknell for this purpose, but institu\xad\ntions such as Penn State are able to operate a counseling \nsystem similar to this one, and I see no reason why Buck\xad\nnell should be behind in this area.\nMy suggestions will not help the people who are too \nlazy to keep up their marks; but if a counseling service is \nestablished more hard-working, and deserving students \nwill be left at Bucknell to benefit from the newly improv\xad\ned academic standards.\n', 24, 0), (732.6930541992188, 813.3475341796875, 883.7191772460938, 859.497314453125, 'I the actions pf a few. \nWe took \n| the stand that this was not typical \ni of the feelings of the majority »of \nI the students;.\nOne possibility we investigated \n', 25, 0), (733.4430541992188, 860.3472290039062, 884.6050415039062, 934.8468627929688, 'j was the sponsoring of a capable \ni Negro student who lacked finan- \nj cial backing to come to Bucknell.\nI We discussed tthis with the admin- \nI istration and also sent two people \nl to a meeting of the National Asso- \nj ciation of Student Government, \ni who was dealing with similar \n', 26, 0), (734.89306640625, 935.7467651367188, 885.2918701171875, 962.9466552734375, 'j problems at the time. 399.7931213378906, 1100.2388916015625, 981.6378784179688, 'Dear Editor, \n,\nWith concern over the recent \neditorial approach to the first se\xad\nmester operation of women’s co\xad\noperative self-government, Senate \nwould like to present some com\xad\nments on the questions which you \nraised. \nAs a representative body, \nwe Ijave felt the need to be aware \nthroughout the past semester of \nthe problems which are in estab\xad\nlishing a new mechanism of self- \ngovernment.\nHowever, we have come to be\xad\nlieve, in the past months,, that \nwomen are beginning to under\xad\nstand When the \nsubject pushes the button of the \ncorrect answer, a bulb lights.\nThe other type of machine is \ndesigned to present and answer \nessay, or open-ended questions. \nThe question is presented on one \nside of a piece of paper under a \nglass panel, and the subject writes \nhis answer to the question on the \nother side of the paper. \nThen, a \nlever is pulled which presents the \ncorrect answer, thus enabling the \nstudent to confirm his response.\nAdvantages\n'The teaching-machine has cer\xad\ntain advantages. [(131.0400390625, 344.8728332519531, 1693.7666015625, 363.9228820800781, 'FRIDAY, MARCH 3, 1961.\nTHE BUCKNHLLIAN, BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY, LEWISBURG, PENNA.\nPAGE FIVE\nPAGE FOUR\nTHE BUCKNELLIAN, BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY, LEWISBURG, PENNA.\nFRIDAY, MARCH 3, 1961.\n', 0, 0), (131.73004150390625, 384.69189453125, 269.89556884765625, 438.63818359375, 'Eight Discuss \nHonesty Today\n', 1, 0), (132.48004150390625, 446.1719055175781, 285.9335632324219, 1568.712646484375, 'Reprinted from—\nRedbook Magazine\nEight leading Americans spoke \nout today against widespread dis\xad\nhonesty and the growing accept\xad\nance of it in America life.\nIn order to determine what can \nbe \ndone \nto retain \ntraditional \nStandards of honesty, Redbook \nMagazine asked reporter William \nPeters \nto \ninterview \nMargaret \nMead, \nDr. \nReinhold \nNiebuhr, \nFairfax Cone, Phyllis McGinley, \nSenator Margaret Chase Smith, \nJudge Learned Hand, Agnes E. \nMeyer and Edward R. Murrow.\nMost of those interviewed felt \nthere was more personal dis\xad\nhonesty and more tolerance of it \nthan in previous generations. Ad\xad\nvertising executive, Fairfax Cone \nand \nAnthropologist \nMargaret \nMead expressed opinions that to\xad\nday’s personal dishonesty was as\xad\nsociated with Prohibition. \nMrs. | \nAgnes Meyer and Senator Mar- j \ngaret Chase Smith related- it to \nWorld War II\nFeel Cheated\nThe idea that some people tend \nto cheat when they feel cheated I \nwas expressed frequently. Those I \ninterviewed said that while cheat- \ning occurred against large imper\xad\nsonal institutions such as govern- 1  \nmen*, insurance companies, cor\xad\nporations, schools, large depart-1 \nment or chain stores, honesty be-1 \ntweefi individuals was as strong \nas ever.\nAlmost everyone interviewed, \nthe article reports, pointed to the; \ninequities in the income-tax law \nand several mentioned the Social \nSecurity regulations which pen\xad\nalizes people for working after \nthey are 65.\nJudge Learned Hand, \nalone, \nstressed an increase in certain \nkinds of morality pointing to im\xad\nprovements in execution laws, | \npolitical graft, voting frauds and | \nimproved standards of judicial j \nconduct, although he felt that | \n“we seem also to have lost most | \nof our former sense of personal j \nresponsibility.”\nIn discussing religion in con- j \nnection with morality, Dr. Rein- j \nhold Niebuhr asserted that “re-1 \nligion is much more popular b u t, \nless meaningful in America to\xad\nday.” \nHe felt there has been a j \ngradual loss of spirit in the re\xad\nligious community, stressing that \nthe church had become more a \nsocial than a religious institution, \nin recent years.\nSecurity Need\nThe preoccupation with security \nwas a predominant factor in the \ncomments of Edward R. Murrow \nwho said that “when a desire for \ncomplete security becomes a ma\xad\njor goal, it is little more than a \ndesire to return to the warmth \nand comfort of protected child\xad\nhood.”\nIn summing up the solutions to \nthe question of morality, there \nwas a general agreement that dis\xad\ncipline must be strengthened.\nEqual stress by many of those \ninterviewed was on removing the \ninequities from necessary laws \nand rules such as unfair income- \ntax laws, inequitable earning re\xad\nquirements under Social Security, \nconfusion of purpose in business \nexpense accounts, shadowy lines \nbeween honest practices and con- \nflcts of interest, unjust grading of \nstudents on curves and on strictly \nobjective tests that ignore indi\xad\nvidual differences, draft regula\xad\ntions that discriminate, unequal \napplication of laws.\nWant Leadership\n“The American \npeople have \nlacked leadership in all these \nareas,” Mrs. Agnes Meyer said. \n“We need the new values and \ngoals that can only be defined by \nstrong, vigorous and intelligent \nnational leadership. \nInstead of \npursuing \nindividual \ngoals \nof \nwealth and security, we need \nhave our horizons broadened until \nwe can see the far greater im\xad\nportance of freedom and coopera\xad\ntion. \nOur public leaders must \nbegin using all available scientific \nknowledge \nabout \nthe \nmodem \nworld and its problems to arrive \nat an understanding of our proper \nnational goals and then they must \nbegin to talk clearly and honestly \nto the American people about \nthem.”\n', 2, 0), (281.980224609375, 380.24267578125, 377.61224365234375, 392.24267578125, '... Faculty Stand\n', 3, 0), (282.230224609375, 397.4127502441406, 434.478759765625, 1015.0574340820312, "(Continued s from page 1) \n,\nor in any manner to abridge their \nprivileges or immunities as stu- j \ndents, in any department of the ; \nUniversity.’\nWe take this statement to mean j \nthat neither in the employing of \nteachers nor in the selecting of \nstudents ought the administration ; \nor the faculty to consider religi- > \nous belief or church affiliation as j \na relevant qualification—or dis- \nqualification.”\nB. \n“Further, we believe it to [ \nbe a correct extension of the pro\xad\nvision \nof \nthe \nCharter quoted \nabove, and certainly consistent \nwith the intention of this provis\xad\nion, that, along with religious be\xad\nliefs, national and racial origins \nshould be looked on as irrelevant \nin the selection of students and \nfaculty. \nDiversity of religious \nviews and national and racial \nbackgrounds is to be welcomed— , \nindeed, should be considered es- i \nsential—in an institution of high\xad\ner learning whose aim is to seek ' \nthe truth wherever it may be \nfound.”\nC. \n“Finally, we hold that the\nJJniversity should be directly con - \ncemed both to prevent discrimin- j \nation on the basis qf race, religion, ! \nor national origin from entering \nany part of its life and to protect i \nits students, its faculty, its staff, \narid its guests from discrimination \nwhile they are associated with the I \nUniversity.” \n\\\nII. \nThat the Faculty recom- ! With respect \nto America’s foreign policy, he \nappealed \nfor \ndisengagement, \nwhich he defined as an “orderly \nwithdrawal \nfrom \ncommitments \ninvolving the risk of war.” \nDiscussing necessary economic \n! measures, Thomas deplored the \nj “war economy” of our present \nI “garrisoned state,” in which al- \nI most half of the funds available \nI for scientific research are channel- \nj ed into weapon development, and \n| pleaded for a planned transition \nj to a “peace economy.” \nIn the \n! social sphere, he raised the prob- \n! lem of discrimination, emphasiz- \n| ing the immeasurable damage \n! done to our foreign prestige by \nI such' incidents as race riots.\nThomas’ treatment of the tradi- \nI tional objections raised to disarm- \nI ament again struck an impres- \nI sively realistic note. He express- \n| ed hope that a new Geneva Con- \n1 ference, unmarred by a U2 inci- \n| dent, might produce a satisfactory \n, treaty, for Russia is more confi- \nI dent than America of winning the \ncold war without arms. \nIn addi\xad\ntion, however, he emphasized the \nfact that secret testing might be \ncontinued by Russia, and that in \nall probability no system of in\xad\nspection adequate to detect such \ntests would be possible.\nTaking this fact into considera\xad\ntion, he nevertheless declared that \nthe risk of total annihilation im- \nj plied by continued armament is \ninfinitely greater than the risk of \nI increased Russian power which \nmight result from a policy of dis\xad\narmament. \nAmericans \nhave \nceased to value universal ideals \nand are concerned only with na\xad\ntional security, with the preserva\xad\ntion of their own way of life.
