But \nthe reason for the foreign advant\xad\nage is not what he had anticipat\xad\ned.\n“Until I got on the inside,” he \nsaid, “I thought they had us lick\xad\ned over here because of wage \nrates. \nI know differently now. \nFor every penny they’re saving in \ndirect labor costs, they’ve got us \nwhipped by three cents in gen- I \neral overhead. \nInside the plant, \nit’s about a standoff—but when \nyou get to the office, they make | \nus look like fools.”\nHis company and this European 1 \nfirm are about the same size in \nterms of units of production. The i \nAmerican \ncompany \nhas \nabout I \n1200 hourly workers in its plant, \nthe overseas factory 1300. \nBut | \nin terms of salaried employes, it’s j \na different story—912 in America \nversus 221 in Europe. There’s a \nclue to our basic disadvantage in \nforeign competition today. Here \nin the United States we have the \nmost expensive industrial m an-, \nagement on earth.\nIt starts right at the top. The j \nAmerican firm mentioned has an j \nactive chairman of the board, a \npresident, five vice presidents, and I \nan executive staff of 42 people. \nThe European firm is run by a I \nmanaging director and one key I \nassistant. \nThe top-management | \nstaff totals only nine. \nThe con\xad\ntrast continues right down the \nline. \n“They could pay our wage | \nrates,” the American president \nsaid, “and we still couldn’t com\xad\npete—our overhead would lick us \nhands down.”\n“If you know the answer, why \ndon’t you go home with a big ax} \nand chop yourelf down to size?” j \nI asked. \nHis reply pretty well \ndefined the problem: “How can \nI? \nEven if I were capable of \nrunning our company as a one- \nman show—which is virtually | \nwhat’s happening over here—I’m ] \nnot at all certain that I could get \naway with it as far as our organi- | \nzation is concerned. \nOur second- j \n1 level executives \nhaven’t \nbeen \ntrained to take over in the way | \nthese European boys have.” \nFin\xad\nally, almost to himself, he added, \n“I wonder how we got so far off \nthe beam?”\nOne Explanation \nI have a theory that may be at I \nleast partially applicable. \nThis ! \nman, like so many other corpora- j \nlion heads today, is now in his! \nmiddle 50’s. That means he spent I \nhis formative years during the j \nDepression, as I did, when busi\xad\nness leaders were being violently \nattacked as enemies of society— \ngreedy, grasping, dictatorial, anti- j \nsocial. \nNot all these politically \ninspired charges were true by any \nmeans, but the rising young busi-1 \nnessman of that day saw enough \ntruth in some of them to cause I \nhim to decide that when he got \nto the top. he was going to be i \ndifferent. \nBefore long, we found j\n', 4, 0), (280.764892578125, 423.5753479003906, 429.5230407714844, 835.271484375, 'a word to characterize that differ\xad\nence: “enlightened.”\nAt first “enlightenment” meant \nonly a heightened social con\xad\nscience. \nFairly quickly, however, \nthe definition was broadened to \nimply a businessman who was, in \nall particulars, the opposite of \nwhat the old-style businessman \nwas charged with being. \nIf the \nOld Man was distatorial and auto\xad\ncratic, we enlightened business\xad\nmen would bring democracy into \nthe world of business. \nWe would \nend one-man rule. \nWe would \nemploy group thinking. \nThus, \nthe committee system of opera\xad\ntion came into being—and the top \nexecutive became a sort of super \ncommittee chairman.\nAgain, if the Old Man’s weak\xad\nness was in handling people, that \nwas where the new man would \nbe strong. This resolution led to \ngreat expenditures of time and \neffort in labor relations, public \nrelations, \ncommunity \nrelations. \nKeeping everyone happy and con\xad\ntented became a prime goal of \nbusiness management.\nThus was formed the rounded \nimage of the ideal corporate ex\xad\necutive. — quiet, even-tempered, \ndemocratic, one of the group, a \nman who led by soft persuasion, \na compromiser, a coordinator, a \nman who never ruffled tempers \nor hurt people’s feelings—in short, \na man whom everyone liked. It \nis the image of the “nice guy” wp \nstill worship in this era, when \n“getting along with people” is \ncounted as the most important \ntalent a man can possess.\n', 5, 0), (454.514892578125, 423.1195983886719, 552.5755004882812, 431.6195983886719, 'Managerial Revolution\n', 6, 0), (431.7149963378906, 436.5714416503906, 579.5384521484375, 834.5679931640625, "At the same time, another trend \nwas under way—the “managerial \nrevolution.” \nAs American indus\xad\ntry grew older and larger, the \nownership of more and more \ncompanies passed from, individ\xad\nuals or families to general pub\xad\nlic. Instead of businesses being \nrun by the men who owned'them, \nthey were managed by men who \nwere hired to perform that func\xad\ntion.\nThe rise of professional man\xad\nagement has been vital to our \ntremendous economic growth, but \nit has its drawbacks. \nThe pro\xad\nfessional business manager has \nevery \ninducement \nto join the \n“nice guy” cult. In the previously mentioned debate, it was right\xad\nly stated that the bulk of the responsibility for diversify\xad\ning the studënt body rests upon the students themselves. # \nVarious means to this end are now wihin the realm of \npossibility.\nA study undertaken by a member of the English de\xad\npartment has shown that more applicants hear about \nBucknell from other students, than from any other source. \nWhat better means exists, of changing the “image” of \nBucknell, than by our informing students of other racial \nand economic groups of the educational opportunities \navailable here? \nAs students, we can encourage the filing \nof applications for admissions by qualified students from \nour own high schools and communities. We can do more \nourselves toward securing such applications, than can the \nAdmissions Office.\nSecondly, we all realize that a major reason for the ab\xad\nsence of qualified students from lower economic groups \nresults from a lack of substantial scholarships. Why not \naccumulate funds for a scholarship fund to be awarded to \na selected student from another racial and/or economic \ngroup? This fund would be maintained by student con\xad\ntributions and administered by the university. Incident\xad\nally, a contribution to such a scholarship fund would \nmake an excellent class gift!\nDiscussion has resulted in the realization that all seg\xad\nments of the Bucknell community desire a more diversi\xad\nfied student body. \nWe have stated several means by \nwhich we, as students, may further the realization of this \ngoal. We had first hoped to receive \nsuch a letter after the appearance of an editorial in mid- \nDecember ending with the question, “SFC, what are you \ndoing?” SFC’s letter was well-expressed, tactful and in\xad\nformative, if somewhat late.\nWe feel, however, that some of the criticisms which \nmentioned in the letter bear defense. \nThe letter stated \nthat SFC eliminated the leadership conference as useless. \nWe would like to point out that the 1959 leadership con\xad\nference had a great deal to do with two necessary moves: \n(1) the revision of the SFC recognition of student organiz\xad\nations, and (2) the elimination of the ill-functioning SFC \nsocial committee.\nEven without such problems, the leadership conference, \nunder a capable executive committee could become a \ntruly profitable meeting of Bucknell’s student leaders, \nperhaps their only opportunity to meet as such and con\xad\nsider the problems of student government and student life \nat Bucknell. \nSFC should be the one organization most \nconcerned with a unified student approach to university \nproblems.\nSFC’s second defense, is that it did not fail to distribute \nfaculty-evaluation forms, but decided to evaluate the \nforms themselves. We feel that the Faculty evaluation \nforms are a valuable means for a professor to gain knowl\xad\nedge of student reaction to his teaching methods. \nOnce \nsuch a system of evaluation has been established, a \nprompt application of it pear the end of each semester \nwould be most beneficial for both students and faculty. \nRëgardless of whether the decision to evaluate the forms \nwas made after SFC failed to distribute them, we look \nforward to a timely distribution of the evaluation forms \nduring the spring semester.\nSFC’s third defense was of communication. The Buck\xad\nnellian is happy that these éditorials, after two and one- \nhalf months, solicited SFC’s most effective public rela\xad\ntions gesture of this term of office: the letter in last week’s \nissue.\nWe have nothing but good wishes for the incoming of\xad\nficers of SFC. This laissez-faire attitude is one reason why other institutions of \nI higher learning have remained static, when in reality they should \nhave been thriving, dynamic bodies. \nThus my first aim will be to \nawaken the student body to their responsibilities as members of the \nI Bucknell society, and to make them keenly aware that as good an \nI institution as Bucknell is, it certainly is not beyond reproach or above \nI revision.\nMinority Groups\nMy second aim will' be to further the advancement of the minor\xad\nity groups on campus. \nBy this I do not simply mean only race or \nreligious groups, but also the independent men and women, who most \ncertainly1 represent aft important segment of our campus.\nMy third aim will be to re-establish the Student-Faculty Con\xad\ngress ts the supreme governing body of the University, and to elevate \nit from the subservient position to which I fear it has slipped, due \nto the overly-emphasized role which our “social institutions” have \ncome to play. \nThis will necessarily mean a concentration of power \nin the supreme governing body and a lessening of concentration in \nall of the other branches of student government.\nThis is not to say that such groups as the IFC, MSG, or WSGA \nwill become stagnant organizations devoid of power, but that their \npower will come from the SFC and will be curtailed by them if such \noccasions should arise.\nLastly, but certainly not the least important of my aims, will be \nan emphasis on the main purpose of the University, the intellectual \nstimulation of its students. \nI would attempt to fulfill this aim \nthrough one or both of two methods. \nFirst, by programs conducive \nto the stimulation of intellectual curiosity and interest, and second a \npossible revision of our present curriculum and semester plans at \nBucknell. \nThis would entail a lessening of the work load on both \nstudents and teachers, and thus allow more time for cpncentrated \nstudy leading towards positive achievement.\nStudent Contributions\nThe part which the students can play in this overall picture is \ngreat. \nSince, essentially, you are the government, a basic stand on \nvarious issues should be taken. \nMake known your views. \nBe ex\xad\npressive rather than complacive. \nBe alive instead of dormant. And \nrealize most of all that what you do not say will not be realized, but \nwhat you speak out about will be heard. \nA  dynamic student body, \none which is sincerely interested in making Bucknell a better institu\xad\ntion, and one which takes positive, strides towards the procurement \nof ideas, will bp the student body that will get results.\nI ask you to think carefully about what has been said, seek Im\xad\nprovement for what you consider lacking, and take an active part in \nyour student government. The meetings of the SFC are open to you \n—take advantage of the opportunities which are most certainly yours \nand which will assuredly make Bucknell an improved institution.\n", 11, 0), (753.0910034179688, 390.82037353515625, 865.8129272460938, 449.37042236328125, 'LETTERS TO \nTHE EDITOR\n', 12, 0), (735.0911254882812, 455.9664611816406, 885.7908935546875, 806.2628173828125, 'Dear Editor:\nThe question of student interest \nin the problems facing the present \nworld interests me no end. Well sir, some* \ntimes words are proper names that have passed into the language. \nTake, for instance, the words used in electricity: ampere was \nnamed after its discoverer, the Frenchman Andre Marie Ampere \n(1775-1836); similarly ohm was named after the German G. S. \nOhm (1781-1854), watt after the Scot James Watt (1736-1819), \nand bulb after the American Fred C. Bulb (1843-1912).\nThere is, incidentally, quite a poignant little story about Mr. \nBulb. Until Bulb’s invention, all illumination was provided by \ngas, which was named after its inventor Milton T. Gas who, \nstrange to tell, had been Bulb’s roommate at Cal Tech! In fact, \nstrange to tell, the third man sharing the room with Bulb and \nGas was also one whose name burns bright in the annals of \nillumination—Walter Candle!\nThe three roommates were inseparable companions in col- . \nlege. After graduation all three did research in the problem of \nartificial light, which at this time did not exist. All America \nused to go to bed with the chickens. In fact, many Americans \nwere chickens.\nWell sir, the three comrades—Bulb, Gas, and Candle— \npromised to be friends forever when they left school, but success, \nalas, spoiled all that. First Candle invented the candle, got \nrich, and forgot his old friends. Then Gas invented gas, got rich, \nbankrupted Candle, and forgot his old friends. Then Bulb in\xad\nvented the bulb, got rich, bankrupted Gas, and forgot his \nold friends.\n', 46, 0), (1436.9156494140625, 1190.702392578125, 1653.497802734375, 1209.702392578125, 'lief f a m e o v e r  M it?\n', 47, 0), (1425.625732421875, 1221.8115234375, 1672.579833984375, 1519.6103515625, "Candle and Gas, bitter and impoverished at the age respec\xad\ntively of 75 and 71, went to sea as respectively the world’s \noldest and second oldest cabin boy. Bulb, rich and grand, also \nwent to sea, but he went in style—as a first-class passenger on \nluxury liners.\n■ Well sir, strange to tell, all three were aboard the ill-fated \nLusitama when she was sunk in the North Atlantic. And, \nstrange to tell, when they were swimming for their lives after the \nshipwreck, all three clambered aboard the same dinghy!\nWell sir, chastened and made wiser by, their brush with death, \nthey fell into each other’s arms and wept and exchanged for\xad\ngiveness and hefcume fast friends all over again.\nFor three years they drifted in the dinghy, shaking hands and \nsinging the Cal Tech rouser all the while. Then, at long last, \nthey spied a passing liner and were taken aboard.\nThey remained fast friends for the rest of their days, which, \nI regret to report, were not many, because the liner which picked \nthem up was the Titanic.\nWhat a pity that Marlboros were not invented during the \nlifetimes of Bulb, Gas, and Candle! Had there been Marlboros, \nthese three friends never would have grown apart because they \nwould have known how much, despite their differences, they still \nhad in common. One needs only \nto look at the combination of tal\xad\nents used in the making of it to \nknow he is going to see some\xad\nthing different. \nBut what does \none find here? Only a story about \nordinary human beings, all hav\xad\ning faults and virtues; this is the \nmajor problem. We have become \nso used to seeing stereotyped \ncharacters and situations on the \nscreen that when “the misfits” \ncome along, it is difficult to ac\xad\ncustom oneself to them.\nIf the power of The Misfits had \nto be attributed to a single force, \nthis force would be the words of \nArthur Miller, for he has some\xad\nthing important to say. We are \nall searching for the meaning of \nlife. \nIf there is one, few of us \nfind it, and perhaps it can only be \nfound through the understanding, \nkindness and love of human re\xad\nlationships. \nMr. Miller uses all \nhis characters to express his phi\xad\nlosophy, but in no one is this more \nobvious than in Rosalind, the \nunifying factor of the entire \nmovie.\nRosalind is so beautifully play\xad\ned by Miss Monroe that I wonder \nat the competence of the critics, \nwho, after watching her in this \nfilm, say that she cannot act. She \ncaptures attention in every scene \nwhich she plays, but this was \nmeant to be. Gable, Wallach, and \nClift, in short, have never been \nbetter. \nEach handles his role \nwith such sincerity that they \noverwhelm one with their natur\xad\nalism, and with the expert direc\xad\ntion of John Huston and the per\xad\nfectly placed music of Alex North, \nall help create an outstanding \nmovie that is at once bold, fresh, \nand exciting.\nFrom beginning to end, The \nMisfits glows with a vitality that \nnever, not for a single moment, \ndiminishes in its intensity. Each \nindividual is portrayed with such \ndepth and feeling that, when he \nis on the screen, one has little \ntime or desire .to think of other \ncharacters. This is a motion pic\xad\nture that does not make one think \nafterwards about other people, \nbut about himself. I can, there\xad\nfore, think of no higher praise to \noffer The Misfits than to say that \nit belongs among the finest Amer\xad\nican films ever produced.\n', 15, 0), (121.65896606445312, 1099.345458984375, 267.42498779296875, 1136.5262451171875, 'Man at desk to himself: “I wish \nI had a dental; appointment to \ncancel—that always brightens my \naav.”\n', 16, 0), (269.0089416503906, 386.5362854003906, 712.99365234375, 409.9627685546875, 'Burma Weekend Includes Plays, Party, Banquet\n', 17, 0), (288.20794677734375, 436.05157470703125, 314.2349853515625, 444.55157470703125, 'S i a l i\n', 18, 0), (271.658935546875, 516.4042358398438, 285.419921875, 525.4852905273438, 'lite\n', 19, 0), (270.45892333984375, 633.0542602539062, 716.2378540039062, 670.6848754882812, 'Seated at the head table for the annual Burma-Bucknell banquet were Ambassador U On Sein, Mrs. \nSamuel Chu, Mrs. Merle Odgers, Dr. Samuel Chu,;and President Merle Odgers. J. Idzerda, humanist\n', 26, 0), (714.6500244140625, 378.1565856933594, 867.6878662109375, 958.4312133789062, "scholar and director of Michigan \n! State University’s Honors College.\n. In the past, Mr. Idzerda stated, \nthe function of the artist was to \ncreate the ethos of a society, to \ngive significance and form to life, \nj and to enlarge experience- Gea- \n! erally the artist held a position of \n¡honor and found patrons among \nj the ruling class, as in the age of \nPericles, the Medici, and Louis \nXIV.\nDuring the last two centuries, \nhowever, “the words ‘artist’ and \n‘alienation* have become synony\xad\nmous.” \nThe artist is generally \ncharacterized by such terms as \n»poor, eccentric, and of low mor\xad\nality. The essence of his aliena\xad\ntion lies in the fact that he must \nstruggle to maintain the integrity \nof his work, and that he frequent\xad\nly lowers his * standards or \nnounces art entirely.\nFour Causes\n| \nDr. Idzerda cited four main \n' causes of this alienation. \nThe \nfirst was the rapid growth of \nscience and its application to \ntechnology. \nThe analytic char\xad\nacter of science, as well as its \n“naive rationalism and naive em\xad\npiricism,” creates an atmosphere \nhostile to art, which is essentially \nunanalytic, ineffable, and intang\xad\nible. \nMoreover, scientific devel\xad\nopment encourages specialization \nof functions and division of labor \nand the artist or craftsman be\xad\ncomes “antiquarian, \nor merely \ncute.”\nA second cause cited by Mr. \nIdzerda was the rise of the middle \nclass. In addition to its role as \nchief supporter of scientism, the \nconservative attitude of this class \ncauses it to value .the more tra\xad\nditional forms of art, and to op\xad\npose innovation. Art objects may \nbe prized . as symbols of social \nposition, but, are unlikely to be \nvalued for their inherent worth.\nThe growth of literacy, Dr. Id\xad\nzerda stat0d, was a third cause \nof the artist’s alienation. \nArt \ncriticism, iconology, and art his\xad\ntory, \nmade \nwidely \navailable \nthrough developments in printing, \nhave, to a large extent, taken the \nplace of art itself. There has, \nin the past, been a general lack of pride in Bucknell \namong both faculty and students, and the question, “Why \ndid you ever come here?” has been asked on this campus \nall too often. Freshmen are disillusioned by the lack of \n“school spirit” and the fact that Bucknell is too near, in \nsome respects, to the idyllic American college delineated \nby our advertising culture, and too far from it in others. \nSaturated with trite pictures of football heroes in letter \nsweaters hand in hand with a campus queen and with \nstories of undying devotion for one’s school, we have felt \nthat we lack a uniqueness or personality as a university. \nWe are not overwhelmed by picturesque traditions, but is \n■ the absence of this sort of thing a real loss?\n', 2, 0), (155.9701385498047, 610.58154296875, 431.9400939941406, 705.031494140625, 'More significant causes for feeling inferior have been \nlow standards among both faculty and students. 795.2254638671875, 'by Wally Seward PBSCC\nThe Bucknell Sports Car Club \nwill hold its first outdoor event \nof the spring season this Sunday \nafternoon. \nStarting at Coleman \nHall parking lot at 2 p. m. a meas\xad\nured distance \npredicted \nspeed \nrally will feature hidden time \ncheck points over an unmarked \ncourse that will take approxi\xad\nmately two and one-half hours \nto complete.\nThe purpose and idea behind \nan event of this sort, unlike a \nregular road race, is not to run \nthe given distance at maximum I \nspeed, but rather to complete the I \ncourse at a speed as near as pos\xad\nsible to that which has been pre-1 \nviously determined by another j \npace car marks the initial speed I \nat a point well below the legal \nmaximum so that only the ability \nof the driver and navigator is \ntested, rather than the endurance \nof the car. \nIn order to make the I \nevent more challenging, contest- i \nants are not allowed the use of a | \nroad map, etc., but are allowed to j \nuse only a gven set of instruc-1 \ntions provided by the rally com- j \nmittee which cites \nlandmarks, I \nroad signs, and the like at which j \nchanges in speed and direction \nwill be made.\nThe navigator serves a very \nimmediate need in that through\xad\nout the event he must keep a run\xad\nning account of the total distance\n', 16, 0), (1104.26171875, 425.2755432128906, 1250.8775634765625, 687.672119140625, 'are important, not the handling \nability nor the maximum speed \nof the car. \nOddly enough the \nwhole sports car club has been \nissued a challenge by the owner \nof a ’61 Chevy Convertible.\nAll cars are invited to partici\xad\npate, regardless of vintage. \nIn \norder to encourage participation, \nthe Club will award trophies for \nthe drivers and navigators of the \nwinning \ncars. ‘ The \nsuggested \nequipment for an event of this \nsort includes: a navigator, (male \nor female), a watch with a sweep \nsecond hand, a clip Thank you for \nyour comments and also for your articles.\nI thought I would devote this article to the reasons for my com\xad\ning to Bucknell and to my future plans. \nI also hope that, after read\xad\ning this aritcle, some of you may have comments or suggestions to \nmake concerning what I have to say.\nAlmost from the first day in school I had a desire to attend col\xad\nlege and to learn as much as I possibly could. However, it was not \nuntil almost the beginning of my senior year in high school that I \nbegan to have any particular preference as to the college .1 wished \nto attend. I knew that I would prefer to attend a small college where \nI could obtain a good education. \nAttendance at a smaller college \nwould also have the advantage of affording more opportunities to \nmeet people. \nI felt that I would like to attend a college where some\xad\none like me had not recently, or perhaps had never attended. As it \nhappened, Bucknell was to be the place where I would continue my \neducation.\nMath Major\nAll through my secondary education, my major interest was \nmathematics. My father’s work involves mathematics and I guess I \ninherited the interest from him. Mother asserts that her interests \nwere no\\ so inclined. \nI felt that if given the opportunity to continue \nmy education, I would major in mathematics. Thus, I now find my\xad\nself as a mathematics major at Bucknell.\nOne of the major aims of the University is to instill in the stu\xad\ndent a desire to pursue knowledge—truth. Already I have found that \nBucknell offers one such an opportunity to pursue knowledge if one \nso desires. However, I am also aware of the fact that four years is \na rather brief time to spend .in this pursuit. I could very easily add \nan additional four years of courses I would like to take, and perhaps \nwith each new course this number would increase.\nHowever, fortunately or unfortunately, depending upon which \nway one looks at the situation, one must also prepare for future em\xad\nployment after those brief four years. You probably wonder what \nI intend to do?\nTeaching Mathematics\nAt this moment I can see two possibilities for me. \nI would like \nto be able to either teach mathematics, or to work with mathematics \nin industry. \nIf teaching should be my future, I would enjoy teach- j \ning higher mathematics. A few years ago there probably would have | \nbeen some opportunities for a teacher of mathematics iin the various j \nschools for the blind in the United States. However in recent years, \nwith the trend of capable blind students continuing their education I \nin “sighted schools,” there only remains, in many instances, the j \nteaching of elementary math in such schools.\nI believe I would much rather prefer teaching in a normal school j \nif possible. \nI realize that there will be many problems for me in j \nteaching in a public school, but I do not feel that the prospective j \nproblems would find no solutions. \nI have already mentioned in a \nprevious article that there have been blind teachers in the fields of | \nphysics and mathematics, and I should like to have the opportunity I \nto join that number.\nI would be interested in your reactions or comments upon such \nan undertaking. \nPerhaps some of you may have suggestions upon \npossible teaching methods I could use. \nIf so, I would appreciate dis- \ncussing them with you. \nI would also appreciate hearing what your \nreactions might be if you walked into a class to find me, or someone \nlike me, as the teacher.\n. \nStatistical W orker\nThe other .possibility for me in the field of mathematics after j \ngraduation is working as a statistician or in some other mathematic\xad\nally oriented employment. \nThis possibility has just recently been \nmade known to me, and perhaps such employment might prove more \nfeasible than teaching. \nI shall be taking my first statistics course \nnext year, and perhaps after this course I shall be in a better position \nfor evaluating the possibilities of employment.\nAnd thus it stands. Whether I shall become a teacher of mathe\xad\nmatics, or work in industry with mathematics remains for the future \nto reveal.\n', 44, 0), (1249.133544921875, 380.7104797363281, 1500.87353515625, 405.7104797363281, '‘ Chez Tchaikovsky\\ \n', 45, 0), (1249.133544921875, 421.5094299316406, 1549.37353515625, 446.5094299316406, 'Disappoint Solov Ballet \n', 46, 0), (1250.0836181640625, 462.5594787597656, 1535.683349609375, 487.5594787597656, '‘ Orpheus’ Performance\n', 47, 0), (1591.8336181640625, 364.82257080078125, 1761.6375732421875, 405.0084533691406, 'Wmm\nesse\n', 48, 0), (1249.1436767578125, 495.5172424316406, 1397.3985595703125, 721.76416015625, 'by Liz Atkinson\nOn March 9-10 the Bucknell \nUniversity Artist Series brought \nballet to Lewisburg. Hartzell.\nThree hundred and ninety-fire \nstudents participated in the tests \ngiven in the morning session, in \nthe fields of the social sciences, \nthe humanities, and the natural \nsciences. \nAfternoon tests were \ngiven in specific areas of study.\nInformation from these tests \nwill be used to evaluate the \nstanding of the students, both in \ntheir own class and on the na\xad\ntional level, and also to evaluate \ndepartmental and the University \nstandards. \nIn \ncomparing \nthe \nscores of the Classes of 1959 and \n1960 with the most recent scores, \nit has been noted that the aver\xad\nage scores are higher this year. \nThere were gains of 15 points in \nthe Humanities Test and 28 points \nin the Natural Science Test. \nIn \nthese two tests the seniors scored \nabove the national group, which \nincluded students from 21 colleges \nselected by the Educational Test\xad\ning Service. Bucknell students may rank with the most capable, \nbut we doubt that they rank with the most mature. They \nare potentially useful, but at Bucknell, are not acquiring \nthe sort of motivations, desires and interests that would \nmake them more prominent citizens. \nA college freshman \nis a very malleable person. He comes to school not know\xad\ning exactly what he is going to experience, or what role \nhe will play (as our freshman counselers can testify). \nBucknell has the opportunity to mold these individuals, \nbut it does not. The very atmosphere of the campus could \npromote interest in world politics, the meaning of educa\xad\ntion, the role of the engineer in our society, or the future \nof labor, simply by association and absorption. We fail, \nhowever, to fulfill this aspect of our responsibility.\n', 14, 0), (153.85903930664062, 666.959228515625, 432.3889465332031, 849.9482421875, 'A college student may choose to be an intellectual, \norienting his college experience primarily toward the de\xad\nvelopment of his mind; or he may be a diletante, with his \nattention divided among his studies, social and extra-cur\xad\nricular activities, and athletics. \nBucknell life is geared \ntoward the diletante. To be sure, it is a pleasant experi\xad\nence to approach what Bucknell has to offer as a bee ap\xad\nproaches flowers, but to do this is to miss a great oppor\xad\ntunity. The chance to devote one’s self intensely to in\xad\ntellectual activity is a rare and valuable opportunity, and \none which all too many of us forego. Such activity has a \nvaluable effect upon one’s character as well as his mmd. \nIt affects the motivations and values of the individual. It \ndevelops individuality and authenticity of the self. It is \na refining influence. People invest in higher education, \nnot only because it gives professional training, but also \nbecause it is one of the best opportunities society has of \ndeveloping the character- of its members.\n', 15, 0), (156.9590301513672, 857.248291015625, 434.7389831542969, 980.7402954101562, 'It is in this intellectual realm where Bucknell lags be\xad\nhind its potential. Our social structure, our extra-curric\xad\nular activities, even our students, are geared to diletant- \nism. \nWe become like a high class, co-educational sum\xad\nmer camp, with plenty of social opportunities, arts and \ncrafts. \nSuch experience is valuable, but it is not what \ncollege was meant to be. \nWe are cheating not only so\xad\nciety and the people that invest in us; we are cheating \nourselves. It is time for intellectualism to become a mat\xad\nter of pride on this campus. We must—and we can—be\xad\ncome more than we are, by applying our resources more \nintensely.\n', 16, 0), (745.4490966796875, 352.0356140136719, 876.6146240234375, 360.5356140136719, 'THURSDAY, MARCH Kiss Me Kate, The Pajama \nGame, and Pal Joey. \nAlthough \nthere has been a steady decline in \ntheir quality, the performances \nhave varied. \nBy far the best \nwritten and scored, Guys and \nDolls \nexhibited \nextraordinary \nsinging and dancing talent by, \nalas, long gone Bucknellians. \nIn \nthis production, even the noxious \ninfluence of the orchestra was \nheld to a minimum. \nKiss Me \nKate, on the other hand, found it \nrougher going and nearly suc\xad\ncumbed to the clamor in the pit \nbut for the powerful voices of the \ntwo leads. \nThe less said about \nPajama Game the better; its va\xad\npidness defies description.\nNow Pal Joey is quite a unique \ncase. \nIt seems that those mys\xad\nterious people behind every musi\xad\ncal production have finally real\xad\nized that you can’t join an undis\xad\nciplined voice with an unruly Or\xad\nchestra and get anything but \nnoise. \nIt’s a simple matter of \nlogistics; you don’t pass ammuni\xad\ntion to the enemy. \nEvidently the \nstaff of Pal Joey took a good look \nand a long listen to their leads, \nbecame panicky, and immediately \nsent for Dorothy \nWilson. \nA  \nwoman of unquestionable talent, \nMiss Wilson scored the music for \ntwo pianos, thereby removing a \nmajor obstacle in the path of a \nrespectable performance.\nThe next difficulty to be over\xad\ncome was casting, and here the \nattempt was only partially suc\xad\ncessful. \nIt was curious to notice \nthat for the \nidentical reasons \nSusan Aymar failed last year in \nPajama Game, she succeeded in \nPal Joey. \nHer shy manner and \nsmall voice perfectly suited the \npart \nof \nLinda. \nUnfortunately \nthe reverse was true of Linda \nGarrett. \nWhile she might have \n.looked and acted the part of the \nvamp, the impression immediate\xad\nly disintegrated when she sang. \nNobody could have looked more \nlike a Joey than Jeffrey Gaynor. \nTall, slim, and dapper, Mr. Gay\xad\nnor counteracted the effect of his \nquaking voice with sure and easy \ngestures, and when not upstaging \nhs fellow actors, he was vexing \nthe audience into envious disap- I \nproval of Joey’s exploits.\nAs inevitably happens in these \nmusicals, the secondary charact\xad\ners stole the show. \nJudy Levy as \nGladys combined the grace of a \nballerina and the vitality of a \nCossack with a rich and vibrant \nvoice to assure her place as fore\xad\nmost in the memories of the audi-\n', 4, 0), (286.8101806640625, 427.4442138671875, 402.4739074707031, 450.1915283203125, 'Performance\n', 5, 0), (281.0600891113281, Only last week four people exploded in Cleveland, \nOhio—one of them while carrying a plate of soup. In case you’re \nthinking such a thing couldn’t happen anywhere but in Cleve\xad\nland, let me tell you there were also two other cases last week— \na 45 year old man in Provo, Utah, and a 19 year old girl in \nBangor, Maine—and in addition there was a near-miss in \nKlamath Falls, Oregon—an eight year old boy who was saved \nonly by the quick thinking of his cat Walter who pushed the \nphone off the hook with his muzzle and dialled the department \nof weights and measures. After \nall, lias not science in recent years brought us such marvels as \nthe transistor, the computer, the bevatron, and the Marlboro \nfilter? Oh, what a saga of science was the discovery of the \nMarlboro filter! Oh, what a heart-rending epic of endless trial \nand error, of dedication and perseverance! And, in the end, what \na triumph it was when the Marlboro scientists after years of \ntesting and discarding one filter material after another—iron, \nnickel, lead, tin, antimony, sponge cake—finally emerged, tired \nbut happy, from their laboratory, carrying in their hands the \nperfect filter cigarette! What rejoicing there was that day! \nIndeed, what rejoicing there still is whenever we light a Marlboro \nand settle back and enjoy that full-flavored smoke which comes \nto us in soft pack or flip-top box at tobacco counters in all \nfifty states and Cleveland!\nYes, science will ultimately solve the problems rising out of the \npopulation explosion, but in the meantime the problems hang \nheavy over America’s colleges. This year will bring history’s \ngreatest rush of high school graduates. Where will we find class\xad\nrooms and teachers for this gigantic new influx?\nWell sir, some say the answer is to adopt the trimester system. \nThis system, now in use at many colleges, eliminates summer \nvacations, has three semesters per annum instead of two, and \ncompresses a four year course into three years.\nThis is good, but is it good enough? Even under the trimester \nsystem the student has occasional days off. Moreover his nights \nare utterly wasted in sleeping. Is this the kind of all-out attack \nthat is indicated?\nI say no. I say desperate problems call for desperate reme\xad\ndies. I say that partial measures will not solve this crisis. I say \nwe must do no less than go to school every single day of the \nyear.. But that is not all. I say we must go to school #4 hours \nof every day!\nThe benefits o f such a program are, of course, obvious. First \nof all, the classroom shortage will immediately disappear be\xad\ncause all the dormitories can be converted into classrooms. \nSecond, the teacher shortage will immediately disappear because \nall the night watchmen can be put to work teaching calculus \nand Middle English poetry. And finally, overcrowding will \nimmediately disappear because everyone will quit school.\nAny further questions?\n© 1961 Mmc HRultnaw\n', 43, 0), (614.380859375, 1554.9927978515625, 862.9658813476562, 1586.9925537109375, 'Yes, one further Question: Have you tried Marlboro’s newest \npartner in pleasure— the unaltered, king-site Philip Morris \nCommander? J. \n22 Prospect St.\n', 66, 0), (1284.9400634765625, 1275.25732421875, 1477.250244140625, 1531.397216796875, 'Plenty! Consider the problem. Western Elec\xad\ntric manufactures the switching systems which \nconnect some 60-million Bell telephones \nthroughout the U. S. The average call over \ntoday’s electromechanical system requires 420 \nrelay operations. All together, this intercon\xad\nnecting equipment makes up the heart of what \nis, in effect, the world’s largest machine.\nThat’s where Western Electric and you \ncome in. The switching equipment for this \n“machine” involves an enormous manufactur\xad\ning job carried on by our plants throughout \nthe country. Because of the size and service \nrequirements involved, we require quality \nstandards far exceeding those of ordinary \nmanufacturing. The size of this job presents \nan unusual challenge to the engineer who may \nsave the Bell System many thousands of dollars \nby even a small cost-reduction step.\nWhile today s switching calls for a priority \non engineering, tomorrow’s will be even more \nexciting. For even now the revolutionary Elec\xad\ntronic Central Office is under field trial and \npromises to remake the world of telephony.\nFuture Western Electric engineers, working \nclosely with their counterparts at Bell Tele-\n', 67, 0), (1290.93896484375, 1537.8885498046875, 1683.4486083984375, 1566.3427734375, '„  , , , \na, Chicago 111 • Kearny N. S. Government or \nthrough private organizations and institutions to help \nforeign countries meet their urgent needs for skilled man\xad\npower.” Unofficially, it is a new adventure designed to \nwin friends for the U. S. by approaching foreigners on a \npersonal, non-political basis, thus thwarting present cold- \nwar techniques.\nMen and women, at least 18 years old, are eligible to \nvolunteer for the Peace Corps. \nApplicants need not be \n' college graduates, but should be people with trade skills \nor some special job experience. Before they are selected, \napplicants will bethoroughly interviewed, tested and re\xad\ntested, and specifically trained to serve in a particular area \nand in a particular capacity.\nMembers of the Peace Corps will not have an easy job. \nThis statement needs emphasis. Volunteers may find their \nwork tedious and full of frustration. Their living condi\xad\ntions will probably be poor. They will have to learn to \ncope with the deep distrust of the uninformed. Members \nof the Peace Corps will receive no salary—only an allow\xad\nance which is sufficient to meet their basic needs and to \nmaintain their health. \nFurthermore, service with the \nCorps will not exempt volunteers from Selective Service.\nDespite any of the inherent drawbacks of the Peace \nCorps, its potential worth seems to far outmeasure any \nharm which may result. \nWe have an “exciting genera\xad\ntion” of Americans who are willing and capable to aid \ntheir country and world. It seems only fair to-give these \npeople the training and opportunity to play their full part \nin the world community.\nBecause of the facilities available at Bucknell and the \nlarge number of foreign students enrolled, this University \nhas applied to become a training center for Peace Corps \nvolunteers. To foster interest and support in the Corps, \na conference is being planned by the Christian Associa\xad\ntion. By adequately informing and educating the students \nhere, it is hoped that Bucknellians will take an affirmative \nstand regarding this newest peace venture.\n", 5, 0), (469.4580078125, 452.1448059082031, 567.8126220703125, 891.640380859375, "somehow \ni have \na rather\n' uneasy feeling \nthat\nspring isn’t \ndue\nthis year\nthe way things are \ngoing at \nthis point \nsummer will \nmost likely \nfeature \nsports like \nskiing \nice skating \ndog sled races \nand\nsnow sculpture \ninstead of tans \nstudents will \nsport frostbitten \ntoes and\ncolds\nthe lack of\nsummer-type weather \nwill also \nseriously curb \nsome of the \nmore interesting \nspectator sports\nfor some of the \nfraternities located \nnear the sem who \nusually indulge \nin a bit of\nsun-porch watching \noh well \ncheer up \nthere should be- \nat least one or \ntwo interesting, snow \nball fights \nto liven up the \nscene\nSAM\n", 6, 0), (583.90966796875, 371.6216735839844, 880.753662109375, 409.0716247558594, 'Social Events or Saturday Classes? \nStudents Discuss Incompatibility\n', 7, 0), (583.2096557617188, 414.4393615722656, 880.9575805664062, 727.9847412109375, 'The \nmembers \nof \nPolitical!for entertainment Therefore, one \nScience 204, Public Opinion, are cannot be realistic and expect \nanxious to poll the members of ! that the mere abolition of umver- \nBucknell’s fraternities and sorori-1 sity social affairs will necessarily \nties \nconcerning \nthe \nfollowing, result in a more intellectual at-\nimosphere and more stimulating\nq \nt, \n/■ \nou \nu  .up nrPc \nand profitable Saturday classes.\n1. They must share \nthe burden of guilt because they \nare accessories before the fact.\nSome institutions unmentioned \nin the present investigation are \nas much involved as those whose \nimmature \nathletes \ncollaborated \nwith the gamblers. \nThe college \nbasketball is a rotten pumpkin. \nThe ethics of a lot of schools \nwould embarrass a shylock. \nIt is \nas if, instead of functioning as \nshrines of enlightment, they are i \nmobs competing for the control of \nthe underworld that college bas\xad\nketball has become.\nUniversities "Buy" Loyalty\nOriginally, \nbefore \nthe \nfixers \ncome, some universities buy the \nloyalty \nof their players. \nThe \nsatchel men merely offered big\xad\nger bribes. \nThe kids are taught \nthat even honor has a price. Ath\xad\nletic directors educate them to \nbelieve that they should go where \nthey can make the best deal.\nNever a season goes by that a \ncollege isn’t exposed as surrepti\xad\ntiously offering propositions to \nsteal kids from other universities. \nHardly a year passes without one \nbeing fined or suspended for giv\xad\ning boys clandestine benefits.\n', 2, 0), (273.82916259765625, 432.4059143066406, 427.8791198730469, 592.5533447265625, 'The kids wear the names of \ntheir college on their jerseys, but \nthe money from the hustlers is \nin the pockets of \ntheir \nstreet \npants hanging in the lockers. doesn’t happen, and I \ncontinues not to happen, one may \nhave to conclude that either the \nfilms are not comical or he just \ndoesn’t have a good sense of \nhumor.\nIt all started with Carry on | \nj Nurse, a British movie, with its \ncomedy heavily relying on some \ni broad, rather unsubtle humor. \nSet in a hospital, it perhaps sym\xad\nbolically caused me pain even to \nj force myself to did be\xad\ngin with a truly hilarious scene \nin which Ian Carmichael takes a \ntour through a candy factory, but \nas soon as the satire changed \nfrom \ncommercialism to labor- \nmanagement of shop steward was boring \nafter its first ten minutes. If WVBU truly represents that voice, it would \nbe wise for Bucknell to speak no more!\nNumerous weaknesses qf the radio station are apparent. \nFirst of all, WVBU is designed only for Bucknellians, but \nhow can it be at all effective if,many of the students and \nfaculty, who live on or nearby the campus, are unable to \nreceive its broadcasts clearly? Last year, when the sta\xad\ntion was relocated, there was talk about a new surge of \npower for WVBU broadcasts. \nHowever, more powerful \ntransmitting equipment still remains as WVBU’s basic \n| \nnecessity.\nThis one item, although stimulating WVBU, would fail \nto cure its other ills. \nBeing the student’s radio station, \nWVBU should cater to the students’ interests. To do this, \ni \nradio programming obviously needs to be increasingly \nj \nvaried. \nMany students are interested in music which \ntranscends rock and roll and jazz (especially the former). \nThis situation warrants an increased number of classical \nprograms. \nConcerts and lectures given on the campus \ncould be taped and broadcast. \nThus, students who are \nunable to attend or even those who are desirous of a re\xad\nrun could hear such events.\nWVBU could be used effectively in the area of politics. \nFor example, candidates for various student organizations \ncould speak to outline their plans. \nThis would enable \nmore of the student body to becme acquainted with them. \nSports events, especially away football and basketball \ngames could be broadcast when other local stations do not \ncarry these events. \nAll university-scheduled activities \nshould be announced daily. Finally, interviews, debates, \nand programs similar to the television “College Bowl \nwould enable the students to be stimulated on an academ\xad\nic level.\nMost of these changes would not increase the station’s \nexpenditures; the only need would be for more volunteers \nso that WVBU could operate a revamped program sched\xad\nule effectively.\nBy adapting these revisions, we hope that WVBU will \nemerge from its extended larval stage, and that the re\xad\nsults of this metamorphosis will be desirable.\n', 16, 0), (155.29714965820312, 877.5099487304688, 401.07916259765625, 903.5099487304688, 'Four Percent Straw\n', 17, 0), (141.5972442626953, 911.9720458984375, 422.6011962890625, 1385.73681640625, 'A student revolt against the four percent State sales tax \non textbooks and school supplies is snowballing across \nPennsylvania’s 88 college and university campuses. The \ndrive has reached the proportions of a State-wide lobby\xad\ning campaign aimed at the Pennsylvania legislature.\nTemple University is prodding its students to write to \ntheir local newspapers, telephone their ward leaders, and \nenlist the support of parents in bringing pressure to bear \non State legislators. We believe that SFC, the represen\xad\ntative organ of student government here at Bucknell, \nshould sponsor a similar drive against this tax. The State \nsales tax on textbooks and school supplies is an unneces\xad\nsary financial burden on college students in a period when \ntuition, room and board, and prices of texts and other \nsupplies have been rapidly rising.\nAlthough the tax bite on the individual student is small \n—probably no more than an average of $4 a year—and \nmay not seem to be a heavy burden, neither was the \nstraw that broke the camel’s back! \nThe average under\xad\ngraduate spends between $75 and $100 a year for text\xad\nbooks and supplies. This outlay is compulsory since we \nmust buy books in order to remain in school. Today, ed\xad\nucation is a necessity. However, its price is too high for \nmany students, and the tax on texts aggravates the prob\xad\nlem. Backers of the drive point out that the loss in state \nrevenue would be negligible—one estimate fixes the sum \nat approximately $500,000.\nAlbeit the small additional $4 cost of texts may seem \ninconsequential to most of us, there are some students \nwho are required to work their way through school, and \nthey are the ones who bear the brunt of the unnecessary \ntax levy. It is true that these students are in the minor\xad\nity. Yet, we are faced with a situation where the force \nof the majority could provide enough impetus to succpr \nthe cause of the minority.\nSo far, the campaign initiated by Temple University has \nhad little tangible success. Undergraduates have met with \napathy in the past in their lobbying because most students \nare not of voting age, and for this reason have not been \nable to sufficiently influence legislators. We hope that a \nconcerted push by Bucknell’s SFC (with student backing), \ntogether with the student councils of other colleges will \nbring favorable results in an effort to abolish this unnec\xad\nessary State tax. \n_______________________ ____\nIttrkniUian\n', 18, 0), (202.54100036621094, 1389.9813232421875, 366.0809326171875, 1434.0716552734375, 'OF BUCKNELL UNIVERSITY What did \nI you eat? . . . What did you get \n| bit by? \nWhat in the world would \n! you want to go there for? \nSel- \n! dom have I had the time in casual \n¡meetings like these to tell of the \nmany detailed experiences that \nI made last summer a milestone, \nj \nNow the time has come to tell \n! of some of these experiences such \nI as how we, a small group of col- \n| lege age girls and fellows, work\xad\ned side by side with Africans for \nlong hours every day, digging \nfoundations and making bricks to \nI build schoolhouses in the rain \nforest; how we traveled dark \njungle roads in the back of trucks \nto visit other small villages; how \n! we danced at a huge State Ball, \ncelebrating the independence of \na new African nation; how we \nheld our breath while eating hot \nI African food, or sighed a sigh of \nrelaxation when climbing onto \nour mahogany-board beds.\nMore than these accounts of \naction I remember the intangible \nexperiences that in our daily liv\xad\ning with our African friends help\xad\ned dispel their suspicions that all \nAmericans hate black people, that \nevery American city is a Little \nRock, that college students,' or \nAmericans in general, can not do \nmanual labor (because we have \nmachines to do everything), and \nthat America is not interested in \nhelping Africans strive for inde\xad\npendence.\nI’m not going to tell the whole \nstory now, but I will talk and \nshow slides this Sunday evening, \nApril 23, at 8 p. m. in Spotts Au\xad\nditorium. All students and mem\xad\nbers of the faculty and adminis\xad\ntration are invited to come.\nSince the mission and work of \nOperation Crossroads Africa is \n(Continued on Page 10)\n", 29, 0), (578.65087890625, 917.7791748046875, 728.8660888671875, 1115.128173828125, '2. How can we understand \nhim? Well sir, perhaps the best way is to take an average day \nin the life of an average dean. Here, for example, is what hap\xad\npened last Thursday to Dean Killjoy X. Young \nSigafoos had been writing a series of editorials urging the \nUnited States to annex Canada. When his editorials had evoked \nno response, hd had taken matters into his own hands. Accom\xad\npanied by his sports editor and two copy readers, he had gone \nover the border and conquered Manitoba. With great patience \nand several excellent Marlboro Cigarettes, the Dean persuaded \nyoung Sigafoos to give Manitoba back. Young Sigafoos, how\xad\never, insisted on keeping Winnipeg..\nAt 9 a.m. the Dean lit a Marlboro and met with Erwin J. \nBender, president of the local Sigma Chi chapter, who came to \nreport that the Deke house had been put on top of the Sigma \nChi house during the night by high-spirited undergraduates.\nAt 10 a.m. the Dean lit a Marlboro and went to umpire an \nintramural softball game on the roof of the law school where the \ncampus baseball diamond had been placed during the night by \nhigh-spirited undergraduates.\nAt 12 noon the Dean had a luncheon meeting with the presi\xad\ndent Ojf the university, the bursar, the registrar, and the chair\xad\nman of the English department at the bottom of the campus \nswimming pool where the faculty dining room had been placed \nduring the night by high-spirited undergraduates. \nHere, as Krull, he gives \nthe character an honesty and \nspecial type of naivete that go a \nlong way into making him such a \nlikeable rogue. \nKurt Hoffman \nmust also be applauded for his \nmasterful direction; rarely does \none see cutting and editing used \nwith such smoothness and variety.\nWhen the lights came on at the \nend of almost two hours, there \nwere few in the audience I wondered if I \nwas punishing myself for catching a cold in the first place.\nI was hesitant to ask my friends about it, but they assured me \nthat being mentally sick was just the same as being physically ill. \nOne of my friends who is very secure said that most people will tell \nyou about the time they had whooping cough or tonsillitis, but he \ntold people all the time about when he had paranoia and manic de\xad\npression.\nI was just trying to figure out whether there was any connection \nbetween my cough and the fact that I was once knocked unconscious \nby an icicle, when another friend who is very stupid and doesn’t \nread much suggested that I go to the infirmary.\n“Take one of these each hour and get plenty of rest,” he said; I \nfollowed his advice. \nAnd then the. funiest thing happened. Just like \nthat my cold disappeared.\nOnly trouble is, I can’t figure out what the pills symbolized psy\xad\nchologically. \nUndoubtedly something deeply, buried in my past. \nOne of the pills was white and looked like an aspirin, and probably \ndoesn’t symbolize much of anything. \nIt’s the other pill that disturbs \nme. \nIt was vaguely like the color of a rose.\n", 29, 0), I mean I haven’t been able to walk \nten feet on any campus in America without somebody grabs my \nelbow and says, “How did the different disciplines come to be \nmarked by academic robes with hoods of different colors, hey?"\nThis, I must say, is not the usual question asked by collegians \nwho grab my elbow. Usually they say, “ Hey, Shorty, got a \nMarlboro?” And this is right and proper. After all, are they not \ncollegians, and, therefore, the nation’s leaders in intelligence \nand discernment? And \ndoes not Marlboro deliver a flavor that is uniquely mellow, a \nselectrate filter that is easy drawing, a pack that is soft, a box \nthat is hard? Back to the colored hoods of academic robes. \nA doctor of philosophy wears blue, a doctor of medicine wears \ngreen, a master of arts wears white, a doctor of humanities wears \ncrimson, a master of library science wears lemon yellow. Why? \nWhy, for example, should a master of library science wear lemon \nyellow?\nWell sir, to answer this vexing question, we must go back to \nMarch 29, 1844. On that date the first public library in the \nUnited States was established by Ulric Sigafoos. All of Mr. \nSigafoos’s neighbors were of course wildly grateful—ail, that \nis, except Wrex Todhunter.\nMr. Todhunter had hated Mr. Sigafoos since 1822 when both \nmen had wooed the beauteous Melanie Zitt and Melanie had \nchosen Mr. Sigafoos because she was mad for dancing and Mr. \nSigafoos knew all the latest steps, like the Missouri Compromise \nMambo, the Shay’s Rebellion SchottiSche, and the James K. \nPolk Polka, while Mr. Todhunter, alas, could not dance at all \nowing to a ivound he had received at the Battle of New Orleans. \n(He was struck by a falling praline.)\nConsumed with jealousy at the success of Mr. Sigafoos’» \nlibrary, Mr. Todhunter resolved to open a competing library. \nThis he did, but he lured not a single patron away from Mr. \nSigafoos. “What has Mr. Sigafoos got that I haven’t got?” Mr. \nTodhunter kept asking himself, and finally the answer came to \nhim: books.\nSo Mr. Todhunter stocked his library with lots of dandy books \nand soon he was doing more business than his hated rival. \nBut Mr. Sigafoos struck back. To regain his clientele, he began \nserving tea free of charge at his library every afternoon. There\xad\nupon, Mr. Todhunter, not to be outdone, began serving tea \nwith sugar. Thereupon, Mr. Sigafoos began serving tea with \nsugar and cream. Thereupon, Mr. Todhunter began serving \ntea with sugar and cream and lemon.\nThis, of course, clinched the victory for Mr. Todhunter be\xad\ncause he had the only lemon tree in town—in fact, in the entire \nstate of North Dakota—and since that day lemon yellow has of \ncourse been the color on the academic robes of library science.\n(Incidentally^ the defeated Mr. Sigafoos packed up his library \nand moved to California where, alas, he failed once more. Enthusiastically hailed by both the \nfaculty and students, it was dedicated to the reaction of \nstudent apathy. The Forum’s goal was to bring outstand\xad\ning speakers to the campus to “introduce students to mat\xad\nters currently of concern to our society and to stimulate \nthem to new interests and serious thinking.”\nYet, recently the Forum has drifted away from its usual \nprocedures. \nLast year’s programs utilized a formal de\xad\nbate format in which two speakers discussed Negro voting \nrights, the place of censorship in a democracy, the con\xad\nnection between Labor’s bargaining power and its corrup\xad\ntion, and democracy as viewed by an American commun\xad\nist. The later Forum programs have been centered around \nsingle speakers and more specific topics—namely, planned \neugenics and contemporary art as understood by artist \nand layman.\nWhile both types of programs are manifestations of the \nForum’s intended scope, these most recent issues have in\xad\ncited little student interest. This apparent lack of appeal \nhas been characterized by decreased student attendance \n(as indicated when only 25 students were present for \nMonday night’s program; and hence, a decreased number \nof Forums has been the undesirabe result.\nIt seems to us that this deficiency may be traced back \nto several things. Perhaps students are more attracted to \nthe dehate style than to the lecture style. \nPerhaps the \nintellectual level of the many students cannot be equated \nwith the level on which the recent programs, have been \nconducted. Or, perhaps the Forum Committee’s lack of \norganization, substantiated by their inability to obtain \nspeakers in advance and the almost negligible amount of \nadvance publicity, has caused the present crisis.\nHoping that this situation is remedied, we offer these \ncriticisms because we feel that by now the Bucknell Stu\xad\ndent Foruni should have gained enough in experience and \nstature to rank among the mqst important organizations \non campus.\n', 5, 0), (586.7808837890625, 377.00335693359375, 656.1558837890625, 412.00335693359375, 'If the\n', 6, 0), (445.4408874511719, 456.2030944824219, 576.9126586914062, 831.69921875, 'i’ve heard \na rumor\nfloating \naround \nour fair campus \nthat \na\nfraternity is \nno longer \nin \nunless it is \nout\non social pro \nit seems to be \nthe thing \nthese days \ni guess “they” \nare trying \nto start\na new fad \nbut\nfor some strange \nreason \ni don’t \nthink it \nwill ever be as \npopular\nas fraternity parties \nafter all \n“they” \nseem to think that \nthe sole purpose \nof a fraternity \nis \nto house its \nmembers\nwe must be rather immature \nto disagree \ni do \nsuppose\nhowever \nit may \nbe “they”\nnot us who is slightly \nout of touch \nwith the world \nthere’s always hope\nSAM\n', 7, 0), (582.9434204101562, 413.4491882324219, 880.50146484375, 830.7442626953125, "by Bill Danneberg\nWhen I was very young, my grandfather ® ^ o u t h  ’09) told \n' me a story about a little school (they were called colleges then) ttiat \n| had a real problem. This announcement \nwas made today by the executive \ncommittee of the Law School Ad\xad\nmission Test Policy Committee at \nthe Conference of Western Law \nSchools, meeting at Stanford Uni\xad\nversity, Palo Alto, California.\nThe 80-minute writing ability \ntest is designed to measure the \nstudent’s command of grammar \nand diction as well as his ability \nto recognize verbose or unclear \nwriting. It will test his skill in \norganizing ideas and require him \nto demonstrate his competence by \nre-writing and editing prose pas\xad\nsages. The main purpose of the \ntest of general background is to \nmeasure the student’s awareness \nof the intellectual and cultural \ncontext in which the law func\xad\ntions. \nThe test is designed to \nindicate the candidate’s under\xad\nstanding \nof \nimportant \nideas, \nevents and cultural developments \nof the past and present. It will \ninclude 90 questions—30 in each \nof the three fields bf humanities, \nscience and social science.\nIn its present form, the Law \nSchool Admission Test is admin\xad\nistered in a single half-day ses\xad\nsion and is designed to measure \naptitudes closely related to spe\xad\ncific aspects of the study of law. \nWith the addition of the two new \ntests, the scope of the test will be \nbroadened to include the meas\xad\nurement of achievement in the \nareas of writing and knowledge \nof cultural background and it will \noccupy a full day. \nSeparate \nscores will be reported on the \naptitude test, the writing test, and \nthe test of general background.\nThe Law School Admission \nTest is administered four times \na year in November, February, \nApril, and August at test centers \nthroughout the United States and \nabroad. Educational Testing Ser\xad\nvice of Princeton, New Jersey, \nconstructs, administers, and scores \nthe examination for the Policy \nCommittee of the Law School Ad\xad\nmission Test\n', 33, 0), (1091.2789306640625, 613.645263671875, 1244.38037109375, 991.7426147460938, "relatively unnoticed and unat\xad\ntended.\nHowever, it appears that Buck\xad\nnell' students are not alone in \ntheir apparent apathy toward \nproms. I mean I haven’t been able to walk \nten feet on any campus in America without somebody grabs my \nelbow and says, “How did the different disciplines come to be \nmarked by academic robes with hoods of different colors, hey?” \nThis, I must say, is not the usual question asked by collegianç \nwho grab my elbow. Usually they say, “Hey, Shorty, got a \nMarlboro?” And this is right and proper. After all, are they not \ncollegians, and, therefore, the nation’s leaders in intelligence \nand discernment? And do not intelligence and discernment de\xad\nmand the tastiest in tobacco flavor and smoking pleasure? And \ndoes not Marlboro deliver a flavor that is uniquely mellow, a \nselectrate filter that is easy drawing, a pack that is soft, a box \nthat is hard? You know it!\n', 55, 0), (1420.0809326171875, 1091.9630126953125, 1668.4700927734375, 1509.1553955078125, "But I digress. Back to the colored hoods of academic robes. \nA doctor of philosophy wears blue, a doctor of medicine wears \ngreen, a master of arts wears white, a doctor of humanities wears \ncrimson, a master of library science wears lemon yellow. Why? \nWhy, for example, should a master of library science wear lemon \nyellow?\nWell sir, to answer this vexing question, we must go back to \nMarch 29, 1844. On that date the first.'public library in the \nUnited States was established by Ulric Sigafoos. All of Mr. \nSigafoos’s neighbors were of course wildly grateful—all, that \nis, except Wrex Todhunter.\nMr. Todhunter had hated Mr. Sigafoos since 1822 when both \nmen had wooed the beauteous Melanie Zitt and Melanie had \nchosen Mr. Sigafoos because she was mad for dancing and Mr. \nSigafoos knew all the latest steps, like the Missouri Compromise \nMambo, the Shay’s Rebellion Schottische, and the James K. \nPolk Polka, while Mr. Todhunter, alas, could not dance at all \nowing to a wound he had received at the Battle of New Orleans. \n(He was struck by a falling praline.)\nConsumed with jealousy at the success of Mr. Sigafoos’s \nlibrary, Mr. Todhunter resolved to open a competing library. \nThis he did, but he lured not a single patron away from Mr. \nSigafoos. “What has Mr. Sigafoos got that I haven’t got?” Mr. \nTodhunter kept asking himself, and finally the answer came to \nhim: books.\nSo Mr. Todhunter stocked his library with lots of dandy books \nand soon he was doing more business than his hated rival. \nBut Mn'Sigafoos struck back. To regain his clientele, he began \nserving tea free of charge at his library every afternoon. There\xad\nupon, Mr. Todhunter, not to be outdone, began serving tea \nwith sugar. Thereupon, Mr. Sigafoos began serving tea with \nsugar and cream. Thereupon, Mr. Todhunter began serving \ntea with sugar and cream and lemon.\nThis, of course, clinched the victory for Mr. Todhunter be\xad\ncause he had the only lemon tree in town—in fact, in the entire \nstate of North Dakota—and since that day lemon yellow has of \ncourse been the color on the academic robes of library science.\n(Incidentally, the defeated Mr. Sigafoos packed up his library \nand moved to California where, alas, he failed once more. The postures \nand dialogue of the Mullin family \nare all calculated to dramatize \nthe problem of speech without \ncommunication, in quasi-realistic \nterms. These freshmen will \nnaturally be looking to each and every one of you as the \nepitome of college! It therefore lies in your power to give \nthem that wonderful—everlasting—impression of campus \nlife!\nThe present freshman class has evaluated the program \nof freshman hazing and has made several constructive \nchanges in the procedure. The Freshman Week Program \nwill extend from the first Wednesday of classes to the \nfollowing Saturday. Within the four day period, hazing \nwill be much more rigorous and will be more strictly en\xad\nforced. Frosh men and women will wear the traditional \nsigns and dinks and will be responsible for B. U. songs. \nIn addition, the men will wear ties and unmatched socks; \nthe women Will have to observe certain dress rules, such \nas wearing one knee sock and one bobbie sock and will \nnot be allowed to wear any make-up during the program. \nAny frosh violators will have to perform before the soph\xad\nomore class audience. Frosh are forbidden to cut across \nthe grass and must be equipped with matches for the con\xad\nvenience of the upperclassmen.\nIt is hoped that this new Freshman Week Program will \nbe enthusiastically received and supported by ALL upper\xad\nclassmen. \nHazing is really a great, opportunity to meet \nyour fellow Bucknellians. \nIt’s up to YOU to make the \n“Hello Spirit” a success next fall and to make the Buck- \nnell hazing period truly memorable—but enjoyable—for \nthe frosht\n", 5, 0), (221.47593688964844, 787.402587890625, 349.7324523925781, 805.0526123046875, 'ALUMNI He \nnever gave his own squad’s score because there.never was any. \nHisi \nteam rarely penetrated the ten yard line—their own ten yard line. \nFinally, because his team traveled so much and was on the road so \noften, a bus was bought, all the students loaded aboard, and the \nschool was closed. \nIt’s now known as the Blue Ridge Bus Line.\nThe Why of Football\nSince those mythical days, Rip Engle has come a' long way in \nfootball, but admitted that until the last two years no one. had asked \nhim exactly WHY anyone should play football or participate in ath\xad\nletics. \nThe question was first asked him by the sponsors of a Euro\xad\npean clinic on the sport of football, as Engle and two other U. S. \ncoaches prepared to teach the fundamentals of the game. \nThe fact \nthat Rip Engle was nationally known, had coached winning teams, \nor had been President of the American Football Coaches Association, \nor all his other credentials were nearly as important as his message \nTuesday evening.\nEngle justified football and sports in general to his inquisitors \nby answering that the material rewards of athletics were insigifificant \ncompared to “feeling” that one receives from sports alone. The feel\xad\ning of exhiliration in a hard fought win. The feeling of running a \ngauntlet of emotion, ranging from despair, frustration, and exhaust\xad\nion to pride, joy, and the indescribable inward satisfaction of triumph. \nThe all important sense of accomplishment. Only sports provide a \ndynamic medium for this “feeling”.\nBoys giving of themselves under strain and pressure, displaying \ncourage, which Winston Churchill described as the “One quality that \nallows all others,” determination to win, and consequently knowing \nthe intense gratification of successfully fighting for some goal, were \nthe points of Engle’s thesis on sports. The “Giving” of oneself, the \nsacrifices, the lessons learned, the friendships made, are all a part of \nthe real rewards in sports.\nThese few paragraphs give only a brief picture of Rip’s philoso\xad\nphy on athletics, but for those who attended, it was refreshing to \nhear not a speech blasting the “Play for Pay” athletic image in \nAmerica today, but rather a tribute to those boys who seek and know \nthe real reward of sports.
